column2: ELSWORTH S. HOWELL, a judge, exhibitor and breeder of dogs, thinks judges should be required to submit written critiques on the dogs they place at shows. He says the practice would improve the judging situation materially. "The mental exercise of putting the reasons
A hundred civil rights pickets clashed with the police here early today outside a television studio where Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama was being interviewed.
ROME, Nov. 6 The Ecumenical Council approved as a basis for discussion today a draft decree on Bishops and the government of dioceses that is under continued criticism for its defects and omissions.
The most conservative city in the United States has unveiled what may be the most radical design for a Government Center.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 6 Democrats lost a four-year control of the Rockland County Board of Supervisors in yesterday's election, gained control of one town board and lost another.
The Pennsylvania, known for decades as "the Standard Railway of the World," intends to polish up some of its standards.
JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 6--Civil rights leaders said today they would conduct a statewide drive to register 80,000 Negroes who cast unofficial "freedom ballots" in the gubernatorial race here.
The Republican leaders of the Legislature stood firm against off-track betting yesterday despite the 3-to-1 vote endorsing it in the New York City election Tuesday.
Peter J. Brennan, president of the New York Building and Construction Trades Council, appealed yesterday for cooperation in giving qualified Negroes equal opportunities in the building trades.
Record sales and earnings were reported yesterday by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company for the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30.

GAMES in which desperado tactics rather than posi tionaj considerations carry most of the weight, create mounting excitement until the very end. In a recent Hungarian championship game, A. Dely vs. S. Koeberi, the balance kept swinging from one side to the other.

Seldom has there been an election with fewer broadly significant results, or one in which. either national party could find less legitimate reason for satisfaction. Unfortunately, a common thread of racial discrimination and the ignoble emotions it generates ran through many of Tuesday's races. Resentment against Negro progress in the areas of civil rights, housing,education and job opportunities tainted a deplorable number of the contests.
BOSTON, Nov. 6 Mrs. Louise Day Hicks, chairman of the Boston School Committee, emerged today as the top votegetter in yesterday's municipal election. She drew a total of 128,026.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 6 The Soviet Union, which had been using moderate language in the current session of the General Assembly, bitterly attacked West Germany tonight. In addition it accused the United States of having "artificially" created difficulties over the admission of an American troop convoy to West Berlin.
West Germany's crack riders demonstrated their flawless form once again last night by winning their second international jumping competition of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.
Robert G. Balcer has acted as an intermediary in behalf of a prominent Las Vegas gambler who has extensive associations with notorious underworld figures, it developed yesterday.
Victor Muscat and associates are forming a "protective committee" for stockholders in the Teleprompter Corporation, producer of group communications equipment.

The decisive defeat of Gov. Richard J. Hughes's $750 million bond proposal, coupled with the most impressive Republican legislative gains in New Jersey in a decade, posed serious problems yesterday for the Governor.
Strikebound cargo is beginning to pile up at New Jersey terminals in the port as a result of picketing by tugboat men of the National Martime Union's Local 333, known as the United Marine Division.

Walter H. Liebman, a lawyer and vice president of the Liebmann Breweries, Inc., which uses a double n in spelling the name, died yesterday in his home at 955 Fifth Avenue. He was 57 years old. The concern makes Rheingold beer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 The United States is preparing to extend diplomatic recognition to the provisional Government of South Vietnam tomorrrow or Friday.
The proposed acquisition of Whitmoyer Laboratories, Inc., by Sterling Drug, Inc., has Leen jointly terminated, the companies announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. warned here tonight that, if the civil rights bill does not clear this session of Congress, "I say to you this failure will become a debilitating sore on the body politic and it may lead to a night of darkness and violence."
The 33-player limit for American Football League teams is inadequate, Weeb Ewbank, the New York Jet coach, said yesterday. He also said the chances were "good" for an increase next year.
Higher education fared well in the two biggest bond issues appproved by voters in Tuesday's elections, late returns showed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 Nearly $35 billion of Government operating funds, supposed to have been appropriated and available last July 1, remained blocked in Congress today.
MOSCOW, Nov. 6 Premier Khrushchev said today "it is possible that you and I would not be here today" if the latest incident involving access to Berlin had not ended peaceably.
The touring company of "My Fair Lady," which started out March 18, 1957, in Rochester, will give, its final performance Dec. 14 in Toronto.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 6 The Suffolk Republican party lost the key race for county executive in yesterday's election but gained new strength on the Board of Supervisors and in town offices.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 In the dubious experiment of appraising Tuesday's state and municipal elections as a forecast of the outcome of the Presidential contest of 1964, perhaps the greatest weight should be given to the re-election of Mayor Tate in Philadelphia. For there the

BERLIN, Nov. 6 Maj. Gen. James H. Polk, United States commandant in Berlin, said today that the detention by Russian troops of a United States Army, convoy for 41 hours on the East German frontier had been a deliberate attempt "to call the shots on Allied access to Berlin."
HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 6 Stanley Kramer defended today the economics and ethics ofe his $250,000 press junket, the most lavish in Hollywood history.
A dinner at the Pierre next Thursday will open the 50th-anniversary program, of the Bank Street College of Education.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 6 Twelve-hundred Jewish com munal leaders were told tonight that they must consider the Negro's struggle for equality a major concern of the Jewish community.

The directors of Alleghany Corporation scheduled yesterday a stockholders' meeting in Baltimore Dec. 4 to elect a new board proposed by a majority stockholder group headed by Allan P. Kirby. Mr. Kirby recently regained control of the holding company from the Murchisons of Dallas.

Clarence W. (Gus) Benedict of Armonk, N. Y. was nominated yesterday to head the United States Golf Association in 1964. While golf's ruling body was announcing its slate of officers for the coming year, so did the Metropolitan Golf Association and the Westchester County Golf Association. In each case, nomination is the equivalent of election.
TRADITIONALLY the autumn is the coming out season for new housewares in the department stores. This year's bumper crop has already proved its popularity.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Nov. 6 A campaign to install a permanent marker at the site of the former home of President Ulysses S. Grant here was started today with a contribution from a 14-year-old boy.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 6 The rivalry among Ivy T-formation quarterbacks as providing some of the most exciting episodes in the league.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 The possibility that Washington's rock-bottom liquor prices might be pushed up sent members of both parties scurrying into the House of Representatives today to fend off the dire prospect.
Unsettled conditions prevailed on the London Stock Exchange yesterday as investors awaited today's two important by-elections in Britain.
ATHENS, Nov. 6 King Paul gave George Papandreou, leader of the Center Union, a mandate tonight to form a new Greek Government.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Nov. 7 A leader of the coup in South Vietnam said today that the rebellion there Friday had been touched off because the late President Ngo Dinh Diem broke a promise to his army commanders.

The effects of this year's drought on New York City's water supply may force the city to reconsider the ability of its water resources to meet its needs, the president of the Board of Water Supply said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6-The nation's largest shipowners' association demanded today that United States-flag vessels share in the shipment of all agricultural products to Soviet-bloc countries.
TRADITIONALLY the autumn is the coming out season for new housewares in the department stores. This year's bumper crop has already proved its popularity.
GRAND ISLAND, Neb., Nov. 6 (AP) Clarence Mitchell, one of the last of the spitball pitchers, died today of a heart ailment. He was 72 years old. ,

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Nov. 7 A leader of the coup in South Vietnam said today that the rebellion there Friday had been touched off because the late President Ngo Dinh Diem broke a promise to his army commanders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 Following is the text of the United States note delivered in Moscow protesting the detention of the American convoy on the Berlin autobahn. Identical notes were also delivered by the British and French Governments.
Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson of Canada appealed last night for strengthening the Atlantic Alliance and rejecting the ocean "as a line that divides the constituent nations into separate groups."
IN the heart of New York's paper and printing district there is one establishment where paper is sold by the sheet instead of in reams or tons.

The Cities Service Company reported yesterday that net income for the nine months ended Sept. 30, rose to $52,674,130, or $3.96 a common share; a gain of 17 per cent over the oil company's net earnings of $45,202,828, or $3.29 a common share, in the 1962 period.

"Ruddigore," the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta, will be performed by the Charles Pope Choristers at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. The presentation is for children from 9 to 16 years old. Admission is $1.25. For information call ST 3-6700.
The Cleveland Orchestra conducted by George Szell will introduce two Czechoslovak artists and two new works to New York during its three Monday concerts in Carnegie Hall in February.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 7 --Ground was broken today for the construction of a milliondollar addition to the Franklin D. Roosevelt Library. The ceremonies marked the first anniversary of the death of the late President's wife.
The city is looking for two men (or women) of even disposition with large and sinewy hands and brawny arms to work for $24 a day as farriers to the Police Department.
A secondary offering of 12,000 shares of First National Bank of Boston stock yesterday at $87 each was oversubscribed and the books closed. The underwriter was Keefe, Bruyette Woods of Boston.
Cotton futures advanced yesterday 25 to 75 cents a bale on the New York Cotton Exchange.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (UPI)-- Soybeans led a sharp rally in the grain futures market today on the Board of Trade and most cereals ended firm to strong.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 6--A spokesman for the military junta said today that there had been no American role in the coup d'etat tha toppled the Ngo family government.
LONDON, Nov. 7--Britain has accorded recognition to the new Government in South Vietnam, the Foreign Office announced today.
WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 7-- Funds for tennis courts and wall-to-wall carpeting for a new Coleytown junior high school here were denied yesterday by the Board of Finance.
Cook County, Ill., borrowed $20,000,000 yesterday in the bond market to finance an expressway.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 7 (AP)--A yearling, named Bre Hanover sold for $50,000 today and became the highest-price horse of the 1963 Harrisburg standardbred horse show.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7-- The worst kept political secret of the year, Governor Rockefeller's active pursuit of the Presidency, was officially ignored today by the two men most directly affected.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today that he would have no fear of living "next door" to a nuclear power station.
Virologists in New York took issue yesterday with the American Medical Association's recommendation for administration of viral vaccines very early in life.

The Grace Line has appointed Thomas J. Billington passenger manager for South America. In the new post Mr. Billington will be based in Panama. He joined the Grace Line in 1957 after serving with Furness, Withy Co.

Businesses borrowed an additional $250,000,000 from 14 large New York City banks in the week ended Wednesday, increasing the banks' outstanding level of business loans to a record $11,900,000,000. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said the rises were general.
WOLFVILLE, N.S., Nov. 7 (UPI)--Charles Fenwick Crandall founder in 1923 and former President of British United Press, died here today. He was 86 years old.

A 42-year-old patrolman who was allegedly involved with a ring that defrauded insurance companies of money after having destroyed stolen cars was dismissed from the force yesterday by Commissioner Michael J. Murphy.
A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. Stars, when they appear, are employed as follows: One star ...
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7-- Sales by department stores in the week ended Nov. 2, were 2 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) --A group to advise on ways of stepping up nationwide efforts to control tuberculosis was announced today by Dr. Luther L. Terry, Surgeon General of the Public Health Service.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7-- American official reactions to the proposed common price for grains in the Common Market ranged today from mildly unhappy to strongly adverse.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--An honorable man takes responsibility for his own acts, and this is what Governor Rockefeller is doing by entering the race for the Presidency.
PARIS, Nov. 7 (Reuters)-- The French Academy today awarded its 1963 Grand Prix du Roman, worth 5,000 francs (about $1,000) to Robert Margerit for his novels on revolutionary France.

Brig. Gen Russell Creamer Langdon, who received high decorations for heroism in the Spanish-American War and World War I, died Sunday in the Veterans Administration Hospital, Manhattan. He was 91 years old and lived at 448 Central Park West.
United States industry is planning to step up sharply next year its expenditures for new plants and equipment.
State Senator MacNeil Mitchell announced yesterday that he would reintroduce a bill in the Legislature that would permit artists to live and work in loft buildings in the city.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) --The downward trend in the nation's birth rate continued through August, the Public Health Service reported today.

PARIS, Nov. 7--The most important exhibition of works by George Catlin, the 19th-century American painter, to have been mounted in Europe for many years opens at the American Cultural Center here tomorrow.

For spectators and rooters, a collegiate football series has a long tradition. Columbia and Dartmouth, for instance, will face each other for the 34th time since 1899 when they meet at Baker Field tomorrow.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 7 (AP)--Ann Gregory, an executive of The Times of Vietnam, who has been in refuge at the United States Consulate here, left today to join her husband, Gene, in Hong Kong. The Gregorys' paper had supported the former regime.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP)--Ed O'Bradovich, a defensive end, was reactivated today by the Chicago Bears after being sidelined all of the National Football League season with a series of illnesses. O'Bradovich, a 225pound former Illinois lineman, will see limited duty Sunday against the Los Angeles Rams in Wrigley Field.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP)-- Canadian ships remained idle here today as picketing by the Seafarers International Union continued.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 7 (AP)--Ruth Jessen shot a oneunder-par 71 today and took the first-round lead in the $8,500 San Antonio Civitan women's open golf tournament.
Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz called upon building trades unions yesterday to recognize the slow progress being made in implementing their declared policy against racial discrimination.
WHITE SANDS MISSILE RANGE, N.M., Nov. 7--An Apollo moon-voyage capsule was hurled a mile into the desert sky today in its first launching test.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7-- Mrs. Ngo Dinh Nhu rested today at the Bel Air hilltop home of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Chase, where her three younger children may join her this weekend.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 7 (AP)--Arnold Palmer shot a 68 today and trailed Kel Nagle of Australia by a stroke after the first round of the 72-hole Wills Masters golf tournament.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP)-- John Wells, 27 years old, a jockey from Meade, Kan., suffered five fractured ribs today in a three-rider spill at Sportsman's Park.
Harvard men, whether they be in the Parker House or the White House, never get mad. They get angry, coldly, furiously angry.
BERLIN, Nov. 7--Allied officials reaffirmed today the West's determination to maintain unrestricted rights of access by land for the United States, British and French garrisons stationed in Berlin.

DETROIT, Nov. 7 (UPI)-- Record-hunting Gordie Howe failed again to get his 545th goal tonight, but he set up the only goal of the game on a picture-perfect power play to give the Detroit Red Wings a 1--0 National Hockey League trirump over the New York Ranegrs.
ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J., Nov. 7--Thomas J. Lipton, Inc. dedicated its new national ex ecutive office building and research laboratories today on a ...

Committee members have been announced for the fifth annual gourmet dinner and dance for the benefit of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York. The event, which is being sponsored by Lufthansa German Airlines, will be held in the St. Regis Roof on Nov. 20.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 8 (AP)--Dick Tiger, the world's middleweight champion from Nigeria, and Joey Giardello of Philadelphia today signed the contract for their 15-round title fight at Convention Hall on Dec. 7.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) --President Kennedy chose Dr. Donald F. Hornig, chairman of the Department of Chemistry at Princeton Univesrity, today, to be his Special Assistant for Science and Technology.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., Nov. 7-- Mississippi was described tonight as a totalitarian society enslaved by "obedience to an official orthodoxy almost identical with the pro-slavery philosophy."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7-- An inquiry into steamship conferences was announced here today by John Harllee, chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 7 (AP)--The Pennsylvania Game Commission extended the hunting seasons on duck and geese last night to make up for the days lost during a statewide hunting ban caused by the drought.
Four phosphatic fertilizer producers, an exporting corporation and three individuals were indicted here yesterday on charges of illegally fixing prices and allocating sales to export customers.
SAIGON, Nov. 7 (AP--The bodies of former President Ngo Dinh Diem and his brother Ngo Dinh Nhu were buried in secrecy yesterday, a relative said today.

The General Motors Aceptance Corporation, the financing arm of the General Motors Corporation, reported yesterday a decline in net income for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30. However, gross income increased in both periods.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 7-- Some of the traffic problems Speedy Scot was virtually certain to face in tomorrow night's two-tiered Dexter Cup Trot at Roosevelt Raceway were solved for the favored Castleton Farm colt early this morning and late tonight.

Rain or shine--and the weather man forecasts a tapering off of the former this afternoon--70 runners will plod over Van Cortlandt Park's five-mile course to determine the Heptagonal cross-country championships today.
The statement of account of the Bank of England for the week ended yesterday (in thousands of pounds) follows:

NEW DELHI, Nov. 7--In a note to the Indian Government, the new regime in South Vietnam has given assurances it will carry out "all past commitments." India has consular ties with both South and North Vietnam, but no diplomatic relations.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 7 (AP) --The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra revealed today plans for an 11-week tour of Europe and the Middle East during the summer and early fall of 1964.
When Giuseppe di Stefano stepped on the stage of Carnegie Hall last night a cheer went up from the large audience.
LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP)-- Carole Joan Crawford of Jamaica was crowned tonight Miss World 1963. The 20-yearold Miss Crawford won over 39 other girls from all over the world.

A daughter was born last Friday to Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Ayres of the Choate School, Wallingford, Conn., in the Grace-New Haven Hospital. Mrs. Ayres is the former Miss Irene Noble Uhl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin G. Uhl of Philadelphia. The child, the couple's third, has been named Elizabeth Ashton.
DETROIT, Nov. 7 (AP)-- The nation's auto makers are expected to set a weekly production record in passenger cars this week, with an estimated 188,988 units, Automotive News said today.
LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP)-- Shirley Bassey, a popular singer, gave birth to a daughter today. Miss Bassey is the wife of Kenneth Hume, a British film director.

Many horse-players in the metropolitan vicinity did something about yesterday's foul weather. They stayed away from the race track. Only 16,415 customers, the smallest crowd of the year, turned up for the thoroughbred activities at Aqueduct.
PARIS, Nov. 7 (AP)--A book by Jean-Jacques Susini about the outlawed Secret Army Organization was banned today in France.
The Moscow Chamber Orchestra, conducted by Rudolf Barshai, with David and Igor Oistrakh as violinists, will play in Carnegie Hall at 8:30 tonight.
Patrick Dennis, whose novels furnished Broadway with "Auntie Mame" and "Little Me," is becoming active as a playwright.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 7 --Isaac Cohen, founder and president of the Hudson County News Company, died of a heart attack today in Englewood Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 1305 Patterson Plank Road, North Bergen.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP)-- Representatives of two denominations--the Christian Churches (Disciples of Christ) and the United Church of Christ--took another step today toward possible merger.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 7 (Reuters)--A cholera epidemic in the Bogra district of East Pakistan has killed 230 persons 87 of them in the last three days, the Associated Press of Pakistan reported today. In Rangpur, another East Pakistan area, 134 persons were reported earlier this week to have died of cholera.
Sales of the Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation in the fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31 rose 7 per cent to a record $10,582,000, stockholders were told at the annual meeting yesterday.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 7 (AP)-- Don Meade, a jockey banned from racing since 1945, wants to get back into horse racing as a trainer.

Governor Rockefeller disclosed to the world yesterday a secret that was about as surprising as the fact that the day was Thursday. Through the medium of a nationwide, commercially-sponsored television show he informed the nation that he was a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination and that he would enter the New Hampshire primary next March.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--When a United States Senator attacks the leadership of both party groups in his branch of Congress, he compounds the heinous offense of criticizing his own.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Nov. 7 --Four engineers who spent 30 days on a mock space flight said today they found too little time for recreation and showers but would be happy to fly again --on another mock flight or a real one.

I am here this morning-- and I shall go to New Hampshire immediately following this meeting--formally to announce my candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination and my entry, at the proper time, in the New Hampshire primary election of March 10, 1964.

PRATO, Italy, Nov. 7 (UPI) --Nino Benvenuti, the Italian middleweight champion, beat Jean Cailleau of France on points in a 10-round bout tonight. Benvenuti weighed 159 pounds; the French boxer, 158 .
NONE of us, including Bing Crosby, are getting any younger. The crooner, youthfully attired in what appeared to be a blazer, was on the Columbia Broadcasting System ...
Bus service for residents of the Washington Square South area will be expanded beginning on Sunday, the Transit Authority announced yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 7--An attempt by the United States to amend a resolution by the African-Asian group condemning South Africa for her conduct in South-West Africa met vigorous objections here today.
The Follansbee Steel Corporation invited tenders yesterday on 100,000 shares of Ampco Metal, Inc., common stock at $10.25 a share. The offer expires Dec. 2.
A registered secondary offering of 350,000 shares of the common stock of the Mosler Safe Company at $23 a share was made yesterday by Blyth Co., Inc., and associates.
TOKYO. The spectacular growth of the Japanese stock market during the last decade has catapulted Japan's "Big Four" of the securities business into the ranks of the nation's most powerful companies.

MADISON, N.J., Nov. 7-- Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Ward have announced the engagement of Mrs. Ward's daughter, Miss Dorothy Ann McLaughlin, to David Aveling Iams, son of Jack Iams of Bay Head and the late Mrs. Iams.
FAIRFAX, Va., Nov. 7--It was a question in a tiny courtroom here today as to who was the more nervous--the witness or the lawyers who questioned her.

ALBANY, Nov. 7 (UPI)-- State Controller Arthur Levitt said today that local governments in 1962 spent almost $1.8 billion on education and libraries, and more than $9 million on welfare, health and hospitals.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--W. Averell Harriman left today for Argentina on a mission to keep a controversy over oil contracts with companies in the United States from erupting into a major disagreement.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7 (AP)--Wilt Chamberlain made 23 points and nine other San Francisco players helped in the scoring tonight as the Warriors routed the New York Knickerbockers, 110--88, in their National Basketball Association game at the Cow Palace.
A group of drugstore owners, members of the NassauSuffolk Pharmaceutical Society, Inc., agreed yesterday to a court order forbidding them to conspire to fix prices.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) --The Soviet merchant fleet is expanding rapidly while the United States cargo fleet is deteriorating, a Senate study said today.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 7-- American Jewish educators called today for a comprehensive revision in the curriculum and objectives of Jewish education.
Commissioner Joe Foss said yesterday the American Football League's annual draft of college football players would be held on Nov. 30, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 7 --A jury in Union County Court today acquitted Dr. Anthony Ruvolo, 40-year-old anesthesiologist, of the shotgun killing of Dr. Annunziato LaFace, 34, of Union, a former medical partner, on June 6, 1960.
The president of Macy's in New York asked the Moreland Act Commission yesterday to make it possible for suburbanites to buy lower-priced liquor at department store branches in their home counties.
MASSAPEQUA PARK, L.I., Nov. 7--A runaway boy, missing for nine days, returned home yesterday after having spent eight days in a hole in the ground in a woods four blocks from his house.

DETROIT, Nov. 7 (AP)-- Lowell Thomas, 71-year-old world traveler, news commentator and author, was under observation for a possible heart ailment today in Henry Ford Hospital at Detroit. Mr. Thomas complained of not feeling well after he attended a testimonial dinner for George F. Pierrot, a long time friend, last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) --Senators considering Paul H. Nitze's nomination as Secretary of the Navy gave him a thorough questioning on military proposals he raised three years ago but insisted today "I never have advocated."

Hermann Schridde, a 28-yearold farmer who jumps horses for the West German team with extraordinary ability, won both of yesterday's international events at the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.

The Damon Runyon Memorial Fund has received the five-story residence at 33 West 56th Street as a gift from Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, and E.M. Simon, a real estate man. The fund, which now is at 730 Fifth Avenue, will move its headquarters to 56th Street next year.
The cigarette industry may have placated some critics recently by voluntarily curbing ads directed at young people, but vehement opposition still remains.
SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Nov. 8--An army court approved today the release of former Premier Song Yo Chan on sick bail.
The stock market digested the initial impact of stiffer margin requirements yesterday and resumed its upward trend.
THERE is no dissembling in "The Immoralist." In this play that Ruth and Augustus Goetz drew from Andre Gide's book, the cause of a tormented marriage is defined with remorseless honesty.
ALGIERS, Nov. 7--Secret talks between President Ahmed Ben Bella and his chief political foes in Algeria were believed to be deadlocked today.
Final plans for the Grosvenor Ball, to be held Nov. 30 at the Plaza, were made yesterday at a tea at the home of Mrs. German H.H. Emory of 770 Park Avenue.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 7 (AP) --The Republican majority in the Wisconsin Senate today paid back Gov. John Reynolds, a Democrat, for his advice on what Republican candidates should do in the Presidential primary next April.
NASHUA, N.H., Nov. 7-- Governor Rockefeller became the first in his party today to announce his candidacy for the Republican nomination for President.

A work stoppage was staged yesterday in the commercial shops of the city's second largest manufacturing industry, printing and publishing, while union printers met at Manhattan Center on a deadlocked contract negotiations.
The Phelps Dodge Copper Products Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, announced yesterday the election of Edgar P. Dunlaevy as chief executive officer.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 7--The curfew imposed in the country on Friday at the beginning of the successful coup d'etat was lifted today.
TOKYO, Nov. 7 (AP)--Relations between Japan and Nationalist China, strained by the projected sale of a vinylon plant by Japan to Communist China, are reported at the brink of diplomatic rupture.
A secondary offering of 145,000 common shares of Donaldson Company, Inc., at $17.50 a share, was made yesterday by an underwriting group headed by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 7 (AP)--Policemen and National Guardsmen fought a gun battle today with sniper terrorists in the heavily populated workers' district of Caracas. At least eight persons were wounded.

The Lehn and Fink Products Corporation will acquire the Hallemite Manufacturing Com pany of Cleveland and the United States Sanitary Specialties Corporation of Chicago, Walter N. Plaut, president, told the company's annual meeting yesterday.

Stein Bros. Boyce, a member of the New York Stock Exchange for 110 years, has decided to join the trend toward incorporated brokerage houses. The concern, now known as Stein Bros. Boyce, Inc., announced that Joseph L. Abrams, a member of the exchange, had beem named a vice president and a director.
The Board of Higher Education announced yesterday that it would seek $84,027,597, an increase of nearly $20 million, for the operation of the City University in 1964-65.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 7 (UPI)--The defeated Republican candidate for Governor, Louie B. Nunn, and eight other Republican candidates for state office asked today for a recanvass of the vote cast in the general election Tuesday.

PARIS, Nov. 7--Which face of Communism is the bigger threat to the West? The Soviet general with his finger near the "go" button or the party agitator with a pocketful of plans for economic revolution? A dispute over whether the military or the political danger is the graver has arisen at the meeting ...
The naming of Dr. Lawrence W. Friedmann as director of medical services of the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled, East 32d Street and First Avenue, was announced yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 7--Advance sales for the New York World's Fair already total 2,000,000 tickets, British travel agents were told today by Thomas J. Deegan Jr., chairman of the fair's executive committee.
ROME, Nov. 7--A solemn "Te Deum" will be celebrated Saturday in honor of the oldest churchman attending the Ecumenical Council. It will mark his 101st birthday.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 7 (AP)--South Vietnam's provisional Government formally lifted today the ban on dancing imposed by President Ngo Dinh Diem's regime in May, 1962.

PARIS, Nov. 7--The United States proposal for a mixed-manned nuclear fleet was criticized today as a "military superfluity and therefore a waste." The state- ment was made at a conference of parliament members from countries in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

"Where is the Spirit of Moscow?" Ambassador Foy Kohler asked Premier Khrushchev at that Kremlin party yesterday. The question was a good one and entirely understandable in view of the verbal darts the Soviet leader was throwing at the West.
Lumber production in the country totaled 233,009,000 board feet in the week ended Nov. 2, according to reports received from regional lumber associations.
The Georgia Power Company raised about $37,000,000 yesterday on competitive sales of bonds and preferred stock.
McCrory Corporation a 1,500store retailing chain, confirmed reports yesterday that it had sold its 30 Yellow Front stores and a warehouse in Alabama for an amount "in excess of $1,000,000."

Criminal Court Judge Edward T. Galloway of the Bronx died yesterday of a heart attack at the home of a sister, Mrs. John T. Holden, in White Plains. He was 63 years old and lived at 325 East 201st Street in the Bronx.
NEWARK, Nov. 7--An American electronics engineer and a Russian chauffeur were indicted here today on espionage conspiracy charges.
The City Department of Hospitals is widening an experimental program of evening clinics in municipal hospitals.

Robert W. Dowling, chairman of the Citizens Committee on Off-Track Betting, promised yesterday to devise a "termiteproof and vermin-proof" system for the proposed city betting shops.

PARIS, Nov. 7--Thirteen leading French intellectuals have appealed to France, and indirectly to the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union, to devote half of 1 per cent of their military budgets to international cancer research.

Capt. Robert E. Lindquist, the master of the American Export liner Constitution radioed from the mid-Atlantic yesterday that he had taken aboard a sick passenger from the Netherlands freighter Archimedes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) --Six member of President Kennedy's Cabinet will fly to Tokyo to attend the third meeting from Nov. 25 to 27 of the United States-Japan Committee on Trade and Economic Affairs, the State Department announced tonight.
PRAGUE. FIFTEEN years of Communism have turned the socio-economic system in this old, and now gloomy, city upside down.

Local and long-distance trucking is an indispensable element in the nation's transportation lifeline. A nationwide stoppage in this field would cut off much of the movement of fresh food from farm to market, force hundreds of thousands of factory and store workers into idleness and paralyze the transportation of foreign and domestic goods through American ports.

ATHENS, Nov. 7--George Papandreou, 75-year-old head of the Center Union, which gained a plurality in last Sunday's elections, submitted his proposed cabinet to King Paul today. The premier-designate said his ministry would be sworn in tomorrow.

The prospect that today's "Whiz Kids" among scientists and engineers might become tomorrow's has-beens if they do not continue their education was pictured yesterday at a conference at Columbia University.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) --A Congressional study of whether a national scenic highway system should be established was approved today by the Senate Public Works Committee.

A Newark, N.J., lawyer who headed a committee of dissident stockholders that has previously been at odds with management of the Curtis Publishing Company, announced yesterday he supported the company's proposed $35,000,000 refinancing plan.

A report in The New York Times yesterday about the elections in Westchester County implied incorrectly that Mayor Stanley W. Church of New Rochelle, a Democrat, had been defeated. Mr. Church was not a candidate. Raymond Calgi, another Democrat, was defeated for Mayor.

BOSTON, Nov. 7 (UPI)--The Toronto Maple Leafs fought back from a first-period threegoal deficit tonight to gain a 4--3 National Hockey League victory over the last-place Boston Bruins on Tim Horton's lastminute goal.
A PAIR of contemporary works, along with Mo zart's "Jupiter" Symphony, made up last night's program of the New York Philharmonic under the direction of Josef Krips.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Nov. 7--The biennial conference of the Food and Agriculture Organization will convene in Rome on Nov. 16 for a three-week session.
The country's electric power production last week rose 7.4 per cent from the 1962 level, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.
Prices of Government bonds turned steady yesterday, after having declined for seven con secutive sessions. However, Treasury bill prices fell further.
SO much of Joan Miro's work has been a sort of delicate surgery on the unconscious--extracting its organs and forms with aseptic precision.

The bargaining over shipping rates in the oneshot, fast-dollar wheat deal with Russia is obscuring its fundamental significance: opening the way for what Senator Humphrey has called "a broad review" of American trade with the East.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 7 (UPI)--The National Collegiate Athletic Association today anpounced a two-year plan, beginning, in 1964, to televise annually 29 major college football games and to allow smallcollege teams complete freedom in televising their games.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) --J. Dewey Daane, named by President Kennedy to the Federal Reserve Board, rejected today speculation that he was a fiscal conservative and would line up with the "tight money" faction.
LONDON, Nov. 7--Directors of The Spectator approved today the appointment of Iain Macleod, former joint chairman of the Conservative party, as the new editor of the London weekly.

Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey will be the principal speaker today at the annual Veterans Day ceremony in the Custom House sponsored by the Bowling Green Post of the American Legion. Veterans Day will be celebrated Monday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7-- Loadings of rail freight in the week ended Nov. 2 rose above the volume in corresponding week of 1962. Intercity truck tonnage declined slightly during the same period.

A REVIVAL appears likely this fall for the Murphy bed, which fell out of style in the late nineteen-twenties, after being a household word for nearly 30 years. Three furniture manufacturing concerns are introducing their own versions of the modern wall bed.
An accident and riot similar to those at Roosevelt Raceway last night occurred at Yonkers Raceway on Oct. 29, 1956.
World and domestic sugar futures rebounded yesterday after having declined the day before.

The city's commercial rent and occupancy tax survived its first court test yesterday when the State Supreme Court ruled that however unpopular, it was constitutional.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP)--The Hanna Mining Company and a subsidiary were sued by the Government today for more than $1.8 million in alleged overcharges on Government purchases of nickel.
The third conversation on church union between the Christian Churches (Disciples of Christ) and the United Church of Christ ended Thursday in Chicago on a note of confidence.

The London stock market recovered yesterday from sharp initial losses. Industrial shares, which bore the brunt of the early selling, closed mixed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8.-- Retail sales, somewhat sluggish in August and September, rose briskly in October to set a new high for the month, the Commerce Department reported today.

A recent invention by a 42year-old sailing enthusiast from Jackson Heights, Queens, seems likely to catch the fancy of pleasure boating's avant garde.

A vaccine combining the killed-types of measles virus and the three types of polio virus has proved as effective as either vaccine used singly, it is reported in the current issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association by a team of medical workers from Terre Haute, Ind., Syracuse, N.Y., New York City and Denver, Colo.

WASHINGTON. AMERICAN Presidential nomina tions are essentially transfers of a political party's titular leadership from one man to another. In a party of diversified interests, geographical differences and wide philosophical range, if that transfer cannot be accomplished in a manner that leaves all the party elements reasonably satisfied, the nominee must enter the general election with his coalition broken and his strength dissipated.

No assembler of a corporate empire has ever fitted together the building blocks of his colossus with more calculation than James R. Hoffa. The 50year-old president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters is not a patient man.

ROME, Nov. 9--Pope Paul VI gave his full support today to the European unity movement and the establishment of a "pacific, organic and unified" Europe to insure that the "tragic history of our century" shall not be repeated.
Through a recent flurry of acquisitions, the oil industry has obtained a vastly improved position in the agriculturalchemicals business.

AS they chatted and milled about in the cheerful confusion of a pre-departure celebration held here on a recent evening, a happy group of Swedish visitors spoke in glowing terms of their monthlong tour of the United States and of the unique project that made the trip possible.

LITTLE Puerto Rican Jose is "the man of the family" to his widowed mother and younger brother, Tomas, shivering in their first New York winter. As Christmas draws near, 10year-old Jose resolves to earn the money for a wonderful present--a warm woolen blanket for his mother.

DESPITE the liveliness and interest of its informative text, Edward Steichen's autobiography is primarily a gallery of great images.

THE first lunar voyage, perhaps less than 10 years away, should bring the answers to questions that have puzzled earth's scientists for centuries. This, the director revealed last week, is a comedy, tentatively titled "Mickey-O" and written by Alan M. Surgal, a newcomer to the medium. It will be made for Columbia Pictures.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 9-- Eight Princeton homes will be open on Dec. 3 for a tour arranged by the Association of the New Jersey Neuro-Psychiatric Institute.

Archbishop Molloy of Queens continued its two-year domination of Catholic High School cross-country by retaining the Marist championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. Peter Farrell of Molloy was the individual winner.

The Longchamps restaurant chain, in the wake of an investigation into its hiring practices, has adopted a "policy to assure equal employment opportunities" for Negroes, the State Commission for Human Rights announced yesterday.

One of the most unusual sights at the New York World's Fair will not be seen by visitors when the fair opens on April 22, Most of the steel frames that have been fashioned into airy circles, triangles, curves, arches and soaring free-forms will be Covered with exterior building materials by opening day.
A distraught woman recently called the Jewish Child Care Association and said: "Please, I must speak to Miss Sussman. I hear that she can help anyone."

SALEM, Ore., Nov. 9--The Oregon Legislature convenes here Monday for a special session called by Gov. Mark O. Hatfield after the voters rejected an income tax increase on Oct. 15 and made a $55,000,000 hole in the state's current twoyear budget.

The robbers who took jewelry and gold said to be worth at least a million dollars from a messenger service here Friday left about 85 per cent of the loot behind, the police said last night.

A Chicago man, brimming with P.M.A. (positive mental attitude), recently enthusiastically discussed his plan to sell insurance in England, the cradle of the industry.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9--The United States has decided to resume a key program of economic aid to South Vietnam. The program was suspended in August in an effort to get Ngo Dinh Diem, then President, to introduce political reforms.

THE controversy started by the publication of Merriam-Webster's Third International Edition still rumbles through the press, and the spate of books and articles that it has produced has furnished thousands of classrooms and cocktail parties with material for arguments. News that the Automatic Canteen Company has fielded the multimillion-dollar contract for all concessions at Yankee Stadium has hardly caused a ripple in the vending-machine industry.

AN attempt to revive Tampa, Fla., as a cruise-ship port will be made this month. Next Saturday and again on Nov. 30, the 424-passenger Yarmouth will sail from Tampa to Jamaica, and on Nov. 23 the vessel will leave on a cruise to Mexico. Each trip will be of a week's duration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) --The number of persons receiving Federal-state public assistance payments increased by 285,000 in the year ended June 30, the Bureau of Family Services said today. It said there were 6.8 million beneficiaries as the fiscal year ended.

HOLLYWOOD. ANY visitor to the Desilu Culver City studio might think that Hollywood is trying these days for a new high in irrationality. For day after day, while Julie Andrews sings, all recording and film equipment is idle. But when she talks, the camera and sound equipment are in full force. The explanation is that Miss Andrews is starting a new phase in her career and that singing is her solace for taut nerves.

Mitch Miller has added a backstage ingredient to his weekly community sing, but viewers who join in the chorus from the privacy of their homes would never guess that the extra element was dancing instruction.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 10 The Pittsburgh Steelers, dominating three-quarters of the game, dropped the Cleveland Browns into a tie for first place in the National Football League's Eastern Conference today by beating them, 9-7, before 54,497 customers. This was the first sellout crowd to attend a professional game at Pitt Stadium.
Business investment in new plant and equipment may not be a very powerful stimulant to over-all economic activity in 1964 if the latest survey on corporate spending plans turns out to be correct.
GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 10 The annual Christmas bazaar for the benefit of the Greenwich Exchange for Women's Work will be held here on Wednesday and Thursday at the Round Hill Club.
Hermann Schridde brought West Germany its sixth international jumping victory and the team title of the National Horse Show last night, and proved himself a poor prophet.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) Roger Leclerc booted field goals in the first and third quarters and the Chicago Bear's defense was unbeatable today as the Bears scored a 6-0 victory over the Los Angeles Rams.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 10 W. Averell Harriman was understood today to have warned Argentina that her plan to cancel contracts with United States oil companies could sharply impair her prospects for future American help.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 The United States Information Agency is engaged in a major overhaul of its program in western Europe. It plans to put new emphasis on direct personal contacts with European intellectuals and opinion-makers and cut back its mass distribution of American books, movies and periodicals.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 10 Erie's Bingo, a 4-year-old owned and handled by Robert MeLean of Fort Washington, Pa., today won the English springer spaniel amateur allage stake at the 30th annual Copnecticut field trial.

It is not often that one hears the sort of virtuoso cello playing that filled Town Hall last night when Daniel Domb, a 19year-old cellist born in Israel, presented his debut recital. He was the second of this year's Concert Artists Guild Award Winners.
EVERY Saturday morning through Dec. 7 there is some lively play between aspiring masters at the Chess and Checker Club of New York, 212 West 42d Street.
MANILA, Nov. 10 (AP) President Diosdado Macapagal returned today after a hard campaign in the provinces for Senate seats for his Liberal party candidates in Tuesday's off-year elections.
The Central American country of Honduras will soon have a $500,000 seminary to train young men for the Roman Catholic priesthood.

Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said yesterday that a deadlock at the 1964 Republican National Convention could thrust former Vice President Richard M. Nixon into the race for the Presidential nomination.

Paul O'Dwyer, newly elected Councilman at Large from Manhattan, proposed yesterday that a new Charter revision commission be named to devise "a more equitable representation" system than the one under which he was elected.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) Senator Barry Goldwater brushed aside today suggestions that he might need to advance his hour of decision on the 1964 Presidential race because of Governor Rockefeller's announced candidacy.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 10 (UPI)--The Baltimore Colts scored the first four times they had the ball today and then held on to defeat the Detroit Lions, 24-21, in a National Football League game.

But Cassius has destroyed his image and antagonized those who normally would be rooting for him. He has assumed the pose of a loudmouthed braggart of such irri tating proportions that many folks are hoping he gets his block knocked off. It's a pity.
The New York Chamber of Commerce called on Congress yesterday to approve the $11 billion tax cut proposed by the House Ways and Means Committee.

Wall Street's formula for profit "buy low and sell high" is being applied successfully by a majority of the nation's 33,000 franchised automobile dealers. With. 1964 car sales off to a record start and indications that the trend is upward, intense competition is limited.

LONDON, Nov. 10 The London Stock Exchange had byelection jitters last week. Prices drifted lower in the first four days in anticipation of a Labor party victory at Luton. On Friday morning, when these expectations materialized, price continued to drop.

THE man who collects, protects, releases and polices the city's water supply is, like water itself, largely taken for granted, but always on tap to do the job.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 10 The order trend was still upward for steel mills last week. Most mills were starting out the month a little faster than they started October. Orders were down from brisk rates of late October. However, when allowance was made for peak-andvalley buying patterns, it appeared that demand was still climbing.

Frances Grimes, a sculptor, died here Saturday at the age of 94. Until entering Midtown Hospital four years ago, she had lived at 229 East 48th Street.
David Sarnoff, chairman of the Radio Corporation of America, is smiling these days; and, with good reason.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 10 (Reuters) Policemen and troops clamped a tight security cordon around a Russian-built sports arena here today amid reports that anti-Government rebels were trying to sabotage the first Games of the New Emerging Forces.

Fessenden Seaver Blanchard a marketing and management consultant, suffered a heart attack Saturday while watching the Harvard-Princeton football game at the Harvard Stadium in Cambridge, Mass., and died while being taken to a hospital. He was 75 years old.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 10 (UPI) Maj. Andrian G. Nikolayev and his bride, the former Valentina V. Tereshkova, a captain, arrived here today to begin a two-week visit that will involve many speeches and ceremonies.

The New York concert scene, until recently arranged according to well-established traditions, is in the midst of change. The resulting ferment, already apparent in New York, is beginning to be felt all over the country.

VIENNA, Nov. 11--Albania has accused Premier Khrushchev of plotting with an Albanian woman Communist, purged three years ago, to overthrow the Enver Hoxha regime.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 11-- Yale freshmen are so carefully selected that the college no longer considers it fair to use students' academic standing in college as criterion for continued scholarship aid.

Some brokers have noticed a pickup in the ,activity of the lower-price stocks lately, such as Chris Craft, Ampex, American Motors, Martin-Marietta, and even a slight increase in interest in Brunswick. They attribute it to the recent increase in margin requirements from 50 per cent to 70 per cent.
GENEVA, Nov. 11--The Economic Development Committee of the European Free Trade Association began its first session here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11--The Secretary of State, who is a man mild of manner and speech but--as they say in his native state of Georgia--"sot in his ways," last week supplied one of the two reasons for Congress's sharp reduction in the foreign aid budget when he said he doesn't "understand it."
WASHINGTON, Nov.11--Another Federal agency joined today the widening investigation of Robert G. Baker's business activities.
"The sturdy sons" of City College have quietly yielded to the school's "devoted daughters."
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (UPI)-- Dr. Norbert J. Scully, a leading plant physiologist, died today in his office at Loyola University. He was 49 years old.

BONN, Nov. 11--Foreign Minister Gerhard Schroder's effort to revive German influence in Eastern Europe has moved another step forward with the initialing of a new three-year trade pact agreement with Hungary.
"Competition and low-profit margins are the big problems facing the food industry."

ALLAN SLOANE, who for many years has wielded one of the most sensitive pens in television and radio drama, has never written a more poignant and touching work than his play last night, "And James Was a Very Small Snail."

Employee of the new Holiday Inn, an 18-story hotel at 440 West 57th Street, drank a champagne toast yesterday in front of the main entrance as part of a ceremony marking the opening of the hotel. The building is the 424th in the Holiday chain and cost about $11,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI)--The Atomic Energy Commission announced today the start-up of an experimental sodium-cooled nuclear plant designed to generate electricity and also produce more fuel than it consumes.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 11 --The life expectancy of white American men who are now 50 years of age would be 1.4 years greater if none of them smoked, according to a Harvard University epidemiologist.
The Hospitals Department has appealed to several leading voluntary hospitals to establish ambulance services, so that emergency cases in their areas can get immediate treatment.

Directors of the FidelityPhiladelphia Trust Company declared yesterday a year-end extra dividend of 40 cents a common share. The dividend is payable Dec. 6 to holders of record of Nov. 20.
Two men were arrested here yesterday as they attempted to sell $120,000 worth of stolen Government bonds, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported.
PARIS, Nov. 11--Andre Malraux, Minister for Cultural Affairs, addressing the Chamber of Deputies, issued a stirring appeal to France last Friday to shoulder the burden of man's cultural destiny.

AMERICAN history is a proper study for an American historian. This once rather bold idea has been advanced excel lently by Arthur M. Schlesinger (the elder) who must count among his contributions a young historian of the Jacksonian and Rooseveltian eras.
Protest rather than commemoration was the theme for one group of 80 veterans yesterday as they picketed the 95th street Armory over alleged segregation in New York militia units.

JURG VON VINTSCHGER, the young pianist from Switzerland who made his American debut last night at Town Hall, is a veritable tornado on his instrument. His fingers are fast, his ear for sonority is sharp, his control of nuance refined to a high degree.

Paul Hall, president of the Seafarers International Union, attacked Canada's maritime trusteeship law yesterday as "one of the most alarming situations the free trade union movement has ever confronted."

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 11--It took Mongo less than 148 seconds to finish first in today's Washington D.C. International, but the next 15 minutes--until he was officially declared the winner--were long, complex and emotional. To the crowd of 36,653 jammed into this pretty park under a bright and warming autumn sun, the 4-year-old
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Nov. 11--Ten Latin-American countries asked the General Assembly today to give its blessing to studies of measures needed to establish Latin America as a nuclear-free zone.

THE big buck shifted slightly as he lay under the sheltering overhang of a spruce tree. His ears twitched as he listened to the small sounds in the forest. Occasionally, his black nose would test the foggy air currents swirling around the mountainside.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11--A physical education "class that escalated into small-time intercollegiate football flared into a big-time controversy on the University of Chicago campustoday. The university's administration vowed the "non-football class," as it has been called, would continue next year.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reached agreement with the Communications Workers of America yesterday on a new contract covering 22,600 of its long-lines workers.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 11-- Castleton Farm of Lexington, Ky., a harness-racing outfit that needs more money as Niagara Falls needs more water, added the Westbury Futurity Trot to its list of recent stakes victories tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.
Donahue Coe, Inc., and Ellington Co., Inc., have agreed to merge their operations, creating a new agency with billings of nearly $50,000,000.
The Secretary General, U Thant, hinted last night that it might not be wise or even possible to keep Communist China out of the United Nations indefinitely.

Steel production continued its tortuous advance last week, rising a slight seven-tenths of 1 per cent from the output of the preceding week. The nation's steel mills melted 1,958,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings last week,
THE jet-age prima donna is perforce a planner. She maps out design and fitting sessions and supervises the shipping, storage and refurbishing of her own opera costumes with the acumen of a general.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11-- The United States and the Soviet Union will begin negotiations in Moscow next Tuesday for a new cultural exchange agreement. However the relative calm in East-West relations is not likely to lead to any significant expansion of contacts.

Leaders of New York City's civil rights organizations--who last summer mounted demonstrations that resulted in the jailing of more than 700 persons--yesterday expressed frustration arid disappointment in direct action as a means of achieving integration in the building trades.

Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon reaffirmed last night that he was not a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination. He said he believed he could "best serve my party and my country as a constructive critic."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 11--Two military appointments have indicated to United States military men that the governing junta intends to step up the war against the Communist guerrillas.
A much simplified method of screening women for cancer of the cervix has been developed by scientists in Baltimore. It has been tested during the last year on several thousand Maryland women.
George Meany asserted yesterday that the main issue confronting the labor movement and the American people was the achievement of jobs for all.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11-- President Kennedy placed a wreath on the Tomb of the Unknowns today as the nation honored its war veterans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11-- Administration officials suggested today that the threatened cancellation of Argentina's contracts with United States and European oil companies could upset efforts to get Congress to vote more funds for the Alliance for Progress.

The Jacob Ruppert Brewery has acquired Esslinger, Gretz and Keglet Beers of Philadelphia, it was announced yesterday by Marvin Kratter, chairman of Jacob Ruppert.
McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Oct. 28--McMurdo is digging out today from under a 14-hour blizzard in which gusts of 83 miles an hour shook the station's buildings much as a dog worrying a bone.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11-- After a brief Veterans Day, holiday, Congress will return tomorrow to legislative fare of leftovers for which few members any longer have much appetite.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 11 (AP)--The Irish Republican Army began a new organizational drive here today as it paid homage to the Irish brigade that fought in the Battle of Gettysburg 100 years ago.

More of the loot from Friday's West Side jewelry hijacking was recovered early this morning in a building demolition site near the scene of the holdup. A large part of the loot was found shortly after the robbery.

A marathon symposium on the compatibility--or incompatibility--of the arts with the technological age ran through 11 speakers yesterday, starting with August Heckscher at 10 in the morning and ending with Associate Justice Arthur J. Goldberg of the Supreme Court at 10 in the night.

Business and industry here, in the face of the civil rights revolution, have been reassessing their employment policies and hiring Negroes for office and other salaried posts that they rarely held before.

Trading in frozen shrimp began yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The closing prices of the shrimp futures were 88.5 cents a pound for the January contract and 90.5 cents for the March position. Volume came to 65 contracts, equal to 325,000 pounds.
PARIS, Nov. 11--Andre Le Troquer, Speaker of the French National Assembly in the Fourth Republic, died of cancer early this morning in a hospital near Paris. He was 79 years old.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Nov. 11 --President Joao Goulart has challenged the validity of the Alliance for Progress as a workable remedy for Latin America's economic problems. He called on the Latin-American countries today to unite in defense of their common interests in trade and aid.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11-- From the Rose Bowl to last place in the Big Six in two years. That's the unenviable slide the University of California at Los Angeles football team has taken.

Anton Bilotti, concert pianist and composer, died on Sunday in University Hospital at the age of 57. He lived at 903 Park Avenue.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 11--This week promises to be a make-itor-break-it week for the Common Market.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Nov. 11 --A 28-day strike of 4,500 hourly paid workers at two Oak Ridge atomic plants ended late tonight. Officials of the Atomic Trades and Labor Council, representing 16 unions, announced that the membership had voted overwhelmingly to accept a company offer.

Most industrial shares made modest advances on the Zurich Borse yesterday as a result of a forecast of greater liquidity in the Swiss money market. The biggest gainers were Ciba, Hero-Conserven, Geigy and Suchard. German shares were off in the foreign sections, while most dollar stocks were firm.
MOSCOW, Nov. 11--Reports circulating in Moscow's Western community last week have mentioned two rocket pioneers as likely key figures in the Soviet space program.

Nov. 21 will be an eventful day in the career of Ronnie Kroll, an 8-year-old actor. On that night, Ronnie, who had been one of 16 youngsters in "Oliver!," will return to the Lionel Bart musical, based on Charles Dickens's "Oliver Twist." This time he will perform the arduous name role at a commensurate increase in salary.

YESTERDAY was California day in New York as the spring ready-to-wear fashion openings started their third week. Two California designers showed their collections here--and the mild weather made them feel at home.

The Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig, senior minister of New York's four Collegiate Churches and pastor of the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, died yesterday in Istanbul, Turkey. He was 74 years old.

MORE than 1,500 nationally licensed drivers competed in automobile road races in the United States this year. Most of these drivers were involved in purely amateur contests sponsored by the Sports Car Club of America.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 12--The coup d'etat by South Vietnam's military leaders this month has weakened the position of Gen. Paul D. Harkins, the highest United States military official here.

President Kennedy has filmed a short speech in observance of Bill of Rights Day, Dec. 15, for distribution to theaters throughout the country.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 12--The Council of Ministers of the European Common Market postponed today for a month debate of a radical new proposal designed to establish by next July common grain prices among the member states.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 12 (AP)--Communist China won six of the eight track-andfield events in the 41-nation Indonesia Games of the New Emerging Forces and gained a commanding lead over North Korea today.
The Metropolitan Opera will open next season with a new production of Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor," starring Joan Sutherland.

TRENTON, Nov. 12.--Democratic leaders conceded today that proponents of Gov. Richard J. Hughes's $750 million bond proposal had spent more than $250,000 in their unsuccessful effort to sell the plan to New Jersey voters.
Prices of cocoa futures dropped yesterday by the daily limit permitted on the New York Cocoa Exchange--100 points, or 1 cent a pound.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12--Dr. Francis H. Horn, president of the University of Rhode Island, advocated today a five-year course of arts and sciences for undergraduates. He also urged elimination of the requirement for a major field of study.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12-- The Supreme Court began today its exploration of the constitutional limits on the makeup, of state legislative districts.

LONDON, Nov. 12--A letter written by Edgar Allan Poe soliciting Washington Irving's "good opinion" of his work to establish a literary reputation was purchased today at auction for $5,600 by the Carnegie Book Shop of New York.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP)--Chief Justice Earl Warren has rejected a proposal to inscribe "In God We Trust" above the bench of the Supreme Court, the House of Representatives was told today.
"LIFE, within doors, has few pleasanter prospects than a neatly arranged and well-provisioned breakfast-table."
The Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street, is showing, in its toy section, the McDonald Doll Collection, which contains 38 dolls of the 18th end 19th centuries.
MIAMI, Nov. 12 (UPI)--Maj. Raul Castro, head of Cuba's armed forces, announced tonight that Cuban men between 17 and 45 years of age faced being called into military service.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI)--The Supreme Court declined today to examine an appeal by James R. Hoffa and cleared the way for his trial in Tennessee on jury-tampering charges.

The main force or the city's receivership law lies in its effect on landlords who suddenly comply with the housing laws when faced with city action, Building Commissioner Harold Birns declared yesterday.
THE one-world-of-fashion cause received strong support yesterday when Dominic, a sandy-haired young Frenchman, showed a thoroughly American spring ready-towear collection for Matty Talmack.

Soviet authorities have dealt a serious blow to hopes of expanding--or even of maintaining--the current level of Soviet-American cultural and scholarly exchanges by their conduct toward Prof. Frederick Barghoorn of Yale University, whom they accuse of being a spy.

MOSCOW, Nov. 12 (UPI)-- The Soviet Union announced today it had launched an unmanned artifical earth satellite yesterday and that preliminary data showed it was operating close to its prescribed orbit.

CAROL BURNETT, the lady of broad clowning and indefatigable energy, appeared last night in a program hardly worthy of her talents. It was the awkward Western musical called "Calamity Jane," which wasn't too good a film and did not benefit from further compression for TV.
Six high schools boys began working for the Traffic Department yesterday as part of a program that seeks to keep them from becoming dropouts and to give them a potential career.
RICHMOND, Nov. 12--Gov. Albertis S. Harrison Jr., recommended today a substitute for the poll tax as a qualification for voting in Federal elections.
George Meany, the nation's top labor leader, threw his support yesterday behind the fight of the Seafarers International Union against Canada's maritime union trusteeship law.

A public offering of $5,100,000 of 4.125 per cent equipment trust certificates of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad was made yesterday at prices to yield investors 3.85 to 4.30 per cent, depending on the maturity.

The United States Supreme Court dismissed yesterday an attempt to block the World Trade Center on the lower West Side. The Port of New York Authority announced that it would move, ahead with the project immediately.

A meeting of the three members of the New York State Harness Racing Commission yesterday at the Manhattan offices of that body was adjourned after two hours without any action being taken on the twin double. Nor were any rule changes made.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12-- Billie Sol Estes declined today to tell Congressional investigators anything about the activities that brought about the collapse of his argricultural empire and his conviction on charges of fraud and theft.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12-- Some European countries are asking for a substantial role in the management of a communications satellite undertaking. This is their price for cooperating with the United States in establishing a global space communications system.

The American Commercial Barge Line Company, a large inland waterway carrier, announced yesterday that it would acquire Terminal Transport Company, Inc., of Atlanta, a large common carrier trucking company.

Forest Hills General Hospital, which was indicted along with seven individuals for cheating Blue Cross of $92,000 by padding payrolls, will close this weekend.

Jerry Lewis and the American Broadcasting Company have had negotiations looking toward a curtailment of the comedian's two-hour program on Saturday nights. No decision has been reached.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector)-- Today's most famous metropolitan portals are Checkpoint Charlie, where one can legally cross the Berlin Wall, and the Mandelbaum Gate, through which the properly documented traveler may enter Israeli Jerusalem from Jordanian Jerusalem or vice versa, one way only.
Governor Rockefeller gained some support from Maryland yesterday in his drive for the Republican nomination for President.

If there was a criminal lesson to be learned yesterday in Federal Court, it was this: Never unwittingly try to sell stolen diamonds and dresses back to their owners.
