WASHINGTON, Nov. 14-- Detailed plans for the initial withdrawal of United States troops from South Vietnam depend upon policy meetings scheduled to be held in Honolulu next week, President Kennedy said today.
TURIN, Italy, Nov. 14--Giuseppe Pero, president of the Olivetti Business Machines Company, died in a nursing home here today. He was 70 years old.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14--The Union Pacific Railroad obtained a court order today to block the counting of votes of Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad stockholders on a proposed merger with the Union Pacific.
Musical considerations were uppermost last night at Michael Tree's Town Hall recital. Not that matters of skill were in abeyance, not in the slightest. Mr. Tree is one of our more gifted performers.

Television cameras, photoelectric cells, computers, catwalk cars and policemen constitute the components of a new system that has been devised to smooth the flow of traffic through the Lincoln Tunnel.
SINCE Mark Twain's "Reflections on Religion" have never been published in their entirety before, the editors of the Hudson Review are surprised by the lack of interest in them.

Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower will make his third coast-to-coast television appearance Sunday in a nonpolitical campaign to acquaint viewers with his recently published memoirs, "The White House Years."
The Board of Education served notice yesterday that it did not want its new school buildings to "look like spaghetti factories."

PUTTING fabrics on walls has made more than one woman feel she belongs in a padded cell. Any one of a dozen problems like stretching, shrinking, water spotting, color bleeding, lumps and uneven seaming can arise during installation.
JEAN GENET'S problem servants returned to Off Broadway last night in a revival of "The Maids" at the One Sheridan Square Playhouse.

Eddie Arcaro, whose agent once described him as "the only jockey in the world who subscribes to The Racing Form and The Wall Street Journal," has been elected president of the Livestock and Casualty Insurance Company.
In his vigorous defense of the foreign aid program yesterday, President Kennedy provided some needed perspective.
Meanwhile, the new travel restrictions imposed upon Eastern European diplomats have somewhat compromised the position of the United States as an advocate of free exchanges of people and ideas.

Drinks--rye or scotch--are on the house during the 15 minute intermission at "Tambourines to Glory," the gospel singing play at the Little Theateo. The practice was instituted on Thursday night of last week by Roger Euster, owner of the intimate house.
CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 14-- The constitutionality of a state law that forbids racial bias in the sale or rental of privately financed housing was upheld in the Superior Court here today.
TORONTO, Nov. 14 (Canadian Press)--Christine Hanson of Toronto rode Bonheur to victory in the $500 Cilroy Stake tonight to win the Prix St. Georges for the dressage championship of Canada.
MOSCOW, Nov. 14 (AP)-- Marshal Sergei S. Varentsov whose name was brought up it the Penkovsky-Wynne spy case has been expelled from the Supreme Soviet, an official bulletin announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--The United States balance of international payments showed a dramatic improvement in the third quarter of this year, the Commerce Department reported today. After seasonal adjustment, the payments deficit in the third quarter on all ordinary transactions was only $385 million, the lowest for any quarter since the end of 1957.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP)-- Oscar Melillo, former American League second baseman and manager of the St. Louis Browns in 1938, died of a heart attack at his home today. He was 64 years old.
Josef Krips chose uncomfortably familiar pieces for last night's New York Philharmonic concert at Philharmonic Hall, and possibly this was a key to the sense of tedium that hung over the proceedings.
Dividend declarations came in bunches yesterday and in many various fields.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 14 --The biggest air-sea exercise ever held by the Central Treaty Organization nations started this morning in the Arabian Sea off the coast of Pakistan.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 14 (UPI)--Billy Golembiewski of Detroit took the lead in the Professional Bowlers Association's fourth annual national championship during the afternoon round and then held it tonight as the tournament reached its 24-game point at Garden City Bowl.
The head of the nation's largest railroad operating union indicated yesterday that it would not negotiate again nationally on most issues.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 14 (AP)--A terrorist bomb exploded in an open-air cafe on a main street in Saigon tonight, critically injuring two United States servicemen.
Television is heading for the jungle and by next fall Tarzan will be swinging from antennas.
BERLIN, Nov. 14 (Reuters) --Willi Stoph, East German First Deputy Premier asserted today that access routes from the West to West Berlin "come under the sole jurisdiction" of Communist East Germany.

Columbia's football squad will enter its final home game against Penn tomorrow physically under par. Coach Buff Donelli said yesterday it was the first time this season he had to report "injuries of consequence."
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 14 --The insect-killer DDT has "invaded the water enviornment of the world," according to Dr. Luther L. Terry, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. Stars, when they appear, are employed as follows: One star denotes restaurants of more then routine interest; two stars denote those of superior quality, and three stars pertain to restaurants regarded as among the finest in the area.
HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 14--The Greenwich Village school of moviemaking has become an actuality. It may or may not be avant or nouvelle. But it is certainly unusual.
The Bank Street College of Education, long a fixture in Greenwich Village, announced last night that it would move to Morningside Heights in 1966, the year of its 50th anniversary.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14-- The Soviet cultural mission in the United States was hit today by a backlash of anger over the arrest of Prof. Frederick C. Barghoorn in Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14-- Governor Rockefeller moved today to assure Republicans in California and the rest of the country that he would stay in the Presidential competition through the last of the nation's 16 primaries.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 14-- The leading Argentine news paper La Prensa declared today that the Government must not take justice in its own hands in deciding on the cancellation of American petroleum company contracts.

Maximilian Hurwitz, an author and journalist and editor and translator for the World Jewish Congress from 1943 until 1962, when he became a consultant, died Wednesday of a heart attack in his home, 1515 Grand Concourse in the Bronx His age was 76.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 --The Negro will remain tragically unequipped to take his proper place in the American economy until the nation faces the problem of uncontrolled population growth, a sociologist said today.
Mark Klosty Co., freight and chartering brokers, have leased 2,500 square feet at 1 Whitehall Street, a new 21story building constructed and owned by Samuel Rudin.

The era of the pushbutton telephone dawns next Monday. On that date residents of Carnegie and Greensburg in western Pennsylvania will become the first in the nation to subscribe to the Bell System's new "Touch-Tone" service.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Nov. 14--African foreign mininsters arriving here to try to settle the Algerian-Moroccan border dispute are encountering a new flare-up of the frontier quarrel between Ethiopia and Somalia.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14-- Mexican--Americans made strong representation for better jobs today at a five-state conference sponsored by the President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14-- President Kennedy cited a 1936 Supreme Court decision today to assert the ascendancy of the President over Congress in matters of foreien policy.

Schubert was the composer William Steinberg brought last night to Carnegie Hall, where he led the Pittsburgh symphony for a second consecutive evening. The program was a credit to the International Festival of Visiting Orchestras, of which it was a part.

A former limestone mine now in use as a records-storage and business-survival center has been put into action on still another job-- as an underground processing laboratory for 16-millimeter microfilm.
A large Brooklyn savings bank which had been losing deposits to some of its competitors announced yesterday it would pay 4 per cent on all deposits retroactive to Oct. 1.

ROME, Nov. 14--Ente Nazionale Idrocarburl (E.N.I), the Italian State oil and gas agency, announced tonight a six-year oil agreement with the Soviet Union that foresees a total importation of 25 million tons of crude oil valued at more than $200 million.
Herb Score, once a milliondollar baseball property, is available to any major league club willing to risk a bargainbasement outlay of $25,000.

Goodbody Co., a prominent Wall Street brokerage house, announced plans yesterday to merge on Jan. 1 with J.A. Hogle Co. of Salt Lake City in a move creating a coast-tocoast network of 62 offices in 66 cities.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Nov. 14 --Brazil reluctantly joined the majority at the inter-American ministerial economic conference today as she dropped direct opposition to the creation of a permanent executive organ for the Alliance for Progress.

Robert Anderson, best known as the author of "Tea and Sympathy," is eager to branch out as a librettist. He is considering terms to adapt the 1953 Paramount film "Roman Holiday," in which Audrey Hepburn was seen as a princess and Gregory Peck as an adventurous newspaper man.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14-- The Pentagon announced today plans to bring home three tactical air transport squadrons based in Evreux, France.

Two key price changes were announced yesterday, a rise in unbranded-hosiery prices and a decrease in gasoline prices in the Middle West.

MADRID, Nov. 14 (Reuters) --Saleh Saadi, Deputy Premier of Iraq, said tonight that he and four companions planned to leave tomorrow morning to fly to Baghdad by way of Damascus. The five men arrived here yesterday.

JAMES STEWART is currently thumping drums hereabouts for his latest film, "Take Her She's Mine." With him is an experienced biggame hunter--his wife, Gloria.

Gareth Martinis maintained yesterday that if he stood trial for vehicular homicide he would be forced to defend himself against charges of drunken and reckless driving on which he has already been acquitted.

The socialist Baath party that rules Iraq and Syria and is moving toward a union of the two countries in opposition to President Nasser has been shaken by another attempted coup in Baghdad and a Government reshuffle in Damascus. World sugar futures prices rebounded yesterday after posting maximum losses Wednesday. At the close, the No. 8 contracts were up as much as 25 points, thus erasing half the losses of the preceding day. Volume was fairly high at 87,150 tons.

Arthur Judson, who on Oct. 9 announced simultaneously that he was retiring from Columbia Artists Management and opening an office as a music consultant, yesterday announced that he was re-entering the management field.

The National Association of Real Estate Boards urged yesterday that the Government support only those urban renewal projects that are predominantly residential or for public use.

LANSING, Mich., Nov. 14-- The Michigan Legislature killed Gov. George Romney's fiscal reform program today. The action was viewed as a blow to the prestige of Mr. Romney, frequently cited as a possible Republican Presidential candidate.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14-- President Kennedy conceded today that Congress was unlikely to complete action this session on his programs of tax reduction and civil rights.

Staying in front with the same momentum that the similarly named contingent displayed in the World Series, Dodgertown captured the main race at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4-year-old son of Admiral Drake never let the opposition get ahead of him in the 1 1/8mile event and won by eight lengths.

ATHENS, Nov. 14--Several hundred Greeks imprisoned for sedition and murders said to have been committed during the 1944-50 Communist uprising are to be released on five years probation, the new Greek Government announced today.

Prices of Treasury bonds continued yesterday the weeklong advance that took a few long-term Issues almost half a point up.
Intensive competition and higher operating costs have cut into the profits of Montgomery Ward Co. in the three and nine months ended Oct. 31. Despite record sales, earnings declined ...
TODAY'S cook probably can list on the fingers of one hand the ways she uses molasses.
Gregorio Peralta, growing stronger and sharper in the later rounds, took a split decision from Wayne Thornton last night in the 10-round feature bout at Madison Square Garden.

The Kimberly-Clark Corporation, a major paper and cellulose products producer, has acquired 67 per cent of the stock of Hygenic Products, Inc., Manila. The company makes disposable facial tissues in the Republic of the Philippines.
The city will send out about 150 water inspectors early next week to check on the extent of water conservation in 17,000 hotels, restaurants, luncheonettes and food counters.

Corporation Counsel Leo A. Larkin has upheld the right of the City Council to look into the finances of the World's Fair.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 15--The withdrawal of 1,000 United States servicemen from South Vietnam will start Dec. 3, Maj. Gen. Charles J. Timmes announced today. The men are to depart by the end of the year, leaving about 15,500 American troops in the country.

Although we were in the constant presence of official guides, I feel I was able to take a fairly good look at an important part of the Red Giant.

The Seventh Regiment Armory was captured yesterday by the congregation of a church without a ceiling.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 17 A possibility that President Kennedy might discuss with a high official from Argentina the revocation of oil contracts with American concerns collapsed today when the Argentine canceled a scheduled visit to Florida.

The University of Texas maintained its place at the head of the intercollegiate football procession on a day remarkable for the fact that every power ranked in the first ten was a winner. So was the favored team in each of the four Ivy games on the Saturday preceding the close of the season for most teams.
A new company has decided to seek Federal subsidy aid in an unusual project calling for carriers.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 Rabbi Maurice Nathan Eisen drath does not quail before the fury of a religious or social gale.

LONDON, Nov. 17 Drops in British Government loans, in some cases as much a 3 percent, were the feature of stock market trading here last week.
A rarely used play extremely simple in design yet very difficult to execute produced the pivotal touchdown for the New York Giants yesterday in their 48 14 rout of the San Francisco 49ers.
The United Presbyterian Church urged its agencies yesterday to use their financial influence upon businesses with which they deal to eliminate racial discrimination.

Stanley H. Lowell, chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights, said yesterday that "it does not back away one iota from its strong position that new methods, new means, new creative ideas must be found" to achieve equal opportunities for all Americans.
ROME, Nov.17 Pope Paul VI conveyed his affection today to Eastern regions "where the church, in silence and in tears, awaits the dawn of better days."

ALBANY, Nov. 17 The year is 321 days old today. Since it began, Governor Rockefeller has been out of the state 86 days. And in the 44 days still remaining in 1963, there will be other times when he is beyond the state's borders.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 17 The brief address made here by President Abraham Lincoln 100 years ago Tuesday was hailed by diplomatic representatives of three foreign countries today as an immortal and internationally significant expression of the American ideal of liberty.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 17 Suffolk County's planning director said today that a proposed bridge across Long lsland Sound would require a new superhighway running the length of the island.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Nov. 17 President Kennedy's proposal to put a tax on foreign borrowings in the United States has touched off a wave of financial experimentation in Europe.
Supreme Court Justice Arthur J. Goldberg called last night for an international court to enforce the "essential civil rights" stipulated in the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
Just released from a Moscow prison, Prof. Frederick C. Barghoorn was a laconic but relaxed passenger aboard a Pan American flight from London to New York yesterday.
Labor unions may soon begin to push harder for larger settlements at the bargaining table.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 Senator Clifford P. Case gave his support today to a proposal that the New Jersey delegation go uncommitted to the Republican National Convention.

NASHVILLE, Nov. 17 (AP) Dr. Harrison H. Shoulders Sr., former president of the American Medical Association, was stricken with a heart attack at a park here today and died shortly afterwards. He was 77 years old.

Ever since sprawling Interpublic, Inc., acquired Erwin Wasey, Ruthrauff Ryan, Inc., a month ago, Madison Avenue has been looking eagerly for client reaction. The big question: Would all the companies involved go along with the acquisition despite the apparent product conflicts involved?
Tantalizing correlations between man's diseases and the character of the land on which he lives were discussed here yesterday.

The Federal Maritime Commission has forwarded legislation to Congress that would enable the agency to forgive possible past law violations by pert terminals that failed to submit rate agreements to the commission.
About 6,000 teen-agers and young adults of the Catholic Youth Organization, received communion in the grand ball room of the New York Hilton Hotel yesterday.

At long last, the New York Rangers, skating, checking and shooting like a team intent on acquiring a playoff berth, snapped a seven-game losing streak last night by whipping the Detroit Red Wings, 5 2, in a National Hockey League clash at Madison Square Garden.
Mayor Wagner will undertake shortly a personal appraisal of New York City government at the midway point in his third term.

BUFFALO, Nov. 17 (UPI) Tobin Rote, the San Diego quarterback, used his youthful corps of fleet backs with all the knowledge of his 14 years experience as a pro and dealt a blow to Buffalo's Eastern Division title hopes today as the Chargers ripped the Bills, 23 13, before 38,592, a record American Football League crowd.

Amco of Horvelt, Inc., manufacturer of women's sportswear, has leased a floor containing 7,500 square feet at 10 East 39th Street through Donald E. Bondy, vice president of Williams Co., broker, Amco will retain its quarters at 1407 Broadway and use the 39th Street space for additional offices and showrooms.

THE housewife who can spare a dime for a couple of lemons is investing in a tonic that can give life to her menu, from martini to meringue pie. Lemons are available all the year round, but their sunny appearance on fruit Stands is never so welcome as during the drab months of late fall and winter.

IN VIEW of so sensitive a musical mind as that of Rudolf Firkusny, it may be left-handed praise to say that his piano recital, on Saturday evening at Hunter College, left primarily an impression of technical fluency. There was much more than that, of course. There always is when Mr. Firkusny plays.

THE Louvre and the National Gallery were joined on television at 12:30 P.M. yesterday in the first international art program to be transmitted live via the satellite Relay. The presentation was produced by the National Broadcasting Company, which thoughtfully gave a repeat showing on tape at 6 o'clock to accommodate a larger audience.

DALLAS, Nov. 17 (UPI) Don Meredith completed 25 of 33 passes for 302 yards and two touchdowns today and led the Dallas Cowboys to a 27-20 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles. The Cowboys moved into fifth place in the National Football League's Eastern Conference.

BRUSSELS, Nov, 17 Criticism of the United States for unwarranted and untimely interference in European affairs mounted over the week-end in the wake of United States Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman's speech in Amsterdam Friday.
The Coast Guard has drastically revised and simplified its security risk questionnaires for seamen and dockworkers after receiving criticisms from the American Civil Liberties Union.

Paul Gallico has sold another book to Hollywood. This is "The Hand of Mary Constable," a novel scheduled for publication by Doubleday this spring, and which 20th. Century-Fox has acquired for production. No production date has been set but it is being put into screenplay form now by Richard Murphy. Fred Kohimar will be the producer.
John E. Joyce, a Federal bankruptcy referee for New York and Bronx Counties, died yesterday in Union Hospital in the Bronx. His age was 74 and he lived at 265 Bedford Park Boulevard in that borough.

If those who criticized the art policy of the New York World's Fair yesterday had journeyed to the site of the fair, they would have seen several works of art already on display. They include a controversial cartoon by Rube Goldberg and a painting depicting the accomplishments of Robert Moses, the president of the fair.

After 25 years as "the incomparable Hildegarde," the Wisconsin-born pseudo-continental singer with the long gloves and the lace-edged handkerchief has changed her approach. She has become "comparable."
HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 17 The producer of a movie for MetroGoldwyn-Mayer has defied a studio edict against nudity and has criticized the president of the company.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 17 Two major factors in the Indian political scene are Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's birthdays, the 74th of which was celebrated last week, and the serious failure of the third Five-Year Plan to meet its targets during its first two years.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI) The Agriculture Department said today net farm income in 1963 would drop to about $12.26 billion and possibly would sink in 1964 to about $11.6 billion.
ALGIERS, Nov. 17 Mohammed Boudiaf, one of President Ahmed Ben Bella's chief foes, was released from prison last night. He indicated today that he was still opposed to the regime.
After 10 weeks of grudging give-and-take battle, the New York Giants yesterday gained exclusive possession of first place in the Eastern Conference of the National Football League.

The New York State Theater on Columbus Avenue between 62d and 63d Streets in the nonprofit Lincoln Center area already is booked solid from its formal opening next April 24 until the end of 1964.

Boyd McDonald made a debut as a pianist and composer at Town Hall yesterday afternoon and he wore both hats admirably. He is Canadian, he teaches at the University of Saskatchewan and this recital was the result of winning the Leschetizky Piano Debut Prize.

The Board of Education, which last year spent nearly $1 million to replace broken windows, is moving to counteract vandalism with a series of new measures that range from building windowless schools to installing unbreakable glass.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 17 Andrew Johnson was in the White House and "carpetbaggers" were ranging the South when John E. Greenawalt was born at Silver Spring, Pa., on Oct. 26, 1867.
A committee of American artists decided yesterday to ask President Kennedy to make space or money available for an exhibit of American art at the New York World's Fair.
OTTAWA, Nov. 17 Canadian exports have just experienced a great upset against a backdrop of across-the-board expansion.

BOOK lovers of the world, who frequently feel in dan ger of becoming as extinct as the buffalo, can take heart. A clever educator has come up with an idea to expose youngsters to the joys of owning books and so encourage them to read.
United States and foreign airlines are engaged in a mad scramble to buy supersonic passenger planes in spite of their own doubts about the plane's technical and economic success.
Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson denied yesterday that the recent vote in New York City on offtrack betting constituted a mandate to the Legislature to legalize such wagers.
A speculator could have made $750 grow to $15,000 in one year if he had bought a call on 100 shares of Chrysler.
WELLS, N.Y., Nov, 17 (AP) An Air Guard pilot rescued from the Atlantic three months ago by Russian fishermen was found dead today in the wreckage of a jet fighter that had crashed in the Adirendacks.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov.17 (AP) Communist China took five gold medals today as the swimming and diving events began in the Games of the New Emerging Forces. The Chinese also scored in table tennis, shooting and volleyball.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 17 (UPI)--Charlie Johnson passed for two touchdowns today and led the St. Louis Cardinals to a 20-14 upset victory over the Cleveland Browns.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 17--American oil companies, still producing in Argentina, started talks with the Government today on possible new agreements to replace the contracts cancelled by the Government Friday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 The Administration is hopeful that the civil rights bill will reach the floor of the House by mid-December and pass there before Christmas.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 The President's Council of Economic Advisers has come up with a new challenge to the widespread belief that automation is eliminating jobs at a dangerously high rate.
BUFFALO, Nov. 17 A setting of Lincoln's Gettysburg Address had its world premiere this afternoon at a subscription concert of the Buffalo Philharinonic Orchestra in Kleinhans Music Hall.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (UPI) Bobby Hull's three goals paced the Chicago Back Hawks to a 6-0 victory tonight over the Toronto Maple Leafs and increased their National Hockey League lead to four games.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 The first Santas are out on the shoppingcenter tarmacs and the call to consume is heard in the land. Conscientious consumers have already flexed their revolving credit accounts and run their charger-plates through preliminary heats at the department stores.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 Defense Department spending on scientific research and engineering development is expected to level off in the next fiscal year and perhaps even decline a bit.

DETROIT, Nov. 17 (UPI) Roman Gabriel stung the injury-riddled Detroit Lions' defensive secondary with three long touchdown passes to Carroll Dale today as the Los Angeles Rams scored a surprising 28-21 victory.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 Following are the votes of Senators from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on major rollcalls during the week ended yesterday.

The Public Education Association's opinion paper on the problems of secondary education in New York City calls for far-reaching changes. In this tradition-bound metropolis such a demand invites almost automatic opposition as a reflex reaction. Yet, an open-minded and careful evaluation of the P.E.A, proposals is exactly what the schools need.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 The Soviet Union intends to continue its present rate of economic and technical assistance to Cuba, even though political strains have developed between the two countries.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP)--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that the United States should gradually withdraw five of its six combat divisions in Western Europe.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 17. (UPI)--Al Balding of Toronto posted a six-stroke victory in the $16,000 Mexican open golf tournament today with a nine-under-par 279, which set a tournament record.

NEW DELHI, Nov, 17--Canadan and India have found a formula of reciprocity to cover inspection of the atomic power reactor Canada will build here. Achieved after difficult negotia-? formula gives this country full access to a Canadian reactor now under construction at Douglas Point in Canada.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 17 Steel officials reported surprising strength in their markets last week.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 Nothing could stop the Chicago Bears today as they stormed over the Green Bay Packers in a manner few teams have in recent seasons. The victory gave the Bears sole possession of first place in the National Football League's Western Division.

TRENTON, Nov. 17 A constitutional amendment to extend sessions of the New Jersey Legislature to two years was proposed today by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers, the state university.

NEWARK, Nov. 17 Evelyn Short's 3-year-old imported bloodhound from Long Valley, N.J., Ch. Equerry of Brighton, took the best-in-show award tonight in the 45th event of the Newark Kennel Club. The choice was made by Edward H. Goodwin of Scotch Plains, N.J.
JERUSALEM (Israel Sector) Nov. 17 The Cabinet expressed today "the disgust" of Israeli citizens with ultra-Orthodox Jews in New York who have accused the Israeli Government of religious persecution.

"The Deputy," the controversial play by Rolf Hochhuth, was the subject of a sermon and a following symposium yesterday at the Spencer Memorial Church in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 Interracial marriage is completely compatible with the doctrine and canon law of Roman Catholicism, a national church organization said here today.
ST. LOUIS, Nov.17 Governor Rockefeller said today that Senator Barry Goldwater had held ultraconservative views too long to extricate himself enough to win the Republican Presidential nomination.

Argentina's oil seizures cast dark new clouds over the Senate-House conference that will set the authorization ceiling for foreign aid. Both houses already have mauled the aid bill President Kennedy sent to Congress. His original figure of $4.5 billion is expected to come out of conference trimmed down to $3.6 billion, the lowest figure authorized since the Marshall Plan.

The huge earnings of Nevada's legal gambling industry have created a new force in American life a force with a hidden impact so great that it is of deep concern to top law enforcement officials throughout the nation.

A committee of Negro clergymen, charging Mayor Wagner with "insults" and "pussyfooting," threatened yesterday a series of harassing tactics to dramatize their demand for more jobs for Negroes in the building trades.

GREENBORO, N.C., Nov. 17 L.P. McLendon, special counsel for the Senate investigation of Robert G. Baker, said today he was confident that the Rules Committee would make a full disclosure of any findings concerning Mr. Baker's alleged use of his Senate influence to further outside business interests.

UNION CITY, N.J., Nov, 17 Emerson reached its top form of the season today and walloped Memorial of West New York, 34 7, at Roosevelt Stadium here. It was Memorial's worst defeat in its series with Emerson since 1932.

Things are finally looking up in the battle for the dollar. The third-quarter results show a dramatic improvement over the dismal figures for the first half, when the outflow of dollars reached record proportions. A good part of the reduction of the drain is attributable to the Administration's proposed tax on American purchases of foreign stocks and bonds, which has a retroactive provision. BEIRUT, Lebanon, Monday, Nov. 18 The Iraqi Army revolted and overthrew Iraq's Baathist Government today, the Baghdad radio said in a broadcast monitored here.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 Dr. Burton P. Fowler, a former president of the Progressive Education Association and a civic leader, died Friday. He was 76 years old.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov 17 (AP) Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that continued detention of Prof. Frederick C. Barghoorn by the Soviet Union "Would have had a most serious effect" on Soviet-American relations.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 17 Prof. Frederick C, Barghoorn, home after 16 days as a prisoner in the Soviet Union, said tonight that there were "many inexplicable and mysterious aspects" of his arrest as a spy.
Two school principals, three teachers and a salesman ended yesterday at sundown their second weekend fast aimed at winning integration at a Harlem school still to be selected.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 17 (AP) Ten persons, five of them ministers, were jailed today for trying to integrate four Methodist churches.

OTTAWA, Nov. 17 An amendment to the income-tax lath designed to increase Canadian ownership of subsidiaries of foreign corporations has been passed by the House of Commons and is before the Senate for final approval.

THE South American zonal tournament, recently com pleted in Fortaleza, Brazil, was won by the Argentinian brand master, Hector Rosetto, who scored 12 points out of the maximum 15 in a 16man round robin. Second place went to A. Foguelman of Argentina, who scored 11 points. Tied for third, fourth
Holy Cross captured the Catholic High schools Football League championship yesterday as Kevin Colombo's 18-yard field goal gave the Crusaders an 11-8 upset victory over Chaminade.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17--The head of a powerful arm of American Reform Judiasm called on Jews tonight to reassess Jesus and to revise an "oft-times jaundiced view of Him in whose name Christianity was established."
Transtate Airlines, a new organization, has announced that it would delay its plan to begin nonstop service between Buffalo and New York City on Nov. 25.
HONG KONG, Nov. 17--The National People's Congress, Communist China's Parliament, formally opened today.

ROME, Nov. 17 Non-Catholic observers at the Ecumenical Council are looking forward with particular interest to the opening of debate tomorrow on ecumenism, or the movement toward unity among Christians.

Kennedy family, friends, fans, and followers flocked last night to the New York premiere of the movie "It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World" at the Warner Cinerama Theater, a benefit for two charities established by the Kennedy Foundation.

Leon Fleisher played Mozart and Beethoven piano concertos with the Festival Orchestra at Town Hall Saturday night, and this remarkable artist not only played them beautifully, from musical and pianistic standpoints, but also played with such spontaneity that the works sounded new.
Senator Jacob K. Javits prepared yesterday that Richard M. Nixon "would be a willing candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination if he saw the opportunity for running again."

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 17 (UPI) Bob Pettit tonight became the second player in National Basketball Association history to reach the 18,000-point total as he sparked the St. Louis Hawks to a 117-112 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers.
The long-delayed public hearing on the controversial plan to fluoridate New York City's drinking water will be held today, and political observers believe that this time the measure will go through.

MIAMI, Nov. 17 Going into the second of six days' play to select the United States open and women's teams for the 1964 worldchampionship bridge matches, the 16-pair field for the open team was led by a young California pair, Robert Hamman of van Nuys and Don Krauss of Los Angeles.
Two robbers forced their way into a stockbroker's East Side apartment yesterday morning and held five persons at gunpoint as they scooped up $55,000 worth of jewelry.
DENVER., Nov, 17 The New York Jets scored 14 points in the first half today and made them stand up to defeat the Denver Broncos, 14 9, in an American Football League contest at muddy Bears Stadium.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 17 (AP) Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., broke an 11-year Australian monopoly today when he defeated Mike Sangster of Britain, 6 8, 6-3, 6 4, 6 4, for the New South Wales tennis championship.

The captains of American labor, more than 1,200 of them, swarmed through the Americana Hotel yesterday, talking softly and carrying no sticks at all.
NARROWSBURG, N.Y., Nov. 18--There are ago nizing moments as painful as a nerve end touched with a needle that a hunter must expect sometimes in his pursuit of game.
Charles Chaplin's classic comedy, "City Lights," will open a special series of six revivals of his films at the Plaza Theater on Nov. 26.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 18--An atomic generator that will power an unmanned lighthouse beacon and foghorn for 10 years without attention went into test operation today.

A reassuming picture of the military defenses of the United States and its Western allies against the Soviet Union and the other Communist countries was given here last night by Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara.
World sugar futures paced a downturn in most commodity futures prices yesterday.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Nov. 18--The foreign ministers of the members of the Organization of African Unity named a seven-member commission today to ascertain the facts in the Moroccan-Algerian border dispute and to recommend a solution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18-- Professor Barghoorn is scheduled to confer here tomorrow with high State Department officials. They are awaiting his report before determining United States policy on future cultural relations with the Soviet Union.
Sears, Roebuck Co., the nation's largest retailer of general merchandise, announced yesterday that directors raised the regular quarterly dividend to 40 cents from 35 cents a share.
The lives of thousands of unmarried New Yorkers revolve-- not always happily--around a growing social phenomenon called the public dance.
James Robert Kennedy, former First Deputy Police Commissioner, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital at the age of 70. At his death he was supervisor of the security division at Yonkers Raceway.
ALBANY, Nov. 18--Building contractors in the state were accused today of collusion with unions to preserve a historic pattern of discrimination against Negro employment in the construction industry.
KEVIN COLOMBO took a deep breath, took two strides and kicked the football, somewhat off center, he thought. His right ankle, heavily taped, gave him a momentary twinge.

Miss Jessie Rosenfeld was the shining white-haired example yesterday or the fallacy of the old injunction "never volunteer."
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 18 Twenty-five persons were feared to have died today in a fire that swept a 60-room, fourstory hotel. Twenty-three persons, including, firemen and policemen, were injured.
Wayne Hardin, the Navy coach, said yesterday "without reservation" that his quarterback, Roger Staubach, is the finest football player he has ever seen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--A special House committee began an ambitious cram course today on how the Government spends billions of dollars on research and development. It quickly discovered that it had tackled more than it could handle.
A State Supreme Court jury awarded $158,000 yesterday to a couple and their young son for permanent brain damage that the child suffered during his birth at Doctors Hospital.

The Immigration Department gives more weight to a Broadway's producer's plea for the admittance of an alien actor than to a union's argument against it, an official of the Government agency conceded yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 18-- Lee Benson's City Lights, a 3year-old brown son of Darnley, scored a one-length victory over Galcaro in the Sunrise Village Trot before a crowd of 19,428 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
BONN, Nov. 18--Chancellor Ludwig Erhard said today he hoped to help strengthen and unify the Western alliance by his official visits to France and the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--The Supreme Court asked the Justice Department today for its views on whether a state may ever enforce a private owner's decision to exclude Negroes from his place of business. The Justices voted 5 to 4 to put this broad and hotly debated question to the Administration.

UMTATA, South Africa, Nov. 17--Here in the rolling hills, where time is counted in the mud-hut villages by when a chief was born or when the floods came, South Africa is setting up the first of her projected Bantustans, or all-black enclaves.

Lillian Hellman, the playwright, and Arthur W.A. Cowan yesterday bought for $5,000 copyright interests belonging to the estate of the late Dashiell Hammett, noted detective story writer of 30 years ago.

The head of Joseph E. Seagram Sons, one of the nation's largest distillers, denied yesterday that it gave wholesalers in some cities a price advantage over those serving the New York retail liquor trade.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18-- The Treasury succeeded today in its objective of halting the upward movement of the Treasury bill rate and pushing the rate slightly lower.

The Pittsburgh Symphony, which in the past has been obliged to make up deficits by individual fund drives, has been given a $5 million endowment fund. At the start the fund will bring a deficit-offseting income of nearly $200,000 a year.

Hope is still being held for the preservation of the St. George Hotel, a Brooklyn landmark that had its beginnings four years before the great blizzard of 1888. The fate of the hotel will be decided with the bang of an auctioneer's gavel at a bankruptcy sale on Dec. 12.
Jack Kemp and Bill Miller, a pair of American Football League castoffs who have found a home with the Buffalo Bills, have regained the individual leadership in their specialties.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that minority groups in the city "do not have equal rights," and he promised to accelerate the fight to win them.
DETROIT, Nov. 19 (AP)-- Company and union representatives were hopeful they could settle this week a series of labor disputes that cut deeply into auto production last week.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 18-- Mayor Thomas J. Whelan today announced his choice for his successor as Councilman from the Journal Square Ward and indicated he would take some action toward a general pay increase for city employes.
The Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday sizable gains in total gross revenues and net income for twelve months ended Oct. 31.
Kipling Arms, a 15-story and penthouse apartment building at 143 West 96th Street, adjoining the northeast corner of Amsterdam Avenue, has been sold by Kipling Arms, Inc., to an investor.

All segments of the bond market--Governments, corporates and municipals -- showed almost no change yesterday, and trading was light.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18-- The Administration began a new drive today for legislation providing health care for the aged under Social Security.

The 20th annual Christmas Fair to aid the work of the Women's Association of the Brick Presbyterian Church will be held in Watson Hall of the church, 62 East 92d Street, on Thursday and Friday.

This is the time of year when television screens suddenly become alive with dancing dolls, prancing poodles and similar playthings for the Christmas trade.

Twenty years after the conference at Hot Springs which gave it birth, the U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization points to the need for more aid in the production of food if the present tragic gap between the developed and the underdeveloped nations is not to widen into catastrophe.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Wednesday, Nov. 20 Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the ruler of Cambodia, severed yesterday all economic and military ties with the United States.
A Board of Education study had found that the school system overpaid $174,202.62 for the bus transportation of retarded children in the last two years.
The Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street, is showing, in its toy section, the McDonald Doll Collection, which contains 38 dolls of the 18th and 19th centuries.

Gilles Villemure, a 23-yearold goalie who is regarded as an outstanding prospect, will make his National Hockey League debut for the New York Rangers tonight against the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 19 The surprising young Californians, Robert Hamman of Van Nuys and Don Krauss of Los Angeles, continued to lead the American Contract Bridge League's International Trials after the ninth of 15 sessions today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 Prof. Frederick C. Barghoorn informed high State Department officials today that he had been the victim of an entrapment in Moscow.
The City Council yesterday approved Mayor Wagner's request for $3,563,000 to be used by the Board of Education to improve its programs for racial minorities.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 19 (UPI) The Kansas City Athletics plan to move the leftfield fence six feet closer to the plate in Municipal Stadium. They'll do it for their newly acquired slugger, Rocky Colavito.
The State Attorney General's office has begun an investigation into alleged price-gouging, bill-padding and fraudulent selling techniques in the funeral business.

MOSCOW, Nov. 19 Soviet and Chinese Communist, representatives have been conducting consultations here with a view to holding a conference of their two parties on ideological issues. It now appears that such a conference will take place in Peking.

Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy, angered by picketing at Police Headquarters yesterday, asserted that a civil rights group's charges of police brutality here "are aimed at destroying respect for law and order and are, in effect, calculated mass libel."
Cliff Carter had 19 horses going for him at Aqueduct yesterday, which is not so unusual for a horseplayer, but is pretty good for somebody who doesn't bet.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 19 This thriving community, already notable as a sports center because of its annual Masters golf tournament, became a full-fledged member of the nation's major auto racing network last Sunday with the opening of an ultramodern three-mile road course.
HEROLD (MUDDY) RUEL was an aristocrat among ball players during an era when there were mighty few aris tocrats in their ranks. He dressed with a quiet elegance.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 19 (AP) Hank Bauer, a fighting Marine instilled with the winning spirit of the New York Yankees, was named manager of the Baltimore Orioles today.

Directors of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company will vote on a management proposal to split the company's common stock on a two-for-one basis at a meeting scheduled Dec. 17, Donald C. Luce, president, stated yesterday.
Glenda Unterreiner, the young secretary who was killed by a sniper's bullet as she sat in her furnished room in Queens Sunday night, lived on a quiet, respectable street of tidy brick houses.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 19 (AP)--James Locke's Armalad finished second but was declared the winner of the Public Relations Purse at Pimlico today, after Bonded Suite, who finished first, was disqualified for interference in the stretch. Armalad paid $16.40 $7.20 and $4.20 for $2 across the board.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 19 U Thant, the Secretary General, put before the United Nations today plans for expansion and renovation of its headquarters that would cost nearly $11,250,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 The editor of Science complained today that the President's scientific adviser had acquired excessive secret power that could lead to "corruption either of the intellect or of the purse."

An ambitious plan that would bring Metropolitan Opera performances, Carnegie Hall concerts and perhaps shows from Broadway and London's West End into motion picture theaters by closed-circuit television was put forward yesterday.

GREENVILLE, N.C., Nov, 19 (AP) East Carolina College accepted a bid tonight to play Northeastern University in the Eastern Bowl football game at Allentown, Pa., on Dec. 14.

WHEN Clyde Brion Davis completed his 20th book, "Shadow of a Tiger," in July of 1962 he was 78 years old. A week later he died. Few memorial articles were written. Few of our more solemn critics were even acquainted with his work.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 Squabbling Texas Democrats are making a political stew out of President Kennedy's "nonpolitical" swing through their state this week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--A jurisdictional dispute between two employe organizations at the Agriculture Department has resulted in the first "unfair labor practice" charge ever brought against the United States Government.
Premier Khrushchev has supplied an introduction for an edition of "Program of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union," which International Publishers will issue on Friday.
Indian Summer carried a lilt of spring yesterday.

NARROWSBURG, N.Y., Nov. 19 Sullivan County in the area around Narrowsburg does not lack for several things. It does not lack fob handsome deer and it does not lack for lots of woods threaded through with old roads that make the labyrinth of Minos look like child's play.
CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (UPI)-- Soybeans rallied briskly on late buying to show sharp gains today on the Board of Trade. Wheat closed mixed, while other grain futures were steady to lower.
FORT WINGATE, N.M., Nov. 20--The Army successfully demonstrated today its newest nuclear missile system. It is the Pershing, which will be sent to Europe early next year.

Frank Sacco, described by Federal authorities as a Scarsdale, N.Y. loan shark, was released in $10,000 bail by Federal Judge John Cannella yesterday after his surrender on charges that he plotted the theft of $15,000 in merchandise.

A capacity attendance at the fifth annual gourmet dinner of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York last night in the St. Regis Roof brought the organization's campaign goal of $675,000 nearer realization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20-- Mrs. John F. Kennedy returned to the White House social scene tonight, mingling with 700 guests at the annual judicial reception.

Mrs. Anna M. Kross, the city Commissioner of Correction, was hostess yesterday at a "bologna sandwich-and-25-cents" luncheon.
CHICAGO, Nov. 20--By an overwhelming vote, leaders of American Reform Judaism were urged today to grant women the right to serve as rabbis.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UPI)--At dawn, 20 years ago today, the most costly brief engagement in Marine Corps history began.

Dr. George James, the city Health Commissioner, said yesterday that the Board of Education had approved his agency's proposal for a course on venereal disease education.
The Ford Foundation sold 4 million shares of Ford Motor Company common stock yesterday through a huge nationwide syndicate of 326 underwriters to raise almost $200 million.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 20 (AP) --Federal Judge R. Dorsey Watkins has set Dec. 11 for the sale at auction of two heavily attached ships anchored in Baltimore harbor.
A drop of 863,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

UMTATA, South Africa, Nov. 20--A massive turnout was reported tonight in South Africa's first "one man, one vote" election for black Africans.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 20--A special grand jury will be impaneled here soon to investigate gambling, police corruption and laxity or collusion among community officials in a large area of Westchester County.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 20--Former Judge Stanley Matthews of the First District Court of Appeals of Ohio died here yesterday. He was 84 years old.
The State Attorney General's office was flooded by phone calls yesterday from persons seeking to file complaints about price-gouging and high-pressure selling techniques by undertakers.

Stockholders of the Socony Mobil Oil Company and of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation approved a merger yesterday of the two companies.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 120--Hopes and fears that the Federal Government would provide cheap public power for ailing Appalachia were discounted here today.

The importance of the United Nations to American foreign policy and to world peace was emphasized anew yesterday by President Kennedy in his report to Congress. The Hooker Chemical Corporation is planning to acquire the National Phosphate Corporation in an exchange of stock valued at $9,665,000.

Plans for "halfway houses" here and in three other major cities to help narcotics addicts adjust to normal living, were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20-- Congressional investigators studying alleged disparity between export and import ocean shipping rates were told today that charges that export rates are generally higher were substantially untrue.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 28 (AP) --Leading from start to finish over the 1 -mile turf course, Jerry Basta's Cedar Key today won the $62,900 Dixie Handicap at Pimlico. He returned $58.20 for $2.

A Massachusetts housewife with a strong appreciation for a financially stricken Broadway play has contributed $500 and offered to provide additional funds if necessary to keep it going.

The Julian Bream Consort, in its second and last recital here this year, played plenty of its specialty, Elizabethan music, at Town Hall last night.
Passengers scheduled to take a Thanksgiving Day flight yesterday morning from Idlewild Airport to Puerto Rico had themselves to thank when the jetliner took off.

Mayor Willy Brandt of Berlin will be interviewed Sunday at 1:30 P.M. on the American Broadcasting System's "Issues and Answers." He replaces Sentor Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona whose appearance has been rescheduled for January.
The Green Shoe Manufacturing Company and the R.J. Potvin Shoe Company, both of Massachusetts, have agreed in principle to merge in the near future.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28--Cape Canaveral, site of the United States space facility on the Florida east coast, will henceforth be known as Cape Kennedy. President Johnson made the surprise announcement tonight near the end of his Thanksgiving Day message, broadcast from the White House.

Canada's two transcontinental railroads are competing for passengers. Not only are they seeking to lure them from each other with competitive low-fare plans, but they are trying to get them back on the track from the air and off the highway.

Army swept all major honors yesterday in the 53d annual City Hall to Coney Island handicap walking race of the Walkers Club of America.

Debutantes and postdebutantes, many of whom are descendants of old New York families, attended the first Junior Assembly of the season in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza last night. The second assembly will take place at the hotel on Dec. 23.
Industrial shares continued to move ahead yesterday on the London stock market. But, although the volume of trading remained strong, the gains were not as widespread as they had been on Thursday.

VIRTUALLY every woman, every Christmas, gets at least one gift that is so wildly original (and so useless) that it fills her with dismay. The striving for "something she wouldn't buy for herself" often leads the gift shopper down the treacherous paths of gimmickry and gadgetry.
The Chicago Black Hawks, with six consecutive victories and three of the National Hockey League's four top scorers, meet the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden today at 2 P.M.
The value of public bond offerings in November was nearly double the level of a year earlier but fell sharply from the preceding month, a New York Times survey showed yesterday.

Arthur Schoen, a lawyer with an office at 789 Madison Avenue, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home at 591 Park Avenue. He was 47 years old.
Net income of Marshall Field Co. in the quarter ended Oct. 31 rose to $2,488,861, or 62 cents a share, from $2,168,039 or 54 cents a share in the similar three months a year ago.

Yale and Harvard, twin progenitors of the American game of football, play for the 80th time today and Princeton meets Dartmouth as the intercollegiate season comes to a close for all but a handful of teams, including Army and Navy.

Some of the special obstacles that block jobs for the hard-core unemployed are reflected in a special Labor Department study disclosing that the Federal retraining program is shutting out many of those most in need of skills to qualify for work.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 1-- Augie Pabst of Milwaukee won the 99-mile Nassau Tourist Trophy race today in a Lola Chevrolet. The rakish car with a rear-mounted engine was one of four entries representing the team entered by John Mecom Jr. of Houston.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 1 (AP)--Foreign Minister Auguste Mabika-Kalanda was dismissed from office and arrested today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 1 (Reuters)--President Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej of Rumania returned to Bucharest today after a nine-day official visit to Yugoslavia that seemed to underline his growing independence of Moscow in economic policy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1-- The House majority leader, Representative Carl Albert of Oklahoma, said today that he saw no possibility of getting the civil rights bill to the floor of the House in the present session.
Tenants in 34 Harlem tenements began a rent strike yesterday, joining families in 16 other buildings who already have refused to pay rent. The action brought to 585 the number of families affected.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 1 --The president of the Investment Bankers Association of America issued today a strong plea for senior managers of the securities industry to participate more actively in the adoption of new regulations.

WARSAW, Tuesday, Dec. 3 --Delegates to the World Peace Council decisively defeated early today an attempt by Communist China to gain the support of the world's Communists for Peking's militant anti-Western policy.
Negotiations between the school system and a custodial helpers local broke down yesterday and a city mediator said that it might go on strike.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2-- President Johnson today presented the Enrico Fermi award, the highest honor of the Atomic Energy Commission, to Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, the atomic physicist once declared a security risk by the commission.

PARIS, Dec. 2--A proposal that a mixed-manned force of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization take over operational control of 150 Minuteman missiles in the United States was presented today to the Assembly of the Western European Union.
The mere announcement that an upcoming board meeting is the one at which dividend action usually takes place is enough these days to guarantee a strong runup even among the blue chips.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2--The House rushed through a bill today to provide temporary secretarial help, free mailing privileges and Secret Service protection for Mrs. John F. Kennedy.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 2-- The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission voiced determination today that changes in the securities industry be hammered out promptly. He left the door open, however, for compromise. Solutions "perhaps less than perfect" may have to be accepted, he said.
CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (UPI)-- Wheat and oats futures were steady to up, but other cereals weakened on the Chicago Board of Trade.

Mike Tilley, a 6-foot 2-inch sophomore, came off the bench and scored the deciding goals has Hofstra opened its basketball season last night with an 80-74 victory over Long Island University in overtime at the losers' Brooklyn gymnasium.
RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 2--A residential school that will experiment with new ways of helping students to develop their full potential is to begin operation in North Carolina next year.
IT would be comforting to speak kindly of "Have I Got a Girl for You!" if only because it employs 14 actors. The sad fact is that there is hardly any other reason.
Merger agreements have been reached by the Colonial Corporation of America and the Crown Textile Manufacturing Company, Inc., through an exchange of stock.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI)--Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, Army Chief of Staff, testified today that the Soviet Union had instructed approximately 100 million people "at least cursorily" in civil defense.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 2--More lonely steps along the trail of Lee H. Oswald in the last autumn of his life came to light today.
The private garbage collection industry in New York, a $55million-a-year enterprise, began thinking big only a decade ago.

SAN DIEGO., Dec. 2--Baseball's Triple-A minor leagues, the International League and the Pacific Coast League, finally settled their realignment differences today when the Coast League expanded to 12 clubs, the first league of this size in minor-league history, and the International dropped to eight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2-- Four of President Kennedy's closest advisers have agreed to remain at their White House posts so long as President Johnson wants their services.
TRENTON, Dec. 2--The Appellate Division of Superior Court struck a blow today at the practice of letting a defendant "cop a plea."
The auto industry raised production 8.6 per cent from the 1962 level last month, for the highest November total since 1955.

CALGARY, Alberta, Dec. 2 (AP)--Trade Minister Mitchell Sharp said today he expects another wheat sales contract under the three-year agreement with Communist China will be concluded in the near future.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 2 --Charles Morgan Jr., Birmingham attorney, told an audience at President Kennedy's former residence house at Harvard University tonight that the "good but silent people" were responsible for his death.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) --The Supreme Court called today for further information before it ruled on appeals by 10 Freedom Riders convicted in Tallahassee, Fla., of unlawful assembly.
Gareth Martinis is expected to take the stand today at his trial in Bronx Criminal Court on charges of assaulting a press photographer.
MONTREAL, Tuesday, Dec. 3--Two freighters collided and caught fire in the St. Lawrence River early today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2-- The Treasury bill rate rose once again above the Federal Reserve discount rate today, partly because this week's bill issue was $100 million larger than last week's.
World sugar futures prices declined yesterday in active trading. Most other commodities traded here tended to advance in moderate activity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2--A massive sale of $150 million of gold to France in July accounted for the bulk of the United States gold loss of $180.5 million in the third quarter of this year, the Treasury disclosed today.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 2 (UPI)--Chuck McKinley, testing his ailing back in competition today, teamed with Dennis Ralston to win a doubles match in the Victorian tennis championship.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2--They nation's railroads and the five operating rail unions will resume negotiations here Wednesday to try to settle the remaining issues in their four-yearold work rules dispute.
LONDON, Dec. 2--A theater festival unlike any attempted before in Britain, or possibly anywhere else, has been planned for the 400th anniversary of William Shakespeare's birth next year.

It's time for self-employed doctors, lawyers, other professionals and tradesmen to think about a new tax-favored pension plan for unincorporated businessmen. Within the 29 days remaining this year, self-employed persons who report their income on a calendar-year basis can set aside up to $1,250 for retirement on a tax-deferred basis under the new law.
SAN DIEGO, Dec. 2-- Walter Alston, baseball's quiet man, received congratulations today after signing his 11th one-year contract to manage the Los Angeles Dodgers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2--Ambassador Roberto T. Alemann of Argentina met today with Under Secretary of State W. Averell Harriman. There were growing signs that Argentina's dispute with United States oil companies would be settled amicably.

Volstead Act prohibited Dunk Dunk from crashing the winner's circle, at Aqueduct yesterday. The latter, established as the odds-on favorite in the onemile feature, flashed his expected closing rush, but it was not enough to catch Mrs. Edith Marienhoff's front-running son of Double Brandy.
The Queen Elizabeth docked at 10:25 A.M. yesterday and by noon the 1,119 passengers and their 6,231 pieces of luggage were away from Pier 90, North River.
A display of the latest advances in the processing of chemicals and intermediate materials used in making all sorts of products jammed four floors of the Coliseum yesterday.
Stock prices rose slightly on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. It was the fourth consecutive trading session in which prices have advanced.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 2--The Mansholt Plan for establishing uniform grain prices in the European Common Market by July 1 apparently is dead.
FORT WORTH, Dec. 2--Authorities said today that threats to desecrate the grave of Lee H. Oswald had presented a serious police problem.
The Government body that holds the purse strings for United States subsidized shipping has sharply taken to task the shipping management and labor unions involved in the lay-up of the liner America.

HARTFORD, Dec. 2--A Public Health Service study has found that the Connecticut River is so polluted as it moves down from Massachusetts that it "endangers the health and welfare of persons in Connecticut."
The London stock market continued its advance in active trading. At the close, a substantial number of securities had made good gains.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2--The public pledge by President Johnson on Nov. 27 that he will do all in his power to impose the standard of "thrift and frugality" on Government spending, and his subsequent practical moves to that end, are absolutely consistent with his record since he came to Congress in 1937.

An appeal to 100 national advertisers to let the television industry reschedule spot announcements that were canceled during video's special coverage of President Kennedy's assassination was made last night by the Television Bureau of Advertising.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2-- Two Supreme Court justices charged today that the Interstate Commerce Commission was writing Sanskrit-like opinions and favoring railroads over barge lines.
A labor dispute halted work on the superstructure of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge yesterday when 300 steelworkers refused to raise a 400-ton roadway section into place without safety nets.

OTTAWA, Dec. 2 (Canadian Press)--Orders have been given at all grain-export ports to stop the use of glass bottles near vessel holds, Transport Minister George J. McIlraith told the House of Commons today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 2--The United States called on the Soviet Union today for a first small step toward joint exploration of the moon.

LAST year they had a New Haven Night at Lincoln Center. Last night it was the turn of Brooklyn, and the Brooklyn Philharmonic under the direction of Siegfried Landau gave a Philharmonic Hall concert. WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI) --A private organization composed of union and management officials who run multibilliondollar pension and welfare funds decided to dissolve today rather than risk possible control by James R. Hoffa.
As the temperature and then the rains came down yesterday, the spirits of three of the city's newest animal celebrities went up.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 2 (UPI) --T. Eugene Thompson denied before a district court jury today that he had hired an assassin to kill his wife.

LONDON, Dec. 2--Lord Mancroft, a 49-year-old British business leader who comes from a prominent Jewish family, has resigned from the London board of one of the nation's biggest insurance groups because of Arab pressure.

LONDON, Dec. 2--The Western premiere of Dmitri Shostakovich's opera "Katerina Ismailova," a revised version of the work originally entitled "Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk," was acclaimed at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, tonight. The composer was present.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2--Joe Don Looney, a 220-pound running back who has attended four colleges, the current one being Oklahoma, was the first selection of the New York Giants today at the National Football League's annual draft of college football players.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2--The conviction of a Norwalk, Conn., man on a charge of having painted a swastika on a synagogue was set aside today by the Supreme Court.
S.S. ESPARTA Kingston, Jamaica. BY the standards of New York headquarters for this ship, 16 hours seemed sufficient to discharge the cargo for the island of Jamaica.

SANTA CLAUS arrived a trifle early for some of the not-so-good boys in the National Football League. However, he didn't bring his full pack when he dropped by the last several days. All he brought were some ties. They sure were dillies, most being of such hideous hues that they were embarrassing.

LUXEMBOURG, Dec. 2-- The six European Common Market countries agreed in principle today to raise tariffs on steel. The final decision was delayed for consultation with the United States and other major steel producing countries.
Steel production passed the 100-million-ton mark last week for the first time in six years.

"Shakespeare on the Desert" claims distinction as the first of many international celebrations to commemorate next year the 400th anniversary of Shakespeare's birth. The assertion was made yesterday by Paul H. Emerson, founder and producing director of the Arizona festival.
Two major electronic computer manufacturers and a major electronics company unveiled equipment yesterday that speeds up and expands the use of computers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2-- President Johnson reinforced today his commitment to President Kennedy's civil rights program.
The annual meeting of E.J. Korvette, Inc. yesterday had almost everything to entertain the stockholders attending.

LONDON, Dec. 2--The Minister of Aviation is acting like "a modern vengeance counting the heads of the guillotined" at the British Overseas Airways Corporation, the Opposition Labor party charged tonight.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 2-- Premier Ismet Inonu's coalition Government collapsed today and the 79-year-old political leader submitted his resignation to President Cemal Gursel.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 2 --Dr. Raul Leoni has won the Venezuelan presidential election. With 3,051,545 votes in, virtually all of those cast, the Democratic Action candidate had received 985,230 votes, or 32 percent of the total.
An upsurge in the sale of religious and inspirational Christmas cards has been noted here since the assassination of Presi ent Kennedy.

HELSINKI, Finland. FINLAND is rapidly proving itself the dark horse of modern Scandinavian home furnishing design. Immediately before World War II Sweden commanded the top position, after the war Denmark assumed the lead, and now this country is edging them both out of the design race into the homes of the world.
The Government rested its antitrust case against the Westinghouse Electric Corporation yesterday.

Democracy is a novel experience in Venezuela, where President Romulo Betancourt became the first popularly elected chief executive only five years ago. Yet in defiance of Communist terrorists inspired by Cuba's Castro, Venezuelan voters turned out in record numbers to assure the succession of a new candidate. Dr. Raul Leoni, the choice of President Betancourt, seems most likely to emerge the winner, but the real victory belongs to the Venezuelan people.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2-- There were strong indications tonight that the United States would support a recent request by Cambodia for an international conference to guarantee her independence and neutrality.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI)--Representative William Ayres offered legislation today providing two methods for filling the Vice Presidency when the elected holder of that post becomes President.

George Hyde, designer of the M3 submachine gun, which became known to American and Allied soldiers as the "grease gun" during the latter stages of World War II, died yesterday at Adelphi Hospital, Brooklyn. His age was 75.

The Korea Tourist Association has leased space for an information office in the KLM Building, 609 Fifth Avenue at 49th Street. It is operated by the Korean Government and promotes American tourism to Korea. The lease was negotiated by John Begley of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agents for the building.

THE subjects of Geoffrey Hellman's fine New Yorker profiles seem to cooperate con brio in their mantlings and dis mantlings. They run the gamut of their lives splendidly--from, if Miss Dororthy Parker will permit me to say so, I to Me.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 2--The Provisional Government has decided to slow down the strategic hamlet program, which was the cornerstone of the campaign against Communist guerrillas by the regime of Ngo Dinh Diem.

The parents of a child who has a tooth knocked out should not despair. Instead, they should take both the child and the tooth to their dentist as quickly as possible so that the tooth can be replaced.
Firemen and policemen led 90 persons to safety down aerial ladders, fire escapes and stairwells yesterday during a twoalarm fire on the lower East Side. Eight persons were injured, two critically.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2-- Manufacturers sales, new orders and inventories all continued to rise in October, with the strength centered in the durable goods industries.

IF someone were to suggest to our city government that the way to solve the city's pigeon problem was to have a half-dozen expert shotgunners cut down the pigeons in Times Square the reaction would be great.

B. JAY BECKER of New York and Mrs. Dorothy Hayden of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., won the Blue Ribbon Pairs contest, last and most highly rated event of the American Contract Bridge League's fall national tournament which ended in the early hours yesterday morning at Miami Beach.
BONN, Dec. 2--George C. McGhee, United States Ambassador to West Germany, unveiled tonight a row of bronze letters renaming Bonn's Rhine Bridge "Kennedy-Bruke."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) --Representative Richard Bolling said today he would force the House to hold an unusual Saturday session this week in an effort to speed the Administration's civil rights bill to a vote.

Mrs. Josephine Forrestal, widow of James Forrestal, the first Secretary of Defense, is returning to the Broadway producing field after an absence of more than 30 years. Using the corporate name of Forrestal Productions, she will introduce an Irish revue called "Double Dublin" on Dec. 26 at the Little Theater.
SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 2-- Sandro Mazzinghi of Italy retained his world junior middleweight title tonight by knocking out Ralph Dupas of New Orleans in the 13th round.
Sporadic violence marked the first day of a strike by truck drivers who haul garbage from hotels, restaurants and some apartment houses in the city and in Westchester County.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Dec. 2-- Mrs. Marguerite Oswald, by her own account, is a hard-working, patriotic, religious woman whose son inexplicably became an avowed Marxist and an accused assassin.

The court-martial sentence of a young Coast Guardsman convicted of causing the sinking of his own ship was ordered "duly executed" yesterday after a review by the Commander of the Third Coast Guard District.

More than 5,000 New Yorkers assembled yesterday in City Hall Plaza to pay tribute to President Kennedy. It was a blend of eloquence, of prayer, of music by Bach, of song by Marian Anderson--all on a spot where, nearly 100 years ago, the body of Lincoln lay in state.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy said yesterday he was hopeful that a new high school recruitment program would help solve his department's manpower problems.
PURCHASE, N.Y., Dec. 2-- Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart here announced today the establishment of the John Fitzgerald Kennedy Scholarship Fund.
CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (AP)-- Loyola opened defense of its National Collegiate basketballs championship tonight with a 92-54 victory over North Dakota.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2-- Two Government bodies opened four months of products-byproducts hearings today to prepare the ground for next year's series of global tariff negotiations, which is being called the "Kennedy Round."
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 2-- The Brookhaven Town Democratic chairman was indicted today on misdemeanor charges of conspiracy and a felony charge of falsification of accounts by a public officer.

SAN DIEGO, Dec. 2--The major league trading mart, logjammed ever since the baseball clans started gathering here, finally shook loose today when the Cleveland Indians traded Barry Latman, a right-handed pitcher, to the Los Angeles Angels, for Leon Wagner, a long-ball-hitting outfielder. The Angels also are to receive a player to be named later.

Allan Haymes, realty investor and developer, has contracted to buy the blockfront on the east side of 11th Avenue, between 44th and 45th Streets, from the Dana Realty Corporation. Arthur Kahn of Pearce, Mayer Greer was the broker in the sale of the block, which was reported to have brought more than $2 million.

The price of zinc went up a half a cent a pound, to 13 cents, yesterday, presumably on the basis of strong industrial demand, firmer foreign prices and dwindling industry supplies. The price is quoted at East St. Louis.

The United States Plywood Corporation showed a 17 per cent increase in earnings for the quarter ended Oct. 31. This brought the net for the fiscal half-year 12 per cent ahead of the corresponding period a year earlier.

Broadway reaction to the intention of the office of the State Attorney General to disclose details next week at public hearings on black-market activities in theater tickets was mixed yesterday. It ranged from hopes that something constructive would emerge to expressions of cautious indifference.
The spotlight in the bond market was on short-term Treasury bills yesterday.

Now that Barry Kramer, New York University's sparkling performer, almost has completely recovered from a severe ankle sprain Coach Lou Rossini is hopeful that all the players would be healthy when the Violets open their basketball season against Cornell at Ithaca tomorrow.

ONE of the busiest kitchens in Westport, Conn., is op posite the town's railroad station. It is the point of origin for four creditable condiments and relishes that are available in New York and bear the trade name Jan. The kitchen is the enterprise of Mrs. Jan Evans, and the products are a mustard sauce, a chutney, ginger pears in syrup and a red pepper marmalade.

ALMOST, all girls, between the ages of 13 and 17, are passionately interested in clothes. Mothers who find this age group difficult to shop for can appreciate a department like the Charmed Circle at Macy's, on the fourth floor, devoted entirely to the young junior.

Here, Fido. "Fifty Years in the Doghouse," by Lloyd Alexander, will be published on Jan. 15 by Putnam. The central character of this book turns out to be not a dog, but a dog's friend, William Michael Ryan, Special Agent No. 1 of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. It seems that the society's employes refer to the organization as the "doghouse."
