The lyric warmth of Flaviano Laba's voice was a decided asset to the title role of "Don Carlo," which the tenor sang at the Metropolitan Opera for the first time, in last night's performance of the Verdi opera. He poured out his tones generously and effectively and he carried himself with dignity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2--"The Conjugal Bed" is an Italian movie that has had a moderate success in this country, although it is difficult to see why. It is not hilariously funny, as the ads claim, and the salacious content which is supposed to distinguish all films of Mediterranean vintage is well below what a seasoned moviegoer expects of a low-budget California Bible epic.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2 (AP)--Sabu Dastagir, the movies' Elephant Boy, died of a heart attack today in his home at Chatsworth. He was 39 years old.

PARIS. HUNDREDS of French ready to-wear houses have shown their collections in the last few weeks. A few have still to show. Their spring and summer clothes were modeled in restaurants for breakfast and cocktails. They invaded the salons of exclusive and not-so-exclusive hotels. They occupied a vast pavilion at the Porte de Versailles. Some manufacturers were even so sensible as to present their collections on time in their own showrooms.
The Wagner administration is expected to decide today whether to ask for the first time for state aid to help run the city transit system.

Holders of millions of dollars in warehouse receipts for vegetable oil, lard, tallow and fish oil issued by the Harbor Tank Storage Corporation, Bayonne, N.J., formed a creditors committee yesterday to try to ascertain how much their paper is worth.
SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 3--Mr. and Mrs. Wolsey of Wooloomooloo, Australia, will be able to call Aunt Mildred and Uncle Reggie in Surrey, England, to wish them a merry Christmas this year.

Federal Judge Archie O. Dawson knocked out introductory paragraphs in an indictment against Roy M. Cohn yesterday that alleged Mr. Cohn had engaged in a scheme to prevent the indictment of four men in a stock-fraud case.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--The United States needs more Government spending and longrange planning to save its economy from relative stagnation and the world from a powerless America, a noted Swedish ecomist said today.

The Ecumenical Council of the Roman Catholic Church has ended its second business session with few concrete accomplishments to set down in the history books. WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--A few minutes after President Kennedy was assassinated the defense forces of the United States all over the world were informed and instructed to be on the alert.
THE first "Swan Lake" of the New York City Ballet's winter season was danced last night at the City Center with Melissa Hayden and Erik Bruhn in the leading roles.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- President Johnson announced today the terms of an agreement that he had made with Speaker of the House John W. McCormack on the possibility of Mr. McCormack's temporary succession to the Presidency.

LONDON, Dec. 5--The Conservative Government of Sir Alec Douglas-Home suffered sharp reverses in two by-elections today. The results showed the trend to Labor continuing as strongly as ever after seven weeks of Sir Alec's incumbency as Prime Minister.
ULLADULLA, Australia, Dec. 5--The fishermen have declared a shaky truce in their war on the rocky coast of New South Wales.
ROME, Dec. 5--The plans for Pope Paul VI to visit the Holy Land in January were surrounded by confusion today.
DALLAS, Dec. 5--Gov. John B. Connally Jr., weak but ruddyfaced and smiling, left Parkland Hospital today for his home in Austin, where he will continue his recuperation from gunshot wounds.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 5 --A split between James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and his principal assistants was reported today by informed sources.

Jack Paar announced yesterday that he had made an "irrevocable decision" not to continue on the National Broadcasting Company television network after the end of this season. He suggested that N.B.C. release him from his contract, which is scheduled to run through the 1964-65 season.

ALBANY, Dec. 5--The Republican leaders of the Legislature announced today that Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, brother of former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, had been retained to study the question of state aid to private colleges.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Dec. 5 --Mrs. Marguerite Oswald said today she would attempt to prove that her son, Lee H. Oswald, had not assassinated President Kennedy.

HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 5--Joseph E. Levine, whose productions include some of the most successful foreign pictures, asserted today that making money with an artistic film in the United States involves an enormous risk.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--Details of a friendly visit of two old foes--Harry S. Truman and Dwight D. Eisenhower-- came to light today.

PARIS, Dec. 5--The longawaited Givenchy boutique opened today at 3 avenue George V. It is sure to set the pace for every boutique in Paris because, although not quite complete, it is already the most elegant in tone.
HONG KONG, Dec. 5--Some observers here see signs of growing impatience on the part of Mao Tse-tung, 70 years old this month, in recent Chinese Communist attacks on the Soviet Union.
AMERICUS, Ga., Dec. 5--One of the four civil rights workers held without bond on insurrection charges earlier this year was convicted tonight of assault with intent to murder.
The City Center of Music and Drama, which is in business as a purveyor of low-priced, highquality theater, opera and ballet to New Yorkers, is celebrating its 20th birthday.
AMONG the many handsomely illustrated books published this season these two sumptuous glorifications of the wonder and mystery of archaeology seem to me to be the most alluring.

LAST week, around a clearance table in Macy's men's department, a crowd of males --some in leather jackets and work clothes--jostled each other to reach the merchandise. A curious woman wondered what the bargains were.

Guests attending social functions at the Top of the Fair Restaurant at the World's Fair have used buses, taxis, private cars and private limousines. Come springtime, other modes of transportation to the Fair will include hydrofoil, excursion boat and subway.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 (AP)--The Philadelphia Eagles tonight were sold for $5,505,500 to a Washington contractor, Jerry Wolman. The sale is contingent on approval of the National Football League and other club owners.
LONDON, Dec. 5--Each year Dame Margot Fonteyn arranges and sponsors a gland gala ballet matinee at the Theater Royal in Drury Lane for the Royal Academy of Dancing, of which she is president.
PARIS, Dec. 5 (AP)--Mrs. Ngo Dinh Nhu said today that Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge was "a bewildered nanny" in the hands of "South Vietnamese assassins."

DETROIT, Dec. 5--The Ford Motor Company said today more than 7,700 workers at plants in Ohio, New York, Illinois and Michigan were being laid off as an outgrowth of strikes over production standards at three assembly plants.
Cedric Errol Fauntleroy, an aviator in World War I with the French and the Americans and with the Poles in the PolishRussian War of 1919-21, died Nov. 27 in Tucson, Ariz.

WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 5-- Don Busse, winning with his only drive, kept pace with Bob Farrington, who won once in six drives at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Thus, as the harness racing season headed for its final 18 races. Busse led Farrington, 201--196, in the battle for the national drivers' championship.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 5 --Army's football team has not been at full strength this season since the opening minutes of the first game. The cadets won't be at full strength in Philadelphia Saturday against Navy. But their spiritual and mental state should be at a peak against "the best team the Naval Academy has ever had."

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 6-- Arthur H. McClure, chief editorial writer of The New York Journal-American, died of a heart attack today at a hotel in Dorado Beach. He was 59 years old, and he lived at 37-60 88th Street in Jackson Heights, Queens, New York.

A spirited defense of the nation's space program, and especially of the proposed lunar probe, which had been criticized earlier in the day, was made yesterday before the National Association of Manufacturers.

The Federal Communications Commission will open two days of hearings in Washington on Monday to find out whether it has the authority to limit the length and frequency of radio and television commercials.
A relatively bright note on the typically dull Friday in the bond market was sounded yesterday by dealers in municipal securities.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6-- Congessional Republicans deplored today what they called attempts to blame "hatred" in this country for the assassination of President Kennedy.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 6-- Whitney M. Young Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, called today for a "massive effort" to develop the American Negro's work potential and job opportunities.
A LANDSCAPE seen through the eyes of a miniaturist offers more in the way of delicacy and precision than it does breadth or grandeur.
The New York Central Railroad asked the State Public Service Commission yesterday for authority to establish experimental zone fares in parts of the metropolitan area.

THE preparation of yeast breads probably provides more satisfaction and pleasure than any other cooking process. Kneading a yeast dough can be a way of relaxing and also using excess energy, and the shaping process gives opportunity for creative achievement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--A split within the top command of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters raised the possibility today that an effort would be initiated by officials of the union to oust James R. Hoffa as president.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 6 (UPI) --Robert Taft Jr. announced today his candidacy for the United States Senate.
BY a scant two years and two days, the Boston Symphony Concert last night at Philharmonic Hall missed being an all-20th century concert.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 6 --Indonesia's economic and propaganda war against Malaysia has entered a phase of comparative quiet and there were signs here today that it would remain that way for a while.

Controller Arthur Levitt, a Democrat who has been crusading for a stricter code of ethics for public officials, has been named to the Republican-sponsored committee that will revise the ethics law for state legislators.

The Tokyo stock market snapped out of its prolonged depression yesterday. Prices rose sharply following speculative buying in large lots, and buying support developed in leading Tokyo securities houses.
The venerable Norwegian America liner Stavangerfjord has been booked for one more trip--to the scrap yard.
The antique telephone, fast becoming a fixture in fashionable homes, was threatened with disconnection yesterday by the New York Telephone Company.
American Jewish and Israeli leaders emphasized yesterday that American-Jewish communities had the prime responsibility for easing the plight of 751,500 needy Jews throughout the world.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Dec. 6 (AP)--The Russian-born widow of Lee H. Oswald was quoted today as saying she "wants to be an American and continue to live here."

AMONG the week's more interesting openings were a large Franz Kline memorial exhibition at Sidney Janis, a show by a Mexican artist called Toledo at Saidenberg's, and grotesques by a Spaniard, Manuel Ayaso, at the Cober Gallery.

Five men--including a New York City policeman and two employes of private detective agencies--were arrested yesterday on charges of stealing 20 refrigerators valued at $2,000 and other equipment from a Bronx housing project.
There is a belief about La Guardia Airport that the earth hasn't stood still there since Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia broke ground for the start of construction in 1937.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6-- Roman Catholics in Britain will be permitted next year to use a version of the Bible used by many Protestants. This was announced tonight at a meeting of the National Council of Churches.
LONDON--Voters in democracies more often endorse the image of a party than its policies and such party images tend to change with time.
The New York Jets won the first skirmish with the New York Giants for a top college football player when they signed Matt Snell, the Ohio State fullback, yesterday.

THE spiritual leader of the world's 350 million members of the Eastern Orthodox Church, who called on Pope Paul VI yesterday to meet other Christian leaders in Jerusalem, is one of the most imposing figures in Christendom.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 6--Hoping against hope that a bowl bid still might materialize, Pittsburgh's strongest football team in a generation tonight awaited tomorrow's 63d meting with Penn State.

The Nigerian delegate to the United Nations, Chief S.O. Adeba, said last night he resented the notion that the new African nations were either "fellow travelers" of the Soviet Union or "American stooges".

AT about this time in the holiday preparations, most homemakers have come to the unshakable conclusion that they must have some particular cooking or serving piece for the proper entertainment of their Yuletide guests.
Private cartmen rolled their trucks again yesterday and began to pick up the trash and garbage that had accumulated during the four-day strike of drivers and helpers.

MOSCOW, Dec. 6--An exhibition of American graphic art, including many abstract prints, was opened here today in a ceremony attended by the United States Ambassador, Foy D. Kohler, and the Soviet Deputy Minister of Culture, Alekputy Minister of Culture, Aleksandr Kuznetsov.
One month after the overthrow of the Ngo Dinh Diem regime, political and psychological factors are still the dominant ones in the issue of victory or defeat in South Vietnam.
IT may be possible for kindergarten teachers to predict whether a child will make full use of his intellectual capacity in school, according to a Philadelphia child psychiatrist.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6-- The Senate Rules Committee resumed its questioning of witnesses today in preparation for public hearings on the business activities of Robert G. Baker.

The search for 161 million pounds of soybean oil, on which a leading commodity exporter loaned the now-bankrupt Allied Crude Vegetable Oil and Refining Company more than $15 million, ended yesterday. All but 7 million pounds is "missing."

A complaint was issued yesterday accusing the New York Mirror division of the Hearst Corporation of an unfair labor practice in shutting down the newspaper without consulting unions representing its employes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6-- John F. Kennedy and Pope John XXIII received posthumous Presidential Medals of Freedom today.
The lithe, tousle-haired youth with the open collar watched the departing waitress. "She reminds me of the girls at Stouffer's," he said, smilingly, of his dishwashing job last year.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 6 (AP)--The United States Davis Cup team received a sharp setback today when its top doubles team of Chuck McKinley and Dennis Ralston bowed in the semi-finals of the Victorian tennis championships.
A social agency here told yesterday how it tried a decade ago to provide Lee H. Oswald with a substitute for the father who died before he was born.

BERLIN, Dec. 6--West Berliners were told today that they might be able to visit friends and relatives in East Berlin during the Christmas holiday for the first time since the Communists built the wall across the city in August, 1961.

Freight revenues of steamship carriers in the intercoastal trade dropped 19.3 per cent in the second quarter of 1963 compared with those for the same period last year, the Interstate Commerce Commission disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--Unemployment rose last month to its highest rate since last May.

Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon found himself required --like any other lawyer--to explain "what do you believe the principles underlying the form of government of the United States to be," before he could win admission to the New York bar.

Five top-ranking city school officials were subpoenaed yesterday by Governor Rockefeller's special investigations commissioner to testify at a public hearing next week on the school custodian situation here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--California became a partner of Chile today in the first program of technical assistance to a foreign country extended by an American state.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Dec. 6 --Mrs. Marguerite Oswald revealed today that she appealed to President Kennedy in 1961 for assistance in making contact with her son in the Soviet Union.
MOSCOW, Dec. 6--The Soviet Communist party made another major effort today to put a damper on its ideological dispute with Communist China.
THE French Bridge Review offered the North hand in this deal as a bidding problem to its panel of experts and received a variety of opinions.

BONN, Dec. 6--Several million dollars of quick tax relief is in the works for the West German steel industry, the world's third largest producer and the principal pressure group for Government action to stem the general downtrend in the European steel industry.
Arthur F. Vinson, a vice president and group executive of the General Electric Company, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his room in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 (UPI)--The former light-heavyweight champion, Harold Johnson, made a successful but unimpressive comeback start tonight by winning a unanimous decision in a nationally televised 10-round bout with a clowning Henry Hank.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--A new method of recording, patented this week for the General Electric Company, uses a minimum of time and a minimum of tape.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 6-- The Patriarch of the Eastern Orthodox Church, Athenagoras I, proposed today that a meeting of the heads of the major branches of the Christian religion be held in Jerusalem next month during Pope Paul's visit there.
DALLAS, Dec. 6--A rifle shot that narrowly missed former Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker in his Dallas home last April 10 was fired by Lee H. Oswald, police sources said today.
ROME, Dec. 6--The Most Rev. Alfonso Carinci, at 101 years old the world's oldest Roman Catholic bishop, died this afternoon of a heart ailment.
Hugh Shannon, a singer and pianist who has lent a distinctive accent to the night life of Rome, Capri, Paris, London and Nassau, is back in New York after an absence of more than a decade.

Mrs. Dickerman Brown of 165 East 72d Street and James Oliver Brown, also of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Wilson Brown, to George Harrison Gilliam, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Skelton Gilliam Jr. of Upper Nyack, N.Y.

The traditional concept of missionary work--a white man going to convert the heathen of Asia, Africa or Latin America --may be radically changed as a result of a meeting beginning tomorrow in Mexico City.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 29--Techniques that built the Pyramids serve today in this capital, and everywhere else in India, to construct buildings of steel, concrete and glass as modern in their conception as New York's newest skyscraper.
HARRIMAN, N.Y., Dec. 6-- Educating manpower and developing health programs were described tonight as the major problems confronting new African and Asian nations.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 6-- The Baath party was declared illegal in Lebanon today under a decree issued by the Minister of the Interior, Kamal Jumblatt.

The state's longest and most remunerative thoroughbred racing season will come to a close today at Aqueduct. Featuring the nine-race program will be the $25,000 added Stuyvesant Handicap, a contest of 1 1/8 miles for older horses.
One of the most ancient complaints against New York City, and to a lesser extent New York State, involves the lack of long-range fiscal planning.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6--A "Call for Action" designed to put American Christians firmly in opposition to racial discriminaion in any form was approved here today by the National Council of Churches.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 6--There is an air of un reality in this lush and sophisticated city with tree-line boulevards that bask in a tropical sun as sampans quietly ply they Saigon River.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6-- Some of the finest and some of the youngest instrumentalists of the country have dedicated two concerts of chamber music this week to the memory of President Kennedy.
The American Playwrights Theater, formed to stimulate and develop the presentation of serious drama at a university and community level throughout the country, is moving ahead with plans.
President Johnson will fly here tomorrow to attend the funeral service for Herbert H. Lehman.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6--African countries opened a new attack in the Security Council today on Portugal's refusal to consider independence for her African territories.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 6-- Raiders from Ethiopia have killed 22 tribesmen near North Horr in Kenya's Northern Frontier district, the police reported today.
The Radio Corporation of America, the world's largest manufacturer of electronic equipment, has proposed a three-for-one split of the common stock.
Stocks lost ground on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday in fairly active trading.

PARIS, Dec. 6--"Mr. Scrooge," the fourth opera by the Slovak composer Jan Cikker, which had its first performance in Bratislava last week, shows that even the older-generation composers in Czechoslovakia are now beginning to approach Western musical idioms.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6--Anthony DeAngelis, president of the bankrupt Allied Crude Vegetable Oil and Refining Corporation, now involved in a huge financial tangle in New York, has relinquished his one-third interest in a new Chicago refining company.

Gruff comments about drivers who sound horns near hospitals and about refuse collection trucks that make noise at 3 A.M. dominated a bedside interview with Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6--The Soviet Union resorted to a rare maneuver today when it endorsed two opposing resolutions, one of which it was sponsoring with the United States. The subject was the economic consequences of disarmament.
President Johnson's route through the city tomorrow will not be made public, in line with "strict maximum security" measures arranged for his visit.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 6 (UPI) --A jury found T. Eugene Thompson guilty tonight of masterminding the murder of his wife for $1 million insurance and the love of a mistress. He was sentenced to life in prison at hard labor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) --The Labor Department issued a report today on a sore spot in the nation's labor movement, union membership losses.
THE 20th century was in its infancy, along with the ready-to-wear industry, when Archibald and Melville Davidow joined their father's skirt business on Bleecker Street.
Robert Littell, a senior editor of The Reader's Digest and a former drama critic and-columnist for The New York World, died here on Thursday. He was 67 years old.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Dec. 6-- The Government decided today to watch developments for a few days in the strike-bound port of Colombo before deciding how to clear essential cargoes and provide customs services.
Two men on trial for firstdegree murder in Supreme Court are acting as their own lawyers, disregarding advice by the court not to do so.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) --President Johnson discussed today problems centering on the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and military spending.
Roy W. Ammel, first pilot to make a solo nonstop flight from New York to the Panama Canal, died Thursday in Memorial Hospital. His age was 66.

A crowd of 12,693, the largest opening-night gathering for a collegiate basketball twin bill at Madison Square Garden since 1958, turned out last night to see highly rated New York University face its first important foe of the season.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6-- Congress's decision on whether to try to improve itself through reorganization was postponed indefinitely today.
Three children died before dawn yesterday in an apartment house fire in the East Bronx.

World Banking Corporation, Ltd., has been organized in Nassau, the Bahamas, by Robert B. Anderson, former Secretary of the Treasury, and the Bank of America (International). It is scheduled to open on Dec. 20.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) --Senator Maurine B. Neuberger urged the Senate Finance Committee today to adopt President Kennedy's original recommendations for a more liberal tax deduction for child care.
JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 6 (UPI)--A small group of Negroes carrying American flags turned up on Capital Street today in what integration leaders said was the start of a new desegregation drive.

President Johnson's agreement with Speaker John W. McCormack about carrying on the duties of the Presidency when the incumbent becomes disabled is probably as good a stopgap arrangement as could be devised, but it is no adequate solution for this difficult problem.

The liquidation of Ira Haupt Co., the brokerage house faced with such massive demands on its capital that it is going out of business, raises this tantalizing question for many Wall Street partners: Should they change their firms from partnerships into corporations?
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) --The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has ordered contractors on 12 major space projects to stop hiring new employes.
The communique issued at the end of the secret meeting of Communist China's Legislature makes a valiant effort to paint a bright picture of a nation steadily improving its economic situation.
Once again, the Internal Revenue Service has reported its collections from corporations-- this time for the period July, 1961, through June, 1962.
On the promise that they would get safety nets and platforms, the steelworkers who walked off the job on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge five days ago agreed yesterday to go back to work Monday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6-- Four railroad unions filed suit against a Federal arbitration ruling today. A fifth backed out after having said earlier it would join the court action.
The Coast Guard yesterday charged the captain of the Staten Island ferryboat Verrazano with contributory negligence in the crash between the ferry and a coastal tanker.

Eight physicians sued the Columbia Broadcasting System for $16 million yesterday, charging that a television show titled "The Health Fraud" made them appear to be "medical quacks, health frauds and crooks."
LONDON, Dec. 6--Christine Keeler, the party girl who played a central role in the Profumo affair, was sentenced today to nine months in prison for perjury and conspiring to obstruct justice.

BERLIN, Dec. 6 (AP)-- The East German Government charged today that Hans Krueger, West German refugee minister in Chancellor Erhard's cabinet, committed war crimes in occupied Poland during World War II.

IF an American in Paris these days asks how France is governed he is answered, of course, with a single name: De Gaulle. If he asks how Frenchmen would like to be governed in the future, he is hotly showered with innumerable plans and projects and pronouncements.
BONN, Dec. 6--A West German Army corporal went on trial today on charges of having mistreated troops under his command.
The Macmillan Company announced yesterday that on Monday it would resume shipments of Victor Lasky's critical book about John F. Kennedy-- "J.F.K.: The Man and the Myth."

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 6-- A.J. Foyt of Houston raced to a record 97.019 miles an hour today in winning the Governor's Trophy race on the Oakes course here. The 112-mile race was one of the features of the fifth annual Bahamas Speed Week.
Marvin D. Kantor, president of J.R. Williston Beane, Inc., has been named to a top position at the Curtis Publishing Company.
Pier 12, in the Atlantic Basin area in Brooklyn, was dedicated yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Dec. 6--In a joint session that took only 40 minutes, the two major leagues today put their stamp of approval on legislation which, for at least a year, will permit each of the four new clubs in the majors to protect from the draft five first-year men.
Eli Whitney, the practical inventor of the cotton gin, would have marveled at the ingenious scheme for eliminating the two-price system for cotton that the House has just approved.
The Kaiser Aluminum Chemical Corporation, yesterday rescinded its price increase of a cent a pound on aluminum ingots announced on Thursday.
The Habimah, Israel's national, theater, will present Ansky's classic, "The Dybbuk," and two new works dealing with modern life in Israel during its forthcoming Broadway visit and American tour.
OTTAWA, Dec. 6--In the third quarter of the year, for which figures have just been announced, the Canadian economy met all but $27 million of its borrowing needs from its own resources.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--The Securities and Exchange Commission has blocked a proposed sale of stock by the Atlantic Research Corporation on the ground that the company's registration statement was "a mockery of the truth" and "completely unreliable."
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Dec. 6 (AP)--Dr. Archibald Henderson, educator, historian, critic, biographer and mathematician, died tonight at his home here after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 6--A harness racing season that started earlier, will close later and, of course, provided the greatest number of betting opportunities will end tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6--The General Assembly was asked today to appropriate $17,750,000 to finance the United Nations Emergency Force in the Middle East next year.
A police captain was suspended yesterday for moonlighting as a lawyer and accepting legal business from other policemen, including men under his own command.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 6 --Studebaker's sprawling red brick automobile plants, just south of the business district here, were quiet today.
Wide price swings in prices of world and domestic sugar futures highlighted an otherwise irregular commodity futures market yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 6--Movie writers last night authorized their union, the Writers Guild of America, to call a strike against Hollywood's major studios. It could be called at anytime.

An ancestral portrait, with family features strongly resembling today's fund-raising techniques, is clearly discernible in an ancient letter recently discovered by the Jewish Theological Seminary here.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6-- In a subdued atmosphere, the 64th football game between the Army cadets and Navy midshipmen will be played here tomorrow before an expected crowd of more than 100,000.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 6-- Dick Tiger of Nigeria will defend his middleweight championship for the third time tomorrow night, against Joey Giardello at Convention Hall here.
MOSCOW. Eastern Siberia, an area once regarded as having no oilbearing prospects, appears to be developing into a potentially rich petroleum-producing region.
LONDON, Dec. 6--The Conservative party has won a byelection that has finally given it some hope that the political outlook is not as black as it has seemed over the last year.
Foreign stock markets gave no hint of a reaction yesterday to the House Ways and Means Committee's passage of the proposed tax on American purchases of foreign securities.
Igor Stravinsky was at the City Center last night to see the New York City Ballet give the first performance in its winter season of "Movements for Piano and Orchestra."
The 22d anniversary of the Japanese bombing of Pearl Harbor was observed in two ceremonies here yesterday sponsored by the United Service Organizations.
The Board of Education will conduct a survey of school bus service to determine whether it should operate its own buses.
New debt financing will increase in volume next week, with the introduction of several sizable corporate and municipal bond issues.
Wilson Co., Inc., a major American meat packer, reported yesterday a slight dcline in earnings for the fiscal year ended Oct. 26 from the preceding fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--Mrs. John F. Kennedy left the White House today after a quiet goodby to the household staff, and moved into a home in the Georgetown section of the capital.
DALLAS, Dec. 6--Texas Attorney General Waggoner Carr announced today the indefinite postponement of a state inquiry into the assassination of President Kennedy.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 7-- Lost Creek, a community in the northeastern hills, Kentucky, has found itself. It is being called an example for other communities, including some in the Appalachian region, where a Presidential Commission is studying needs.
A financially beleaguered cooperative apartment development in South Nyack, N.Y., was made a profitable operation by refinancing through the Federal Housing Administration.

VIENNA, Dec. 7--It has cost the Austrian Government 2 million schillings (about $80,000) to put at rest the melodramatic tales of a Nazi wartime treasure cached on the bottom of Toplitzsee, a remote Alpine lake in the Dead Mountains of Styria Province.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--Premier Fidel Castro appears to be facing political difficulties with the Soviet bloc as a result of his friendly attitude toward Communist China.
The American neo-classic musical, "Oklahoma!" had a special, bittersweet poignancy yesterday in a capsule version presented to three thousand luncheon guests in Manhattan.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower urged yesterday that the order of succession to the Presidency be changed, eliminating the House Speaker and President Pro Tempore of the Senate.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 7-- Iraq's latest coup on Nov. 18 has created a new situation not only for Iraq but for Syria and for the whole Middle East. It has shattered for the time being the Baath party's dream of uniting Iraq and Syria in a people's Democratic Baathist state.

TWO images will live on in our minds. One is of a deranged assassin, coolly aiming a rifle from a Dallas window; the other is of the dignified bearing of the President's wife in the aftermath of her husband's death.

As was demonstrated by tie, unanimous vote last week in the United Nations Security Coubcil, South Africa's practice of apartheid--which carries racial discrimination to a point unknown anywhere else--has resulted in her complete isolation from the rest of the world.
LONDON, Dec. 4--British archeologists have found in northern Greece the earliest known remains of prehistoric man.

Exactly a year has passed since the start of the longest and costliest newspaper strike in the city's history. The adverse effects of that 114-day shutdown, in changed reading habits and lost circulation, are still being felt by the newspapers and their employes.
LENOX, Mass., Dec. 7--Miss Martha Usher Fuller was martied this afternoon to Francis Brown of Salem, in the Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7--A white bull terrier with a black spot on her left cheek drew a remarkable number of smiles and backslaps from those closest to the ring when she became best in show in the 69th and largest event of the Kennel Club of Philadelphia tonight.
William J. Gottlieb, president of the Automobile Club of New York for nearly 25 years and a campaigner for traffic safety died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 66 years old.
JERUSALEM, Israel--A major archeological assault on Massada, an almost inaccessible rock plateau perched 1,200 feet above the Dead Sea, got under way recently.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7-- Bishop Reuben H. Mueller, newly elected president of the National Council of Churches, said here today that Americans had not fully assessed the lessons to be learned from the assassination of President Kennedy.
PHILADELPHIA, dec. 7--The fiual decision regarding Navy's participation in the Cotton Bowl game on Jan. 1 at Dallas was left to the players themselves.

Lyndon B. Johnson had not been President of the United States 24 hours when he put in a long-distance telephone call to Robert B. Anderson, an old friend from Texas who had been Secretary of the Treasury in 1957-60, when Mr. Johnson was Senate Majority leader.

ALTHOUGH many moviegoers are justifiably bemoaning the moribund state of the featurelength animated film, born in 1937 in the guise of Walt Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs," the end is not in sight.

THOSE who read the verylatest poetry out of Eng land are soon aware of a neonational temper in British verse.

LAST week's list of my favorite crime books of 1963 was limited to full-length novels. An thologies and single-author collections of short stories have been relatively few this year; but some of them certainly deserve mention among 1963's criminous highlights.
ANY fresh interpretation of "the Yoknapatawpha Country" pays further and welldeserved tribute to the intricate art of William Faulkner.

THE holiday season annually inspires more than normal exhibition activity in photography. This year, the schedule is heavier than usual, with some emphasis on color prints. These are highlights of current shows:

THE author of "Christianity and Revolution" shoulders a heavy task. The subject of his book "in general, is the relation of twentieth-century Christianity to the world policy of today. Its subject, in particular, is the relation of the Cuban Church to Castro's Communist state."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--The Atoms for Peace program, once a widely heralded dream, will celebrate its 10th anniversary tomorrow with no official commemoration, a past of only limited achievement and widespread government indifference about its future.

Guy D. Plunkett, professor emeritus of finance at New York University, died in Toulon, France, on Tuesday. He was 69 years old and lived at 12 West Union Avenue, Bound Brook, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Officials here believe that Cuba is pressing for an increase in economic help from the Soviet bloc. She is said to be particularly concerned with rebuilding her lagging agriculture.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 11--The Security Council adopted today a resolution Calling for increased pressure on Lisbon to accept the "United Nations interpretation of selfdetermination" for territories controlled by Portugal. The vote was 10 to 0. France abstained.
LONDON, Dec. 11--The Government announced today that it intended to license five companies to conduct pay-television experiments in various sections of the country.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 11 --Army's swimming team made it two victories in a row today by defeating Lehigh, 65-30. The cadets captured first places in 10 of the 11 events.
WASHINGTON, Dec, 11 (AP) --United States ship operators and maritime labor spokesmen supported today, a bill to provide for subsidies for construction of ships for domestic service.

OSLO, Norway, Dec. 11-- Prof. Linus C. Pauling called today for United Nations supervision of nuclear stockpiles and for the acceptance of Communist China into the community of nations so that meaningful disarmament could take place.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Dec.11--The Soviet Union made a new demand today for a reorganization of the United Nations Secretariat to give a bigger share of senior posts to "Socialist countries" as a means of increasing efficiency.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP)--The Senate paid a final tribute today to President Kennedy.
The Parker Corporation plans to merge with the Putnam Management Company, bringing together five Boston-based mutual funds with assets in excess of a billion dollars.
ALBANY, Dec. 11--The Public Service Commission announced today that it was investigating whether gas rates charged by Consolidated Edison Company were "excessive."

MONTREAL, Dec. 11 (Canadian Press)--The Government board of trustees over five Canadian maritime unions urged the owners of Canadian Great Lakes ships today to form an organization that can speak with one voice.
A serious and somber addition to New York's skyline and culture was revealed yesterday with the Whitney Museum of American Art's release of its new building plans.
The small-businessmen trying to block construction of the new World Trade Center will take their arguments to the United States Supreme Court today.

The complicated salad oil scandal that has already resulted in a series of bankruptcies may take a long time to unravel. The full amount of the monetary losses--or who will bear them-- is not yet known. The extent of fraud or misjudgment is still to be revealed.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Thursday, Dec. 12--Kenya emerged today as Africa's newest independent state.
A David-and-Goliath advertising battle is about to break out between giant Trans-World Airlines, Inc., and tiny Swissair of Switzerland.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 11 --Mining company officials were studying today a broad Presidential decree ordering a halt to any mining operations considered "harmful to the public interest."

MANY outdoor sportsmen probably are unfamiliar with the names Dingell-Johnson and Pittman-Robertson. They should learn more about them for they identify Federal programs. Every time they buy fishing tackle or sporting arms and ammunition a portion of their money in the form of excise taxes goes to these programs.

Kidnapping for reasons of state, revenge, lust, greed and caprice has been resorted to throughout the history of man. The cruel crime reached a height of heinousness in the eyes of United States citizens when the child of a national hero. Charles A. Lindbergh, was kidnapped and killed in the nineteenthirties.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 11 (AP)--Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon conferred with former President Dwight D. Eisenhower for about an hour today.

NEWARK, Dec. 11--The food-oil puzzle centered on the fast-declining financial fortunes of Anthony DeAngelis, president of the Allied Crude Vegetable Oil Refining Company, took several new turns yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI)--President Johnson acted today to block threatened strikes against six major airlines that could have disrupted Christmas travel plans.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 11--The provisional Government indefinitely suspended publication of three Saigon daily newspapers today. Two of them, by innuendo, had criticized Premier Nguyen Ngoc Tho.

Steps toward the possible merger of the Union Oil Company of California and the Atlantic Refining Company were reported under way yesterday. It was said that the plans had not yet reached an advanced stage.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11-- President Johnson plans to invite the leaders of the nation's major farm organizations to a White House meeting this month in an effort to get an agreement on wheat and cotton legislation.
RUDOLF SERKIN never has been the most enter prising of program makers, and it is seldom that his recital programs depart from a handful of works by his favorite composers.
Permission has been granted by Actors Equity for "Funny House of a Negro," a 50-minute drama by Adrienne Kennedy, a new Negro playwright, to give a dozen performances a week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11-- The primary purpose of the Air Force's newly authorized orbiting laboratory will be to determine the effectiveness of manned space stations for photographic reconnaissance of the earth.

WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP, N.J., Dec. 11--Richard L. Saunders Sr. of 674 Beechwood Drive, a former vice president and director of Texaco, Inc., died yesterday in Valley Hospital, Ridgewood. He was 71 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Why doesn't anyone ever "mention" Senator Thomas H. Kuchel of California as a potential candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination?

LONDON, Dec. 11--Did Sir Alec Douglas-Home engage in corrupt practices to get himself elected to the House of Commons last month? Specifically, did the Prime Minister "buy" votes in the Kinross and West Perthshire by-election with drink?

LONDON, Dec. 11--A group of 125 men and women, among them some of Britain's most prominent writers, directors, producers and actors, has applied to the Government for a license to operate a television company.

Five military installations in the metropolitan area will be closed by October, 1966, if plans announced by the Pentagon yesterday are put into effect. The installations employ more than 1,220 persons, most of them civilians.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York awarded yesterday $75 million of first and refunding mortgage bonds to an investment banking syndicate managed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.
Strength in rail issues failed to check an easing trend in stock prices yesterday as market activity thinned.

The rating of the Chicago Bears' crack defensive unit was reflected yesterday in the National Football League All-Star team selected for The Associated Press by a panel of 42 writers and broadcasters from the 14 league cities.

ROME, Dec. 11--Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, Italy's natural gas and oil agency, said that the withdrawal of financial interest by four West German banks in two E.N.I. subsidiaries in south Germany was not unusual and that it had nothing to do with reports that the Italian company was "dumping" Soviet oil in the country.
Four teams with a collective record of 12 victories and one defeat will see action in the college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight.
Ira Smolev, a rugged 6-foot3-inch 190-pounder, may help revive some of the great popularity basketball once enjoyed at City College.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 11 (AP)--Douglas Stewart's Valeene closed with a rush today and upset the heavily favored Gold Frame in the $7,500 Senorita Handicap at Tropical Park. Ye-Cats, the second choice, was third and Put On Airs, running as an entry with the winner, finished fourth.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 11 (AP) --Today was a banner day for long-shot players in the crowd of 8,756 at Pimlico race track as the returns ranged from a low of $10.40 to a Maryland fall season high of $283.40.

GENEVA, Dec. 11--The Swiss Bankers Association has called on the country's banks to help fight inflation by following a tight-fisted credit policy designed to reduce the economic strain resulting from prolonged prosperity.

The rising tide of political "dope stories" on who will be the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee next year serves to emphasize an unhealthy tradition in both major parties. They normally pick their candidates for Vice President on the basis of qualifications precisely the opposite of those applied to their Presidential nominee.
The bull market in impressionist and figurative modern art raised a total of $1,028,250 at an auction last night before an overflow crowd in the ParkeBernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 11--A deadlock between the Bolivian Government and rebellious tin miners continued today over the release of four American hostages.
HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 11--A gap in American humor was filled today when observations about Hollywood by the creator of "Mr. Dooley" were revealed.

PARIS. ONE of the most famous apartments in Paris overlooks the gardens of the Palais Royal. It was the apartment of Colette, the author, and it is now occupied by a personality in her own right, Colette de Jouvenel, her daughter.
The Occidental Petroleum Corporation attained record earnings in the three and nine months ended Sept. 30, Dr. Armand Hammer, president of the Los Angeles company, reported to stockholders yesterday.
Hundreds of thousands of dollars in kickbacks are made annually to Broadway producers and other theatrical employes, state investigators disclosed yesterday.

A high-ranking school official testified at a state hearing yesterday that city school custodians received two to five times as much as was paid for similar work in the municipal colleges and private industry. Moreover, he said, many school buildings still are not kept clean or adequately maintained.
When it comes to men's sportswear and furnishings, it's a young man's world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11-- The Pentagon is expected to announce within a day or two plans to close 35 military installations in the United States by October, 1966. The economy plan would affect about 75,000 jobs.

Long Island University, which has consistently produced one of the area's stronger baseball teams for the last decade, has been admitted to the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Baseball Conference along with Fairleigh Dickinson and Seton Hall of New Jersey, enlarging the league to 11 teams.

ACCRA, Ghana, Dec. 11 (Reuters)--President Kwame Nkrumah revoked today the appointment of Sir Arku Korsah as Ghana's Chief Justice. The move followed the acquittal of three defendants in a treason case.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 11 (AP) --Avery C. Adams, retired president and board chairman of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, died of a heart attack today in his Pittsburgh apartment. He was 65 years old.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 11 --Princeton's swimming team won nine of 11 events to defeat New York University, 66--28, in Dillon Pool tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11-- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson performed her first public act of charity today as First Lady.

ADELAIDE, Australia Dec. 11 (UPI)--Chuck McKinley, the Wimbledon champion and the key man on the United States Davis Cup tennis team, disclosed today he had turned down a $60,000 offer to become a professional player.
LONDON, Dec. 11--R.A. Butler, the Foreign Secretary, has sent a messasge to Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union suggesting that they meet, it was disclosed today.
Cotton futures closed yesterday up $1.05 a bale to down 5 cents on the New York Cotton Exchange. Old December was strong in the late trading.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 11 --The liberal arts tradition in American higher education "is dead or dying," Dr. Jacques Barzun, dean of faculties and provost of Columbia University, said today.
The nation will achieve "substantial economic gains" next year, provided there is an early income-tax cut, according to a leading economist in the life insurance industry.
NASSAU, the Bahamas, Dec. 11--Difficulties continued to beset 17 trans-Atlantic airlines today in their efforts to reach a new set of fares. The current rate schedule expires March 31.
ROME, Dec. 11--The Vatican said today that the purpose of Pope Paul's pilgrimage to the Holy Land was a "spiritual encounter" with Orthodox Christians.
"THE national amateur field trial championship for springer spaniels has taken hold in a big way," said Mrs. Evelyn Monte of New York yesterday of the newest major event on the field trial calendar.
Brooklyn Navy Yard workers, fearful of losing their jobs, have started an intensive campaign to get the government to assign more work to the yard.
The oceanographic research vessel Vema, delayed by heavy weather, returned here yesterday from a 10-month world cruise with news of discovery of a sea canyon off Southeast Africa.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11-- President Johnson intervened today to prevent a further slash in this year's foreign-aid funds.

An ocean freighter, laden to its Plimsoll line with cargo for Europe, cleared the last lock of the St. Lawrence Seaway near Montreal yesterday. Until next April, the great waterway that was opened five years ago list spring as a joint United States-Canadian operation, will lie cold and deserted under the Northern Lights.
An increase of 1,225,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

The Charles Pfizer Company, manufacturer of pharmaceuticals with plants and offices throughout the world, has sold six acres of vacant land at Gardner and Lombardy Streets in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday the changes listed below in the share holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of companies whose shares are listed on those exchanges.
NEWARK, Dec. 11 (AP)-- The trial of two labor leaders accused of demanding and receiving money from a Jersey City macaroni company to insure labor peace ended tonight in a hung jury.

"Okay, roll it." The scene was the 18th floor of the Downtown Athletic Club, where Roger Staubach of Navy was undergoing a four-hour blitz by newsmen yesterday before accepting the Heisman Trophy as the nation's outstanding college football player.
Leading industrial shares surged forward on the London stock market yesterday, many of them reaching new highs for the year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11-- Pentagon officials are understood to be enthusiastic over the prospect of an Army rifle, now in development, that would shoot dart-like bullets and throw grenades.

LONDON, Dec.11--Lord Mancroft, a Jew who was forced to resign from the board of one of Britain's biggest insurance companies because of Arab pressure, said today that he had decided against accepting an offer to rejoin the board.

The Board of Education appointed three special consultants last night in a move to step up the school integration program, and approved another program to increase the number of Negro and Puerto Rican supervisors.

TORONTO, Dec. 11 (UPI)-- The Detroit Red Wings defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight, 3--1, and dropped the second-place Leafs to 10 points behind the first-place Chicago Black Hawks in the National Hockey League.
Good skiing was reported yesterday at Jay Peak in northern Vermont, where there was an 18-to-28-inch base, while at Killington in Sherburne, limited running was listed for the time being.

Stockholders of the Bates Manufacturing Company at their meeting yesterday in Lewiston, Me., approved the purchase of 400,000 shares of common stock of the Virginia Iron, Coal and Coke Company. The plan had been previously approved by directors of both companies.
MOSCOW, Dec. 11--The president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences urged today that the Government set up a national center to coordinate chemical research.

PANGIM, India, Dec. 11-- The Maharashtrawadi Gomantak party, which favors merging this small former Portuguese colony with the neighboring state of Maharashtra, appeared tonight to have won control of Goa's first Legislative Assembly.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11-- Some Republicans on the Senate Rules Committee may boycott the committee's special investigation of Robert G. Baker, former secretary to the Senate's Democratic majority.
The Jersey Central Power and Light Company announced yesterday plans for building a $68 million nuclear power plant in Lacey Township, Ocean County, N.J.
Alfred J. Phillips, a former City Councilman from Queens, died Monday in the Arlington Manor Nursing Home, Oceanside, L.I. He was 81 years old.
STATELINE, Calif., Dec. 11 (UPI)--Sheriff's deputies today released John N. Foss, whom they had held in "protective custody" since he witnessed the kidnapping of Frank Sinatra Jr. Sunday night.
John Halpert's layup shot with 47 seconds left in overtime enabled Yeshiva to defeat Marist of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., 68-- 66, at Archbishop Molloy High gym last night.
LONDON, Dec. 11--"The most noticeable thing about the Jews in politics is that they are so rarely noticeable."
The extension of the present 12-year program of public schools to include junior college was recommended yesterday by Mrs. Mary Conway Kohler, new member of the Board of Education.
WASHINGTON, Dec.11--The Administration, expecting the Soviet Union to shop for longterm trade credits from the West, will continue to press its allies for a common credit policy.
Sugar futures dropped sharply yesterday on profit taking following advances of the two previous sessions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11-- President Johnson instructed Cabinet officers today to hold down new Federal employment and achieve more substantial economies in administration.
The city's subway system will need 1,000 additional workers over the next decade, Commissioner John J. Gilhooley said yesterday.

CORNING, N.Y. Dec. 11-- Frederick Carder, founder of the Steuben Glass Works and authority on late 19th-century and early 20th-century art glass, died last night. He had celebrated his 100th birthday on Sept. 18.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11-- Walter W. Heller, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, indicated today that he expected the gross national product to exceed $620 billion next year if tax reduction was enacted promptly.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--This cave of the winds is whistling with all sorts of ideas for a statute designating a revised order of Presidential succession in the event of the death or "disability" of a President in a time when, as now, the office of Vice President is vacant.
The outlook is rosy for profits in the first half of 1964, according to the National Industrial Conference Board, reporting on answers to queries it put to manufacturing concerns.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11-- The Government urged the Supreme Court today to resolve quickly the four-year-old legal dispute about the closing of schools in Prince Edward County, Va.

Directors of the Carolina Power and Light Company yesterday recommended a two-forone split of the common stock and raised the quarterly dividend to 50 cents from 46 cents paid previously. The cash dividend is payable Feb. 1 to holders of record Jan. 10.

Edward Lane Shea, former president and chairman of the Ethyl Corporation, died of a heart attack yesterday morning in his apartment at 765 Park Avenue. He was 71 years old. His home was in Locust Valley, L.I.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11-- Liberal Democrats are quietly organizing a new effort to alter what they call the power structure of the House of Representatives.
Jacques d'Amboise's "The Chase," a novelty of the New York City Ballet's fall season, was given last night for the first time during the company's winter season at the City Center.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 11 (AP)--President Arturo Illia's Government ordered today a full-scale investigation of the contracts negotiated between the State and private oil companies, largely American concerns, in 1958 and 1959.
The discovery of a profound and highly specific effect of narcotics on the chemistry of living cells was reported at a scientific meeting here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11-- Two lawyers dedicated to Negro rights urged the Supreme Court today to reverse the contept convictions of two Southern racists.
CHICAGO, Dec 11--The Administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency described as one of the most pressing problems today the lack of adequate housing for low-income families.

The Chicago Black Hawks are so good they play as if they had invented the game of hockey. Last night, Stan Mikita's three goals, Ken Wharram's two goals, Glenn Hall's fine goal-tending and Bobby Hull's 200th major-league goal paced the Hawks to a 6-2 victory over the hapless New York Rangers.

Congressional cuts in the foreign aid bill have came at a time when aid appropriations have been bumping up against budget ceilings in most of the other advanced countries. To make matters worse, the leveling off of governmental aid in the face of rising need has coincided with a decline in private foreign investment in the new nations.

A study of the academic records Of Negro scholarship stu dents in interracial colleges shows that Negro graduates of Southern high schools do better in college than Negro graduates of Northern schools.
A PRODUCT called Velcro is smoothing a number of home furnishing tasks today because burrs once became tangled in the clothing of a man walking through a field.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP)--Mrs. John F. Kennedy has purchased a Georgetown home across the street from the one she is now occupying.
PARIS, Dec. 11--The Government of France remained firm tonight on an end-of-the-year deadline for agreement on three farm regulations within the European Economic Community.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11-- Prospects for Congressional approval of a Fire Island national seashore next year appeared brighter today than ever before.

The heralded wheat deal with the Soviet Union is floundering. The Russian negotiators are proving tough bargainers; they are now balking at paying the high transportation costs charged by American shippers. Earlier, they had refused to buy wheat unless they could obtain credit, which involved getting the Export-Import Bank to guarantee loans made by commercial banking houses.
An 11-year-old Chinese orphan boy was granted naturalization yesterday in Federal Court on the petition of only his adoptive mother, herself a naturalized citizen who was born in China.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 11--Elkan Ries Myers, president of D. Myers Sons, womens' shoe wholesalers here and a civic leader, died at his home, Park Towers, yesterday. He was 69 years old.

A letter from Elmhurst, L.I., received yesterday by the Neediest Cases Fund, read: "The arrival of our own child this year has somehow made the plight of the children in the 100 Cases immediate to us."

Officials of the Commodity Exchange Authority, which has been criticized in the present vegetable oil tangle for not properly regulating commodities futures trading, say that they have no statutory authority to exercise greater powers.
United States Government bonds declined yesterday in moderately active trading.
Filling a Civil Court vacancy in Queens is posing a major problem for Mayor Wagner, since the two top contenders are men to whom he is personally and politically indebted.

BETWEEN Thanksgiving and Christmas, the mention of hot desserts generally means one thing--plum pudding, rich, dark and fragrant. The forerunner of the plum pudding was probably introduced into England by the Romans, and was described by Samuel Pepys during the 17th century "as a mess of brave plum porridge." sisted of a meat mixture, thickened with bread or cereals, flavored with fruit and spices.
A key witness in the murderconspiracy indictment of the Gallo gang of Brooklyn has fled and is being sought by the police throughout the East.

THESE fine short stories, by a young Australian now living in America, must have been written with a string play er's mute attached to the typewriter carriage. Everything in them is subdued, understated, muffled like drums under velvet. Although the people in these stories suffer loss of love, loss of mate, loss of illusion, none... GLIFFS OF FALL. By Shirley Hazzard. 192 pages. Knopf. $3.95.
A big increase in the number of warlike Christmas toys and the demand for them, especially in the New York suburbs has ignited a parental revolt in the Morristown, N.J., area.

BONN, Dec. 11--The West German Government said today that some of the European Common Market's agricultural problems could be settled by Dec. 3 only if solutions were found that are "acceptable to all member nations."
Dr. Jack Rapoport, a psychiatrist and a psychoanalyst, died Tuesday in his home at 920 Park Avenue. His age was 55.

FOR many years it had seemed that Jacob Nelson Fox was as much a Chicago landmark as The Tribune Tower. He was the solid man at second base for the White Sox. Nellie is only 5 feet 9 inches tall, but has so many intangibles to go with his tangibles that he won the most-valuable-player award in 1959.
ALBANY, Dec. 11--The State Investigation Commission ran into new roadblocks today as it continued for the second day public hearings on Albany County purchasing practices.

Many of New York's most elegant restaurants remained closed for the third day yesterday as state mediators renewed their efforts to settle the wage dispute.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11-- President Johnson supported today the Potomac River site for the proposed national cultural center that is expected to be named for President Kennedy.

The Board of Estimate unanimously approved fluoridation of the city's water supply in a 16-minute session yesterday.

A New Yorker who asked to remain anonymous sent his donation to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday "in the hope that this gift [$15] brings health and happiness to another family, as my family has been fortunate enough to enjoy."
Low-price issues held the spotlight yesterday in a stock market that showed little change.

LONDON, Dec. 12--The Prime Minister, Sir Alec Douglas-Home, said today that if British companies found themselves in difficulties because of the Arab League's boycott of Israel, they could count on the Government to help them.
Industrial shares on the London stock market continued to advance yesterday, but, at a slower rate.

LEADING the list of those who appreciate the finer things of life are fishermen. This has been true since that myterious lady, Dame Juliana Berners, wrote the first modern book on fishing: "The Treatise of Fishing With an Angle."
Although it was certainly a perfect day to stay in bed, determined Christmas shoppers slogged their way yesterday through the city's first measurable snowfall of the season.
A tall, broad-shouldered scholar and leader in American Reform Judaism was honored last night on nearing his 65th birthday.
STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 12-- A leading industrialist said today his recent announcement that his concern was undertaking a policy of preferential hiring of Negroes had been misunderstood.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 12--A Foreign Ministry official said today that the next conference of nonaligned nations would probably take place in the autumn of 1964, three years after the first meeting, which was in Belgrade.

ALBANY, Dec, 12--Senate Republicans served notice today that they would support no tax increases at the coming session of the Legislature, nor back any new programs involving the outlay of substantial sums.

The fashionable East Side was criticized yesterday for its untidiness. The blame was placed largely on its preponderance of illegal packers, including diplomats, physicians and commuters from the suburbs. The problem was reported especially bad in the 60's, 70's, 80's and 90's.

ALBANY, Dec. 12--Charges by the State Investigation Commission of abuses in Albany County purchasing brought an angry reaction today.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12-- Federal Buerau of Investigation agents trying to solve the kidnapping of Frank Sinatra Jr. indicated late today that they had found a hideout of suspects in the crime.
PARIS, Dec. 12--France's Foreign Minister told the National Assembly today that the Government was interested in the development of trade and cultural relations with Communist China.
Marian Anderson announced plans yesterday to retire from the concert stage after a world tour that will begin next year.

A proposed return to unlimited substitutions was one of nine changes in the football rules recommended yesterday by members of the Eastern Association of Intercollegiate Football Officials during the annual Eastern College Athletic Conference convention at the Hotel Manhattan.

Danny Kaye is expected to continue next season on the Columbia Broadcasting System television network, but Judy Garland probably will not. This season is the first time that either has starred on a weekly one-hour variety show.
The New York Stock Exchange has asked the Internal Revenue Service for tax relief in its liquidation plan for Ira Haupt Co.
Eleven charities and institutions will receive $815,000 from the estate of Herbert H. Lehman, former Governor and Senator, who died Dec. 5 at the age of 85. The will was filed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12-- Governor Rockefeller plans to enter the Republican Presidential primaries in Maryland and the District of Columbia.

The crash of a Boeing 707 jet airliner in Maryland last Sunday appears to have been caused by an explosion that blew off a vapor-filled wing tip, informed sources said yesterday. The explosion may have been touched off by lightning.
Representative Samuel S. Stratton, whose political enemies once accused him of proNazi sympathies, last night received a resounding vote of confidence from a major Jewish civil rights organization.

ART exhibitions are no longer limited to 57th Street and the environs of upper Madison Avenue. In recent years they have been appearing almost anywhere people congregate, including department stores. The latest contribution to this spreading art movement is a show that goes on view today in Macy's ninth floor modern furniture department.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12-- President Johnson hailed today the gains made by business in the movement toward full equality in employment. He added, however, that there was still a long way to go.
BONN, Dec. 12--Dr. Theodor Heuss, West Germany's first President, died of a circulatory disease tonight in his Stuttgart home, his son announced. He was 79 years old.

Edward W. Zdunek, a retired General Motors Corporation executive, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Geneva.
The Radio Corporation of America sold more television sets in the first ten months of this year than in all of 1962.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12-- The three principal Cabinet members will fly to Paris tomorrow for the annual ministerial meeting of the North Atlantic Council.

HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 13-- The tallest structure ever built at a movie studio was "topped out" today at Universal City when a steel beam was hoisted 14 stories after a brief ceremony.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 12--A 46-year-old constitutional provision requiring management to share part of its profit with labor--in cash--became effective here today.

Unranked Toledo University engineered the upset of the young basketball season by overwhelming New York University, 87-74, in the featured game of a double-header at Madison Square Garden last night.

There was good news for holders of railroad shares yesterday. The New York Central Rail road voted a dividend of 50 cents a share, which would indicate that the carrier expects to clear $10.5 million in the fourth quarter and at least $6.5 million for the full year.

One of the city's principal post offices will be included in a 42-story skyscraper to be built on Third Avenue. It will be the first post office to be an integral part of a major commercial office building.

In defending the Administration's proposed tax on American purchases of foreign securities, Under Secretary of the Treasury Robert V. Roosa, observes that buying of foreign stocks and bonds during the first six months of 1963 involved so big an outflow that it threatened the status of the dollar. A continuation of this drain, he implies, would have brought a crisis.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12-- The United States trade surplus declined in October after a sharp improvement in September, the Commerce Department disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec, 15-- To the list of esoteric languages such as Tagalog and Swahili, in which the State Department now offers instruction, English has been added.

UP to now, New York has known Joan Sutherland only as an exponent of operas of the bel-canto school. On Saturday evening, though, she sang her first Verdi role at the Metropolitan Opera-- Violetta in "La Traviata."

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 15-- Church leaders from all over the world were told here tonight that "to our great shame the church is very late in awakening" to its duties in the racial struggles in the United States.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Dec. 15 --The 32 winners of Rhodes scholarships for 1964, which provide two years of study at Oxford University, were announced today.

Project Artemis, the United States Navy's study of the possibility of long-range underwater submarine detection, has been given new impetus with the installation of a deep-sea acoustic-receiver device.

Few pianists can lift the standard repertory to the heights Abbey Simon did in his recital last night at Carnegie Hall. It was not simply a case of playing that was fast and loud, intelligent and penetrating, cool and limpid, or any isolated qualities, but here the blending of all musical elements was paramount.
TO many parents of of teenagers, the holidays ahead loom as a test. Like the designer whose ship is off the drawing board and about to be launched, parents hope their progeny will swim, not sink.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 15--Cambodia has announced that she is closing her embassy in London and recalling the diplomatic staff in a move almost parallel with that taken against the United States last week.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15-- There is growing doubt in Washington that President Johnson will take part in televised debates with his Republican opponent in next year's Presidential campaign.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15-- President Johnson moved swiftly today to emphasize the importance and broad responsibilities of his new adviser on LatinAmerican affairs, Thomas C. Mann.
MOSCOW, Dec. 15--The Government will present its budget and economic plan tomorrow on the opening day of a weeklong session of the Supreme Soviet (Parliament).
Opponents of the city's proposal to lift controls on apartment rents of $250 a month or more said yesterday they would appeal to Mayor Wagner to block the move.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 16--Adding to the European Common Market's mounting tensions, is inflation, which now looms as a threat to the economic health of the community from the Mediterranean to the North Sea.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 15-- Vice President Juan Lechin Oquendo arrived at the Sigio Veinte mine today to free 17 hostages, including four Americans, held by miners there.
NEWARK, Dec.15--James R. Hoffa sounded a warning to the trucking industry today.

LONDON, Dec. 15--Financial circles are reported to be worried about the stability of 55 million ($154 million) in foreign bonds issued by the Central African Federation. One of the five bond issues involved, worth about $42 million, was raised in New York. The others were issued in London.
Two major Hoboken piers that had been idle since last February, when the HollandAmerica Line moved its terminal to Manhattan, have been put back in operation.
GRAND Master Pal Benko of New York, who cap tured first place in the North Central Open at Milwaukee over the Thanksgiving weekend, scoring 6 - , prefers to go his independent way in the openings.

A majority of the nation's leading corporate advertising executives believe that advertising agencies have shown improvements in performance over the last five years, but fully 90 per cent insist that further improvements are needed.

TRENTON, Dec. 15--New Jersey will enter the New Year with a serious financial crisis. And the indications are that neither Gov. Richard J. Hughes nor the Legislature will offer any resolutions toward an immediate solution.

The music of Poggi Escot, a young woman from Lima, Peru, and Charles Whittenberg, trained at the Eastman School of Music, now a New York resident, was heard at the Composer's Forum at the Donnell Library Auditorium Saturday night.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15-- Public officials pledged help today to the flood-damaged Baldwin Hills section of Los Angeles. Residents, meanwhile, began digging foot-... deep silt out of the homes that withstood the flooding after a hilltop reservoir broke yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15--The President's Committee on Equal Opportunities in Housing plans to implement a three-part program early next year aimed at educating the public in equal rights.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15-- After three years of heaving and hauling, the Kennedy-Johnson Administration has composed and published a coherent statement of its attitudes and policies toward Communist China.
JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 15-- Two Negro and two white Methodist ministers from New York were arrested here today when they attempted kneel-ins at two white churches.
Mata (Ruth) and Hari (Eugene) have a formula for fun that seems to have kept them and audiences all over the country entertained for years. And for good reason.

Judo, also known as the "gentle art," produced two cases of artificial respiration, a knockout, some wrist and ankle sprains and plenty of excitement yesterday at the New York Athletic Club.

OTTAWA, Dec. 15--The dramatic decision of Studebaker to transfer its automotive operations to Canada has developed some mayor long-term policy implications for the Government here, mainly in the international balance-of-payments field.

The New York Knicks yesterday acquired two National Basketball Association regulars at virtually no cost in a threeway transaction involving the Detroit Pistons and Cincinnati Royals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15-- The State Department and the Agency for International Development are taking a hard new look at a horsing project in Panama that Senator George A. Smathers has been pressing them to underwrite.
An off Broadway hit will be taped tonight for presentation on Saturday and Christmas night on pay television in Hartford.

LONDON, Dec. 15--Prince Sihanouk's decision to recall his embassy staff in London was regarded tentatively by diplomats here tonight as a further shift of Cambodia away from a position of neutrality to one in closer relationship with Communist China.

Strauss's "Ariadne auf Naxos" will return to the Metropolitan Opera repertory during its 11th week, which begins next Monday. Five performers will be new to their roles in this production, which itself was new last year.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 15 (AP)--Communist guerrillas killed a United States officer in a jungle battle today. Three other Americans were missing after their helicopter crashed into the sea last night while on a rescue mission in a guerrilla-infested area.
A 19-year-old factory clerk was arrested early yesterday and charged with killing a City College basketball star by deliberately running him down with an automobile.

Despite a severe slowdown in retail activity following the assassination of President Kennedy on Nov. 22, the nation's leading chain stores and mail order houses maintained a heavy level of sales volume in November.
While winning their third consecutive Eastern Division title, the New York Giants established a flock of attendance records.

THE winter tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association closed yesterday with a two-session mixed team-of-four contest in which 52 teams were entered. The tournament was played at the New York Hilton Hotel.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP)-- Influences in the grain market were not very durable or convincing last week and prices showed only moderate net changes from a week ago on the Board of Trade.

The head of the American Jewish Congress declared yesterday that the nation's three major faiths this year had moved "closer than ever before to mutual understanding, mutual respect and mutual cooperation."
The United States Lines, operator of the laid-up liner America, asked the National Maritime Union yesterday to make it possible for the vessel to sail again.
PARIS, Dec, 15--The United States and Britain agreed today on further exploration of the Soviet Union's willingness to proceed in reducing EastWest tensions.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 15--The upturn in the steel industry seemed to be moving ahead of schedule last week.

A half-dozen Harlem political and religious leaders, including Rep. Adam Clayton Powell, pledged support yesterday for a mass rent strike in rundown Harlem tenements.

Michael J. Quill urged yesterday that a summit meeting be held to study the possibility of subsidizing New York subway fares.

A newcomer to New York City, experiencing his first subway rush hour, has invented a game of analogy with his football experiences. "From the very moment you enter the turnstile," he explained, "the pigskin is in play."

The United Jewish Appeal announced yesterday that the Internal Revenue Service had ruled that contributions made to the appeal continue to be tax deductible under the recent ruling relating to charitable funds used abroad.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14-- Andrel A. Fomin, the Soviet Ambassador to Brazil, recently called on a high-ranking Brazilian official-in Rio de Janeiro.

PARIS, Dec. 15--The European Common Market is contemplating a new approach to the tariff issue that has proved the most difficult so far in preliminary planning for next year's round of international negotiations. The issue is known as "tariff disparities."
