The London stock market remained steady in languid trading yesterday.
TOKYO, Dec, 17--Japan's top political and business leaders paid tribute to President Kennedy at a national memorial service today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17--The Soviet Union gave a quick, cordial reception to President Johnson's appeal today for an end to the cold war and said Moscow would be pleased to see it followed up with "practical steps."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. (UPI)--A 13-man Army-Air Force team of parachutist has set a world record by falling 41,000 feet, almost eight miles, before opening 'chutes.

Carl Stern, first cellist of the New York Philharmonic for 20 years, will retire at the end of this season. His successor will be Lorne Munroe, the 39-year-old solo cellist of the Philadelphia Orchestra.
British control of one of the largest textile finishing plants in the Northeast has passed to its American Managers.
The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and the Uniformed Firemen's Association have authorized their leaders to ask for a $345 annual package increase for the city's policemen and firemen.
TRENTON, Dec. 17--The Port of New York Authority will decide in about six months whether to build the proposed World Trade Center in lower Manhattan.
BOSTON, Dec. 17--The John Birch Society spent nearly $36,000 in newspapers this week to promote its contention that President Kennedy was assassinated by a Communist "acting under orders."
LONDON, Dec. 17--The Government was assailed today in both Houses of Parliament for failure to guarantee bonds of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, which will be dissolved Dec. 31.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17-- The National Gallery of Art opened its doors today to the most comprehensive collection of modern art ever shown in the capital.
KITTY HAWK, N.C., Dec. 17 --The Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines and Coast Guard joined for the first time today in a display of air power.
The city must provide adequate schools in strategic areas if integration is to become a reality in the classroom, the City Planning Commission was told yesterday.
Shea Stadium definitely will be ready for the New York Mets in April, officials of the city and the architectural firm involved assured a group of visiting newsmen at Flushing Meadow yesterday.
Parks Commissioner Newbold Morris complained yesterday about parents who failed to supervise their children when they took them to city playgrounds.
A speedy turnaround of 5 hours will be attempted today at Southampton by the superliner United States. It would be the fastest turnaround ever made by the United States Lines' flagship.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18-- The Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters and the Pullman Company and three individual railroads reached agreement early this morning on a new contract.

TOKYO, Dec. 17--The Japanese Government is planning an investigation of price-fixing practices by big manufacturers and commercial concerns as part of its campaign to check the rise of commodity prices.
ONCE upon a time there were Three Bears. One was the owner of the team, one was the coach and the other was the captain and right end. All were named George Halas.

SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 17 --The Republic of Korea declared today the establishment of the third republic with the restoration of elected government. It formally brought to an end 31 months of military rule.
A chemical compound that appears to have some remarkable qualities not found in drugs generally available to physicians has created a stir in medical circles in Portland, Ore.
LONDON, Dec. 17--The Soviet Union informed Britain today that it favored an early international conference to discuss the means of guaranteeing the neutrality of Cambodia.
The Federal Aviation Agency is expected to issue an order, possibly today, requiring the installation of static electricity dischargers on the 100 or so Boeing jet airliners not equipped with them.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)--The Senate Finance Committee rejected today an attempt to repeal many of the tighter rules on expense-account reductions adopted by Congress in the Tax Revision Act of 1962.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17-- Senate-House conferces agreed today on an appropriation bill that would let the Justice Department hire the lawyers it needed for civil rights matters.

BALDWIN, L.I., Dec 17-- Michael Della Rocca, a shoemaker who since 1939 had produced and directed operas on Long Island in his spare time, died Saturday in Meadowbrook Hospital after a short illness. He was 62 years old.
IMPERIAL BEACH, Calif. Dec. 17--One of the alleged kidnappers of Frank Sinatra Jr. was talked into giving him self up by his brother.

TWICE a year, the lights dim a little after 9 P.M. in a crowded showroom high above darkened Seventh Avenue. Seated on little gold chairs, the most influential members of the fashion world, in evening dress, await the new Norman Norell collection.

A 44-year-old dock worker in New Orleans has been kept alive for six weeks with two kidneys transplanted from a chimpanzee.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 17--Larry Stevenson, a 6-foot 5-inch sophomore, tipped in a rebound with 4 seconds to play and gave Loyola a 73-71 basketball victory over St. Francis of Brooklyn tonight. The Terriers had led by 10 points early in the second half.
NEW DELHI, Dec.17 (AP) --Pope Paul VI has accepted an invitation to visit India, official sources said tonight.

Questions of national and scientific priorities must be very much in President Johnson's mind this week as he wrestles with the thorny problems involved in drawing up the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's budget for the 1965 fiscal year.
A funeral service for Mrs. Molly Kazan, playwright and wife of Elia Kazan, stage and screen director, was held yesterday at St. Clement's Protestant Episcopal Church, 423 West 46th Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--President Johnson told the United Nations today that "the United States wants to see the cold war ended, once and for all." But what if it happened, or even began to happen? Would the U.S. be ready?
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17-- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman said today that there would be no change in farm policy by President Johnson.
A claim against the Board of Education for $1,035,122 was submitted yesterday by a contractor who had been ordered to demolish and replace sections of a partly constructed school.

The New York Knickerbockers suffered their seventh straight defeat of the season last night, losing to the Detroit Pistons, 107--103. A total of 67 fouls was committed by the two National Basketball Association teams.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (UPI)-- A late rally raised most soybean future priced today, while rye retreated and other grain futures were steady to weak on the Board of Trade.

DANIEL POLLACK, heard in a recital in Carnegie Hall last night, is a good example of the fairly numerous gifted young American pianists who play with great virtuosity and brilliance and who approach music with the respect that makes them carefully dot their i's and cross their t's.
The Brooklyn chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality called yesterday for the immediate removal of Dr. Calvin E. Gross as city Superintendent of Schools.
A.G. Spalding Bros., Inc., the nation's leading manufacturer of athletic and sporting goods equipment, made a sharp recovery in earnings in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31.
Sugar futures plummeted yesterday. The decline followed two consecutive sessions of sharp advances.

Mayor Wagner will name Eric J. Treulich, majority leader of the City Council, as a judge of the Civil Court in Queens.

Two women employes of the Board of Education and three other persons were arrested yesterday on charges of participating in the padding of the board's payroll for a total of $13,970 in its school luncheon program.

Thirty-three works of art from the tomb of King Tutankhamen, including 15 executed in gold, go on exhibition in NewYork today in the Carnegie International Center at 345 East 46th Street near United Nations Plaza.

Several carloads of students at colleges here--and a truckload of warm clothing they have collected for impoverished coal miners in eastern Kentucky --will start out tomorrow to spend Christmas with miners' families in the area.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose above the 7 million-share mark in the month ended Friday. This is the highest level since the short interest reports were initiated by the Big Board in 1931.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18-- Lincoln once told an inquiring reporter that "you gentlemen of the press seem to be pretty much like soldiers, who have to go wherever sent, whatever may be the dangers or difficulties in the way."

College football this year enjoyed its biggest attendance gain. It drew more than one million fans above the record crowds of 1962.

WHAT values should prevail in the modern usage of American English was the subject of last night's hearing before "The Court of Reason" on Channel 13. Josephine Baker will return to the Winter Garden, where she made her last Broadway appearance in the "Ziegfeld Follies" in 1936. Her program, "An Evening With Josephine Baker," will open Jan. 9.

MOSCOW, Dec. 18--African students grappled and scuffled today with Soviet policemen in a mass demonstration in Red Square. They were protesting over the death of... a Ghanaian student who they said had been killed by Soviet citizens and over alleged racial descrimination.

Directors of the General Cable Corporation announced plans yesterday to split the common stock on a two-and-one-half-for-one basis. The move is subject to approval of stockholders at this annual meeting on April 8. If approved, the split would become effective April 20.

Two leases for space amounting to 33,500 square feet have been made in the 39-story office building constructed and owned by the Uris Buildings Corporation at 60 Broad Street. The building now is 97 per cent rented.

Abe Kreshinsky, a Democratic district captain who can deliver 200 votes for his party, walked into the middle of Wall Street a few mornings ago and went to work at his city job.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25-- The National Association of House Builders believe 1964 will be another big year for the housing business, but with relatively fewer apartments built than in 1963.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 25-- India's diplomatic gage is fixed today on Africa, where Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China is continuing his goodwill tour.

Those who arrived early at Philharmonic Hall last night were able to hear two concerts for the price of one.

A FEW hours before sunset yesterday, somewhere in America, a harried woman stood alone in her living room. The good-bys of her husband and children, gone outdoors to try out the new sled or the new pogo stick, still rang in her ears.
A collection of rare United States stamps has been purchased by a New Orleans stamp dealer for a record $1.1 million, it was announced yesterday.

CORK, which this country imports mainly from Portu gal, has attributes to recommend it for a number of decorating uses. It is easy to handle, relatively inexpensive, lightweight and a natural insulator.

At the turn of the century that cynical American observer, Ambrose Bierce, defined Congress as: "A body of men who meet to repeal laws." At this time cynical Washington observers could shorten the definition to: "A body of men who meet." The performance of the 88th Congress, which has done little and took an unconscionably long time to do even that, proves the point.
FOR the next nine weekends, snow fields of New Hamp shire and Vermont will sparkle with dogs racing under the banner of the New England Sled Dog Club.

New York University will permit Lincoln Center's Repertory Theater to use the ANTA Washington Square Theater for an extra year, until January, 1967. The repertory theater's temporary home at 40 West Fourth Street is being erected on land donated by the university to the nonprofit venture.

MADISON, N. J., Dec. 25-- Marcellus Hartley Dodge, honorary chairman of the board of Remington Arms Company, died here today at his home. He was 82 years old and lived at Giralda Farms.

MOSCOW, Dec. 25--A picture of the United States in which workers oppose a dismantling of defense industries, big business comes out for greater understanding with the Soviet Union and whites join in the Negro struggle for civil rights was painted today in Pravda, the Soviet Communist party newspaper.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 25 (AP)--With a strike threat lifted by track workers, Santa Anita Park will open its winter thoroughbred racing meeting on schedule tomorrow with the $20,000 added Palos Verdes Handicap.

HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 25--A film about the Bill of Rights, with screen credits for James Madison, Thomas Jefferson, John Adams, Benjamin Franklin, George Mason and Patrick Henry, is competing for an Oscar in two categories.

PARIS, Dec. 26--The United States was prodded by foreign economic authorities once again today to cut taxes.

THE legend said that Steve Van Buren was barefoot when he reported to the Philadelphia Eagles some 20 years ago from Louisiana State. This was a gross exaggeration. He was wearing shoes even though he was not wearing socks. But he learned a lot in his first season. At an end-- of-the-year dinner he raised one foot above the head table and brandished it.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 26 (AP)--Vince Lombardi, who led the Green Bay Packers from the cellar to two National Football League championships, reeeived a new five-year contract today.

LONDON, Dec. 26--The Labor Party demanded tonight an investigation by British authorities into the fire on the liner Lakonia. The number of those known to have died in the ship disaster reached 96. Thirtythree others are unaccounted for.
A Health Department official said yesterday that inspectors had still been unable to serve summonses on the owners of six rundowm rat-infested tenements involved in the Harlem rent strike.

Newly independent Kenya is divided into seven administrative regions. One of them, the Northern Frontier District, is arid, without natural resources, with only a few nomadic and very backward people. The frontiers with Somalia and Ethiopia are ill-defined.
Jacob J. Shubert, the last of three brothers who founded Broadway's most powerful theatrical dynasty, died of a cerebral hemorrhage yesterday. He was 86 years old.
AUSTIN, Dec. 26--The White House confirmed today that President Johnson had appointed a high-level Government committee to review the foreign aid program.
LET'S hope that the Irish coffee served in the lounge of the Little Theater at the intermission last night was well spiked. For the refreshments offered on the stage by "Double Dublin" were watery.
The Transport Workers Union clung to its demand for a 32hour, four-day week yesterday and threatened a New Year's Day strike of 35,000 bus and subway workers if it was not granted.
A new program for American Communists is being set forth in the light of President Kennedy's death and the party's court victory against compulsory registration.

Former Justice Arnold J.B. Wedemeyer of the City Court died Tuesday in St. Vincent's Hospital, West Brighton, S.I., after a short illness. His age was 86. Mr. Wedemeyer lived at 21 Rose Court, Silver Lake, S.I.
ALBANY, Dec. 26--Governors Rockefeller, will go for New Hampshire four times next month to step up his Presidential primary campaign.

NINETY-FOUR Barnard College undergraduates are living in a style that astounds their mothers and other alumnae of an earlier generation. The students are installed in an off-campus apartment house and enjoying a greater measure of freedom than their dormitory-bound classmates.
The vacant blockfront on the south side of Stanley Avenue, between Logan and Milford Streets, Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Atlantic Pork Provision Company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26-- Harold E. Stassen said today that he would seek the Republican Presidential nomination in 1964.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 26--A drastic change in the country's income tax laws on medical care was urged by a New York economist at a scientific meeting here today.
Levitt Sons, Inc., home builders, announced yesterday a quarterly dividend of 12 cents will be paid Feb. 1, 1964, to holders of record Jan. 15, 1964.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 26--A drastic change in the country's income tax laws on medical care was urged by a New York economist at a scientific meeting here today.
Levitt Sons, Inc., home builders, announced yesterday a quarterly dividend of 12 cents will be paid Feb. 1, 1964, to holders of record Jan. 15, 1964.

WALTER J. SUTCLIFFE, a New Jerseyan who be lieves that competent boatmen should preach what they practice as well as practice what they preach, is scheduled to become the next boss of the United States Power Squadrons.

PARIS, Dec. 26--Ann Lindbergh, 20-year-old daughter of the aviation pioneer Charles A. Lindbergh, was married to Jacques Feydy, Monday, in a civil ceremony in southwestern France. The bridgroom, also 20 years old, is the son of a Paris university professor.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 26 (UPI)--A sophomore guard, Cazzie Russell, scored 26 points tonight to lead Michigan to an 83-74 triumph over New York University in the featured opening-round game of the Los Angeles Basketball Classic.

The four-story building containing office, showroom and commercial space at 35 Union Square West has been sold by Island and Manhattan Associates, Inc. The buyer was Chill Rosen, an investor, who paid cash over a first mortgage of $171,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--The outcome of the complaint issued by General Counsel Ordman of the National Labor Relations Board, that the owners of "The New York Mirror" violated the Taft-Hartley Act by failing to consult its employes' union before shutting down the paper and selling its assets, is of very special concern to unions and management alike.
"I COME from the poor," said Diosdado Macapa gal, fifth President of the Philippines, to his povertyplagued electorate during the campaign of November, 1961.
Ever since Philharmonic Hall opened on Sept. 23, 1962, the acoustics of the auditorium have been hotly discussed and, in general, condemned.
Government bond prices edged up in early trading yesterday but municipal and corporate issues generally were unchanged on light volume.
Most major foreign stock exchanges were closed yesterday for post-Christmas Day holidays.
The Metropolitan Club was the setting for the fifth annual Doric Debutante Cotillion last evening, at which nine young women were presented to society.
SOFIA, Dec. 26--A former Bulgarian Communist diplomat, Ivan-Asen Khristov Georgiev, pleaded guilty today to a charge of espionage for the United States Central Intelligence Agency.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26.-- Defense officials appear to be preparing, themselves and military contractors for possible disarmament agreements with the Soviet Union next year.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Dec. 26--Nathan J. Cohn, a motion picture sales executive, died yesterday while vacationing here. He was 63 years old.
Even a Santa Claus, can be fined $25 for stirring up too much dust on the sidewalks on NeW York.

BERLIN, Dec. 26--A prominent member of the Christian Democratic party charged today that yesterday's shooting of a fleeing East German at the Berlin wall demonstrated that East Germany was in no position to make humanitarian agreements.
Maj. Gen. Charles W. Christenberry, president of the American-Korean Foundation, died on Tuesday in his home at 160 Riverside Drive. He was 68 years old.
HONG KONG, Dec. 26 (Reuters)--Talks aimed at obtaining a ceasefire on the embattled Plaine des Jarres in Laos have failed, Hsinhua, the Chinese Communist press agency, reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26-- In messages to the leaders of the Greek and Turkish communities of Cyprus, President Johnson has offered to do everything possible to end the bloodshed on the island. To preserve United States influence, he has also refused to take sides in the dispute.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI)--A United States-Soviet agreement establishing direct New York-Moscow air service may be signed within 30 days with service starting next summer, Najeeb E. Halaby said today.
The electrical-equipment manufacturing industry expects record sales of more than $27 billion in 1964.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 27--A panel of six space scientists will go to India next week to decide if the new international rocket launching station at Thumba qualifies for United Nations sponsorship.

RIVERHEAD, L I., Dec. 27-- A 20-pound, 5 -foot boa constrictor called Coily, muskrat and other wildlife will be served to 44 members of Company E of the 16th Special Forces when they take part in a week-long jungle survival course scheduled to start Feb. 15.

NUTLEY, N.J., Dec. 27--Dr. William A. Kelly, a psychologist, lawyer and director of graduate studies at Fordham University's School of Education, died today at St. Francis Hospital, the Bronx. He was 63 years old and lived here at 33 Nairn Place.
Stocks staged their second successive post-Christmas advance yesterday. The stock market was strong and active in the morning, then weakened in later trading.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 27-- Smoke from the barbecue pits curled through the live oaks, guests burned their fingers on sizzling beef spareribs and the elite of Washington officialdom tiptoed around in street shoes today as President Johnson held a news conference over a bale of hay.

Herman T. Stickman, who had asked for $665,000 for sevenyears service as trustee of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad during reorganization, received yesterday an award of $445,000 from Federal Judge Archie O. Dawson.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 27 (UPI)--Favored Luis Rodriguez rallied tonight to score a unanimous decision over Wilbert (Skeeter) McClure in their 10-round televised fight.
IN homes throughout the nation this Yuletide, ama teur and professional musicians have been feting delighted, if modest-sized, audiences with Christmas carols and Beethoven quartets.

OTTAWA, Dec. 27--The annual review of Canada's economy and the outlook for 1964 by Mitchell Sharp, Minister of Trade and Commerce, published today, declares conditions are good. Mr. Sharp says there is room for improvements and that he expects some in the new year.

TAYNINH, South Vietnam, Dec. 27--Maj. Gen. Duong Van Minh, head of South Vietnam's military junta, flew to this provincial capital today to receive a public pledge of allegiance from the dissident Cao Dai religious sect and to try his hand at grass-roots politics.

LONDON, Dec, 27--The ambitious "International Season of Ballet" continues apace at the Royal Albert Hall. This combination of London's Festival Ballet and a group of Soviet stars is potentially full of interest. But the Spartan Albert Hall setting and the program's placing seems to be doing its best to dampen any flames of enthusiasm.

MACY'S basement party shop is stocked with festive things for celebrating New Year's Eve. A 10-foot long paper banner that spells out "Happy New Year" in red, white and blue is 94 cents. Strungout gold letters with the same message are 59 cents; in colored cardboard the message costs 29 cents.
WELLINGTON SUN, who has written much about the squeze play in bridge, reports today's deal--in which the result depended on simple card-reading rather than on the less common squeeze play.
The Fair Play for Cuba Committee, whose literature was distributed by Lee H. Oswald, the accused assassin of President Kennedy, is disbanding, some of its supporters said yesterday.

BOSTON, Dec. 27--A vast exercise in what has been sarcastically termed "dialectical immaterialism" began here today when a swarm of economists set out to lecture each other in their own special jargon.

A gift to the Neediest Cases yesterday came from Dr. Rowland T. Bellows, who left New York City 30 years ago after receiving his medical education here. He wrote that the affairs of the city and the state where he was born were still "first in his heart."
CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (UPI)-- Soybean and grain future prices moved narrowly today on the Board of Trade.

The Modern Jazz Quartet, one of the very few jazz groups whose proper milieu is the concert hall, demonstrated last night at Philharmonic Hall, as it has done many times before, that a valid jazz concert can be carefully planned and executed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--Intercity truck tonnage and loadings of revenue freight both declined from the volume of the preceding week in 1962, it was announced today.
MOSCOW, Dec. 27--Premier Khrushchev predicted today that the United States would be expelled from South Vietnam with "even less ceremony" than were the French in 1954.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Dec. 27 (AP)--The Government decided tonight to take over all distribution outlets of three United States and British oil companies.

Former President Harry S. Truman chatted with Mayor Wagner for 45 minutes yesterday and described him as "an able, distinguished public servant." But he said he would not endorse Mr. Wagner or anyone else for the Vice-Presidency.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27-- There was no further word here today on wheat sale negotiations between Soviet officials and representatives of the Continental Grain Company.
OLEAN, N. Y., Dec. 27--Dr. Patricia D. Barron, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick D. Barron of Glasgow, Scotland, was married here this morning to John L. Worden 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Worden.
Miss Letitia Baldrige, former social secretary to Mrs. John F. Kennedy, was married here early yesterday afternoon to Robert Hollensteiner of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27-- Charles L. Decker, Judge Advocate General of the Army, has been named director of the Defender project of the National Legal Aid and Defender Association, the group's chairman, Orison S. Marden, announced today.

It will be Villanova's flashiness against Utah's hopefulness, and Minnesota's balance against the hustling agressiveness of St. Joseph's in tonight's Holiday Festival semi-finals at Madison Square Garden.
LONDON, Dec. 27--In Britain there is a curious local custom known as "swanupping" when the swans on the Thames, once a year, are counted and marked.

CHRISTMAS, a rather leaden season, particularly this year, has left the galleries more or less bare of exhibitions, apart from the usual group show, which since it has no point (except as a bridge over Christmas from one-man show to one-man show) there is no point in covering it. Here are some of the one-man shows still around:
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27-- Francis R. Smith, treasurer of the Democratic party in Philadelphia, was elected chairman this afternoon.

Three Jewish intellectuals yesterday presented contrasting views on the future image of Jewish cultural and communal life in this country that ranged from pessimism and uncertainty to cautious optimism.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 27-- Several thousand Bulgarians besieged the United States Legation building for more than an hour today. They smashed windows and overturned four cars owned by diplomats.

DURING the Second World War, the German Officer Corps, resplendent in Nazi uniforms and decorations, was not heard to make distinctions between those who were true believers in Hitler's Third Reich and those who may have believed in something else.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27--Robert Hall McCormick, a former assistant State Attorney for Cook County and grandson of Leander J. McCormick, a founder of the International Harvester Company, died today. He was 85 years old.
VIENNA, Dec. 27--Radio Free Europe reported tonight that despite a year of economic difficulties and shortages, some parts of Eastern Europe had a more relaxed Christmas than in previous years.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27--The condition of the playing field, the three-day advance weather forecast and the mood of George Halas were all favorable today with regard to Sunday's National Football League championship game between the Chicago Bears and the New York Giants.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI)--President Kennedy showed "stunned amazement" when he learned shortly after taking office that the Army would have virtually no strategic reserve if he sent 10,000 troops to Southeast Asia, his military aide said today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 27--The International Coffee Agreement, which was implemented last July 1 on a provisional basis, came into full force today.

Air pollution is a local problem that is also a national one. It affects 6,000 American communities, including all cities above 50,000 population and almost half of those between 2,500 and 50,000. The United States Public Health Service has estimated that it costs the American people the astronomical sum of $11 billion a year.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 28 (AP)--Roy Emerson of Australia trounced Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., 6--2, 6--3, 3--6, 6--2, today and evened the Davis Gup challenge-round series at 2--2.
TUNIS, Dec. 27--President Habib Bourguiba has appointed his son, Habib Jr., to a job described by a responsible Tunisian as equivalent to that of Deputy Premier.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 27 (AP)--Max Factor Co. of Los Angeles was charged here today by the Justice Department with fixing retail prices on its cosmetics since 1959.
There was a new sense of urgency in the city's transit dispute yesterday, but no solid evidence of progress toward a settlement.
LONDON, Dec. 27 (Reuters) --Parry Jones, a former butcher's helper who became one of Britain's leading singers, died at his London home last night. He was 72 years old.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 27-- Brazil's National Development Bank agreed in an important test case today to make a loan to a private United States company here from funds generated by the sale of American agricultural surpluses.
New York's Great White Way, dimmed a bit in recent years, may soon glitter again with new spectaculars, including the largest electrical waterfall in the advertising world.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 27--Some 450,000 kilowatts of atomic power in the nation's nuclear reactors are going to waste, but basic research that was discussed here today may put a stop to it.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 27--Four prisoners who were involved in military rebellions against the Government escaped today from their prison on the island of Tacarigua, near Valencia. It is believed prison officials helped the fugitives escape.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27--Pete Rozelle, Commissioner of the National Football League, today predicted that Sunday's playoff game between the New York Giants and Chicago Bears would yield the biggest return for a championship game in the league's history.

The chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights said yesterday that "extremists on both sides" were exaggerating, the importance of achieving school integration by transporting children out of their home districts."
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 27-- Boston University and Iona College won tonight to reach the final of the first Westchester Holiday Basketball Festival tomorrow.

DALLAS, Dec. 27--There is no question in the mind of Rear Adm. Charles C. Kirkpatrick, Superintendent of the United States Naval Academy, or of Wayne Hardin, the football coach, that Midshipman Thomas C. Lynch of Lima, Ohio, is the best captain any team could possibly have.
Marcellus Hartley Dodge was one of those rare men remembered above all for the warmth and generosity of their personalities.

Igor Oistrakh again demonstrated his remarkable sensitivity and skill as a violinist in his recital at Carnegie Hall last night. It was his third appearance there this season (the others were with the Moscow Chamber Orchestra) and his only local recital this year.

ATHENS, Dec. 27--Panayotis Canellopoulos, leader of the rightist National Radical Union, informed King Paul tonight that he had failed to form a new government to succeed the minority Cabinet of Premier George Papandreou.

Two of the oldest and most famous names in fine chinaware--Wedgwood and Spode-- have decided to unite. This will mean the pooling of skilled craftsmen working for the two British chinaware manufacturers, which have been in operation for more than 200 years.
A college football season that already has rewarded fans generously with action and excitement continues its year-end fling today with four games.
BONN, Dec. 13--A man can go thirsty for four days, live in total darkness for eight days and fast for up to four weeks without suffering psychological or long term physical effects.

UNTIL the New Year the lights will burn late on the fourth floor at 16 rue de l'Arcade. Marguerite Lapierre, chevalier of the order of Artisan Merit and member of the French Association of Women Painters and Sculptors, will be busy filling holiday rush orders.

The new emphasis upon economy in Government spending for scientific research and development must inevitably raise concern over the future of one of the most important basic research projects on the current agenda: the effort to drill the Mohole.
PARIS, Dec. 27--West German pressure for new initiatives to further the reunification of Germany is understood here to underlie forthcoming Western discussions on East-West relations.
BERLIN, Dec. 27--The United States protested to the Soviet Union today over the killing of an East German by East German guards at the Berlin wall on Wednesday.
LE KEF, Tunisia, Dec. 17-- In this hilly, wheat-growing region close to the Algerian frontier, two Peace Corps volunteers are beginning to see major fruits of year-long labors.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 27--The Negro population outside the South will have doubled by 1980, it was predicted here today.
Burmeister Wain's Shipyard of Copenhagen has launched the first of four fishing-fleet refrigerator ships built for the Soviet Union.

ALGIERS, Dec. 27--The Tunisian Government said today that it intended to recognize the Chinese Communist Government. The Tunisians also said that the Chinese Communist Premier, Chou En-lai, had been invited to visit the country next month.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27 (UPI)--New York University, led by Harold Hairston, took the lead from a smaller Yale team midway in the first half today and scored a 96-82 victory in a Los Angeles basketball classic consolation-round game.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27-- There was essentially no change this week in the yields on newly offered Treasury bills.

Work is about to begin on the design of a large new museum for the space age in the nation's capital. The Government's National Air and Space Museum, a branch of the Smithsonian Institution, will be at one of the city's most conspicuous sites--on the Mall between the Capitol and the Washington Monument.

TO some Americans, particularly those living south of the Mason-Dixon Line, sweet potatoes are not at their best unless cooked with marshmallows. Others in this country are quick to turn up their noses at what they consider an unbearably cloying combination. But with or without marshmallows, sweet potatoes are an American favorite and have been since colonial times.
HOUSTON, Dec. 27--Chancellor Ludwig Erhard of West Germany arrived today from Bonn for a weekend meeting with President Johnson. His plane landed at 6 P.M. after a 17-hour flight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--A dispute over whether the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff may be represented at military meetings by a deputy or by an assistant appeared today to have been resolved.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI)--James Meredith, who was graduated from the University of Mississippi, announced today that he planned to enroll at Ibadan University in Nigeria next fall.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI)--President Johnson's new committee to review aims and operations of the foreign aid program held an organizing meeting today.

MORFONTAINE GOLF CLUB, Thiers, France--There are more kinds of Socialism than most John Birchers can count, and the gods they worship are various and strange. I now offer a new geopolitical formula to distinguish among them--the golf course theory of Socialism.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Dec. 26--President Alfredo Stroessner, the politician with the big smile, has quietly been easing Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, the bemedaled military boss, into the background.
Commuters on the New Haven Railroad, conditioned by fifteen years of deteriorating service and increasing fares, face even grimmer prospects for 1964.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27-- The Justice Department has stayed action in eight suits against six maritime ports and terminals involving a possible $12 million in fines.
All major highways in the World's Fair area will be completed within a month, officials of the fair and of New York State said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--United States officials believe the Cambodian Government is ready to begin repairing its strained relations with Washington. This view was ex pressed privately here as the State Department announced its acceptance of a Philippine offer of good offices in the dispute.

The Margo Jones Award will be presented Feb. 15 for the third successive year. It is awarded to the producer anywhere in the United States or Canada whose policy of presenting new dramatic works is in the tradition of the late Miss Jones.

WARSAW, Dec. 27 (UPI)-- Poland and its Communist allies will celebrate the formal opening tomorrow of the last link of a giant pipeline which will carry crude oil from the heart of the Soviet Union to its East European allies.
MADRID, Dec. 27 (Reuters) the captain of the Greek cruise ship Lakonia today described his crew's behavior as perfect during the fire at sea that took 91 lives Sunday.
Commonwealth Edision Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the 11 and 12 months ended Nov. 30.
HAVANA, Dec. 27 (AP)-- At dawn next Friday a desperate fight for the life of the Cuban economy begins. That is the start of the new sugar harvest.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 27--President Johnson announced today that he would relieve Teodoro Moscoso as the coordinator of the Alliance for Progress and assign the responsibility to Thomas C. Mann, the new Assistant Secretary of State for Latin-American Affairs.

BUFFALO, Dec. 27--Despite a forecast of one to three inches of snow, a passing battle looms between Babe Parilli of Boston and Jack Kemp of Buffalo tomorrow when the Patriots meet the Bills in the Eastern Division playoff of the American Football League.

The marriage of Miss Bettina Baird Patterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jere Wescott Patterson of New York and Tuxedo Park, N. Y., to Second Lieut. Richard Jahn Sands, U.S.A., took place yesterday afternoon.
LONDON, Dec. 27--If a work of art bought in Britain for export is considered of national importance, it remains in Britain.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Saturday, Dec. 28--The Security Council met in emergency session late last night to discuss the conflict between Greek and Turkish elements in Cyprus.

The world of finance has discovered Avenue M in Brooklyn. For 27 years, the bustling, middle-class shopping district that straddles the Avenue M station of the BMT Brighton Line had no bank or savings institution of its own.
ROME, Dec. 27--A meeting in Jerusalem between Pope Paul VI and Patriarch Athenagoras of the Orthodox Church seemed today to be more likely than ever before.
"You are still thinking the way Newton thought; you've got to grow up."

Charles H. Whitmore, president of the Iowa-Illinois Gas and Electric Company, said yesterday the management planned to recommend to directors that the board act to split the common stock on a two-for-one basis. The board is scheduled to meet on Jan. 22.
A drop of 11.9 million barrels in the nation's stocks of light fuel oil in the week ended on Dec. 20, was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
EVANSVILLE, Ind., Dec. 22 (AP)--Evansville College used 16 players tonight, and 12 of them scored in a 96-60 victory over Columbia University in the Evansville holiday basketball tournament.

The Transit Authority announced yesterday that the Rev. John J. Lynch, the Fordham University seismologist, had agreed to advise it on the possible effects on delicate instruments at Rockefeller Institute of blasting a subway tunnel under the East River at 64th Street.
The president of Cooper Union warned yesterday that the private engineering college might eventually have to end its tuition-free policy.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (UPI)--Unheralded Georgetown upset previously unbeaten Loyola of Chicago, the nation's No. 1 team, 69--58, tonight in the opening round of the Quaker City basketball tournament.
The receiver for the Allied Crude Vegetable Oil Refining Corporation sold 1,265,000 pounds of tallow owned by the bankrupt concern for $78,876 yesterday.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 27 (AP) --Syracuse rallied from a 9point deficit in the second half and defeated Princeton, 76--71, tonight in the first game of the Hurricane Basketball Classic.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 27 --Mr. and Mrs. Christopher R. P. Rodgers have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Rodgers, to Alexander Banks Grannis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Uri Balcom Grannis Jr. of Rockford, Ill. A June wedding is planned.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 27 --Miss Mary Byron Gardner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Tytus Gardner, was married this afternoon to Pvt. Robert Neill 3d of the Army, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Neill Jr. of St. Louis.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--The year now coming to an end will probably be marked by the largest increase in consumer prices since 1958.
CHICAGO, Dec. 27--Leaders of the Modern Language Association want the Government to "declare English in the national interest."
LONG BRANCH, N. J., Dec. 27--A policeman was charged today with stealing $500 in cash from the A. supermarket here on Dec. 19 while working as a clerk during his off hours.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 27 (UPI)--The Florida State Seminoles capitalized on free throws in the closing seconds tonight to beat Manhattan, 85--81, and take third place in the Gator Bowl basketball tournament.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 27--Throughout the Davis Cup doubles match, Harry Hopman, Australia's nonplaying captain, was as impassive as a sheep rancher at the opera.

Christmas book buyers turned away from the customary dependence on the best-seller list while running up sales that probably set a record. Booksellers generally reported widely diversified buying and a very good season.

OTTAWA, Dec. 27--Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson announced today the first resignations from his Cabinet since his minority Liberal Government took office last spring. The two resignations started speculation on possible further Government shifts.

The grand ballroom of the Plaza was a garden of white chrysanthemums and smilax for the presentation last evening of 36 young women at the 15th annual debutante ball of the New York Junior League. Each debutante received a green feather fan in the tradition of the league, of which she is a provisional member.

In Christ Church Cathedral (Anglican) in Nassau, the Bahamas, yesterday, Miss Sharon Patricia Noonan became the bride of Philip David Morehead. The Very Rev. Frederick Eveleigh Ellis, the dean, performed the ceremony.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 27 (AP)--An unidentified $2 bettor in the crowd of 9,670 at Tropical Park won $50,678.60 today for picking the twin double.
THE cosmetics houses are not to be outdone by the fashion industry in glitter this year. Sequins and beading on dresses will be matched with luminous evening make-ups.
The bond market is expected to be quiet on a Friday of a holiday week, and that's what it was yesterday.

MOSCOW, Ohio, Dec. 27--A brand-new 1964 Detroit-produced station wagon carrying a visiting Russian automotive engineer and his family failed today on a lonely road between the Ohio River towns of Utopia and Moscow.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27 (UPI)--Bill Crothers of Toronto broke the six-year-old American indoor record for the 880yard run tonight with a time of 1 minute 50.2 seconds at The Examiner holiday invitation track meet.

WHEN Adam Clayton Powell became involved in the defamation action that led yesterday to his being adjudged in contempt of court, The Amsterdam News wrote the following headline on its story: "Ho Hum, They're 'After Adam' Again."
Representative Adam Clayton Powell was held in contempt of court yesterday for failing to appear in State Supreme Court to answer a $211,500 libel judgment.

The Texas hospitality that will accompany Chancellor Erhard's talks with President Johnson this weekend will be the visible symbol of a new fact in international relations. Over the past year a "special relationship" has come into being between Washington and Bonn resembling --though far less intimate than--that which has long existed between the United States and Britain.

MOSCOW, Dec. 27 (UPI)-- Mrs. Nikita S. Khrushchev, wife of the Soviet Premier, showed up today at an American graphic art exhibition that has been officially attacked here as "a kind of ideological subversion."

PINEHURST, N, C., Dec. 27 --William Caldwell Plunkett, owner of tobacco plantations here and a former business leader and Selectman of Adams, Mass., was killed yesterday at Waldorf, Md., by an automobile that struck him as he walked across a highway. His age was 59.
DALLAS, Dec. 27--A member of the Warren Commission and J. Lee Rankin, the commission's counsel, intend to come to Dallas early next year to question Mrs. Marina Oswald, Mr. Rankin said today.
CAIRO, Dec. 27--Twelve Arab League states agreed today to participate in a heads-of-state conference here to discuss unified action against Israel if she diverts Jordan River waters.
BOSTON, Dec. 27--Two leaders in water transportation have emphasized that the entire transport industry would benefit from tighter Government controls on rates.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 27 (AP)-- James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said today he expected to sign the union's first national trucking agreement on Jan. 15.

The National Broadcasting Company will televise events ranging from international skijumping to domestic table tennis on "N.B.C. Sports Special," a weekly series beginning Saturday, Jan. 4, from 4:30 to 6 P.M.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27-- The cleanup of the Baldwin Hills flood area began today. But the reason the dam broke remained obscure.
MR. SALINGER--Can I make a procedural announcement before we start? There are some of you who want to go back to Austin after the President makes these announcements.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27-- After many years in medicine and related science, Dr. Leandro W. Tomarkin has tackled the skidding problem. He believes he has the solution in a tire he patented this week.
The Dana Corporation, Toledo, Ohio, automotive parts manufacturer, achieved the highest quarterly sales and earnings in its history in the three months ended Nov. 30.
Gianna d'Angelo sang her first Amina with the company in the Metropolitan's "La Sonnambula" lash night. She gave a modest performance entirely 'suitable to the Bellini opera's gentle charm.

PERTH, Australia, Dec. 24-- The lights of Perth are burning late again these nights. This city, which blazed with light to help John H. Glenn Jr. mark his path in space as he orbited the world in 1962, now marks Christmas with a dazzling electrical display.
Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, the defending champion, won his seventh straight game in the United States Chess Championship Thursday night, beating William Addison of Los Angeles.

NEWARK, Dec. 27--A sixyear capital-improvement program that would replace Newark's 47-year-old ramshackle police headquarters, improve its sewage system, its library facilities and provide recreational services in depressed areas, was proposed today.

Camille Henry, the smallest man in the National Hockey League, beat the biggest team last night. His two goals in the third period enabled the New York Rangers to halt the pacesetting Chicago Black Hawks, 4--2, at Madison Square Garden.
"Do you think I'd make a good jockey?" asked the 200pounder in the wheelchair.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 30-- President Johnson got good news today from the chairman of his Council of Economic Advisers, who told him of six milestones the nation's economy reached is 1963.
CENTRAL ISLIP, L.I., Dec. 30--A former Long Island Rail Road engineer was arrested on the Southern State Parkway near here today as a suspected bank robber 24 minutes after the holdup had occurred.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 30-- The chief prosecutor demanded today the death penalty for Ivan-Asen Khristov Georgiev, a former diplomat accused of having spied for the United States.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 30 --The Thai Government has made progress this year in its intensifying struggle to block Communist subversion in Thailand's vulnerable northeast provinces.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30-- A special grand jury investigating alleged City Hall corruption said today it had found evidence of a "sinister connection" between the Democratic city committee and the Democratic-controlled City Council.

Villanova's colorful, speedy and erratic basketball team fought off bigger and stronger Minnesota last night and won, 77--73, to take the 12th annual Holiday Festival of the Eastern College Athletic Conference.

NEWARK, Dec. 30--Anthony DeAngelis and Ben Rotello, two prominent figures in the commodities scandal, followed a court-written script today and shed little light on a plot of major interest to the business community--the affairs of the Allied Crude Vegetable Oil Refining Corporation.

EL PASO, Dec. 30 (UPI)-- Southern Methodist University, a team on the way back, meets Oregon tomorrow in the Sun Bowl, a post-season football event on the way up. The game will be regionally televised.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 30--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara announced today that next year's Defense Department budget would be about $1 billion less than the $52 billion that will be spent this year.

WHEN the game ended, the only hot items in the Wrigley field igloo were the Giant players. They were boiling with an angry frustration. Every last one was convinced that the Giants were a better team than the Chicago Bears. Want to know something? They could have been right.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30--A Moscow automotive engineer whose family spent Christmas in an American home in Portsmouth, Ohio, insisted today that "what we saw was pretty much the picture of America we had gained from Soviet books, newspapers and magazines."
Cemetery workers voted last night to go on strike at 39 cemeteries in the New York metropolitan area at 8 A.M. Thursday.
An aged person who owns one of the Continental Casualty Company's special Golden 65 health insurance policies will be paying more to keep it next year.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 30 (AP) --Bob Ferry, who was held scoreless in the second half, spun the ball around the hoop and in with four seconds remaining tonight to give the Detroit Pistons a 114-112 overtime victory over the San Francisco Warriors.

A hitherto unreported courtesy by Moscow at the time of the assassination of President Kennedy was disclosed yesterday by members of the Robert Joffrey Ballet in the company's first press conference since its return from an eight-week tour of the Soviet Union.

Thelonious Monk, the pianist and jazz composer whose long struggle for recognition within the jazz fraternity has become almost legendary, appeared in a program of his own compositions last night at Philharmonic Hall.
